column1: Studenten leren zelfstandig verdiepende kennis op te doen over een fiscaal of fiscaal-economisch onderwerp en over dat onderwerp een onderzoek doen opzetten en zelfstandig doen uitvoeren, d.w.z. van het opstellen van een onderzoeksvraag tot het afronden van het onderzoeksverslag.
Studenten leren een relevante onderzoeksvraag te formuleren op het terrein van het zelfgekozen fiscale of fiscaal-economische onderwerp.

Studenten leren over hun onderzoek in overeenstemming met de geldende academische standaarden correct en bondig op logische en consistente wijze schriftelijk verslag te doen en dit vervolgens mondeling overtuigend te presenteren en te verdedigen.

column1: Het vak Materieel strafrecht borduurt voort op het B1-vak Inleiding strafrecht. In het onderhavige vak wordt dieper ingegaan op het materiële strafrecht. Het overkoepelende thema van het vak betreft ‘strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid’. Het vraagstuk wie, wanneer en waarvoor strafrechtelijk aansprakelijk is, valt uiteen in verschillende leerstukken zoals schuld, poging, deelneming en strafuitsluitingsgronden. De student doet niet alleen kennis op over de centrale begrippen en leerstukken van het materiële strafrecht, maar leert die kennis ook te gebruiken en toe te passen op een casus. Het analyseren van concrete materieel strafrechtelijke problemen (casuïstiek) vormt een belangrijk onderdeel van het vak.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Na dit vak kan de student:

column2: • De beginselen, systematiek en wetsbepalingen van het materiele strafrecht herkennen, analyseren en toepassen op een materieelstrafrechtelijke casus;
• De betekenis en functie van legaliteit begrijpen;
• De betekenis en functie van wederrechtelijkheid begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis en bewijsvormen van opzet herkennen, begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis en bewijsvormen van culpa herkennen, begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis van causaliteit begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis en het systeem van strafuitsluitingsgronden en culpa in causa begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis en het systeem van poging, voorbereiding en vrijwillige terugtred begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis en functie van ne bis in idem en samenloop begrijpen en het onderscheid tussen deze leerstukken herkennen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis van de verschillende deelnemingsvormen begrijpen en het onderscheid tussen de vormen medeplegen en medeplichtigheid herkennen en toepassen op een casus;
• Het systeem en de strafbaarheid van privaatrechtelijke en publiekrechtelijke rechtspersonen begrijpen en toepassen op een casus.
• De relevante jurisprudentie toepassen, analyseren en in onderling verband kritisch  beoordelen  mede  in  het licht  van  de  relevante  materieelrechtelijke beginselen.

column1: This Mathematics course presents the necessary Mathematical tools for analysing quantitative models that emerge from a variety of business and economic problems. The selection below reflects the scope of the studied Mathematical topics that will be useful for the analysis of economics and business problems. These topics are:

column2: • Functions and equations of one and two variables
• Sequences and series
• Financial applications
• Differentiation and optimization
• Integration
• Matrices

column1: This course lays the foundation for the quantitative courses to follow in the IBA curriculum. The scientific description and analysis of complex practical business situations often requires an analytic approach. What is usually needed is the explicit description of the transition of a system when it moves from one state to the next. Mathematics is well equipped to assist in the difficult task of describing the essential elements of such transitions. The word ""model"" is often used for the quantitative description of the specific problem in which a system finds itself at any moment in time. Working with models is a recurring activity in business studies. The process of building and analysing business models requires a Mathematical way of thinking. Therefore, mathematical skills are essential for successfully handling these business models.

IMPORTANT NOTICE: The concepts, skills, and methods from the ‘Preparation course mathematics’ are a prerequisite for this course. You will not be able to understand the course without having successfully mastered the learning goals of the preparation course.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After completing this course, students will be able to apply the mathematical techniques covered in this course and to build, analyze and solve mathematical models emerging from business problems using mathematical techniques from the course and interpret the solutions in terms of the original problem. A detailed list of learning goals per learning unit is available in the document ‘Material overview’ in the ‘Course Information’ on Canvas.

</style>

column1: Traditionally, HTA researchers and health economists have concentrated on health outcomes expressed in QALYs when attempting to measure the benefits from health care products or programs. There is growing recognition, however, that patient preferences also need to be taken into account and Discrete choice experiments (DCEs) are typically used for this purpose. DCEs allow for the investigation of many types of research questions, as it is an attribute-based measure of benefit. This course provides a resource for students in the health sector who want to familiarize themselves with assessment of patient preferences using DCEs. We present the fundamental principles and theory, demonstrate the process of conducting a choice study, and discuss the interpretation and policy implications of the results.

Course materials will be studied in lectures and workgroups and students will be actively involved in conducting their own DCE with the aim of increasing their understanding of what is being taught. Small groups will carry out a DCE study on a topic that is theirs to choose. Part of the work will be done during the work groups, and feedback will be provided continuously. The group's work will be evaluated on the basis of a short report about the DCE; individual members of the group may receive different grades based on their contributions.
The written examination is 70% of the final grade (minimum grade 5.0 or higher). The remainder derives from the group project (30%).
The re-sit is composed as a written examination (70%, minimum grade 5.0 or higher) and a group project (30%).

column1: <body>Understanding ‘the audience’ has long been a central concern in the fields of communication and media studies. This course offers a critical survey of academic research exploring the relationships between audiences and media technologies/texts. A variety of interdisciplinary perspectives will be addressed including active audience theory, spectatorship, media effects, uses and gratifications, critical/cultural studies, and fans/fandom. The literature used in this course applies these perspectives to a variety of media content/forms including television, cinema, videogames, and streaming video.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114783,2023,Media Economics and Media Management,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: In the field of media studies, the research focus often revolves around analyzing the outcomes produced by media industries. However, this course offers a different perspective by delving into the economic aspects of media markets and the strategic behavior exhibited by media firms within them. We aim to understand questions such as how TikTok managed to challenge existing social media or why gaming companies are leading the transition towards metaverse-like technologies (AR / VR).

To explore these and other compelling questions, we will delve into the core theoretical traditions of media economics. We will learn how to define markets in the context of media, examine the unique characteristics of media products, and closely investigate the rapid changes occurring within the media landscape. Subsequently, we will utilize literature on media management to comprehend how media firms respond to the economic structures, product attributes, and market dynamics they encounter.

This course will take an explicitly international perspective, incorporating diverse case studies from various regions around the globe. Through these case studies, we will analyze how the distinct economic characteristics of media products, as well as the societal and economic contexts in which they are offered, influenced the strategic management decisions made by media companies. Moreover, students will be required to conduct a case study of their own, exploring the behavior of a media firm within its designated market.

By the end of this course, students will gain a comprehensive understanding of media economics, enabling them to critically analyze and comprehend the intricate relationship between economic factors, media products, and the strategies employed by media firms in response to market changes.

• Take an international perspective on media economic research.
• Conduct case study research on media firms and their products.
• Formulate the implications of media economic analyses for strategic management decisions of media firms.

column1: The phenomenon of entrepreneurship is closely connected with a growing mediatization of organizations and society. In this way, media facilitate various creative processes and enables individuals and organizations to develop new ideas, facilitate new processes and build new ventures. At the same time, media entrepreneurship is a very young, but rapidly growing research area with a variety of backgrounds, concepts and methodological opportunities.

Therefore, the aims of this course are threefold. First, we aim to provide an overview of the field of media entrepreneurship and intend to spark critical investigations and shared discussions around its meaning. What is media entrepreneurship? What kind of styles, habits and practices can we see in different empirical settings? Second, we will explore current practices of entrepreneurship in the media and creative industries. How can we use media in creative manner to generate new opportunities and create sustainable organizational responses to the challenges we face? Third: These questions will be explored dialogically and creatively around different empirical phenomena in media entrepreneurship, for example through small research activities such as conducting market research or qualitative interviews with practitioners and analyzing these in class for further reflection.</body>

• Construct and develop responses for tackling issues in creative entrepreneurial manner;
• Synthesize and evaluate entrepreneurial actions in relations to current theoretical frameworks;
• Demonstrate the conduct of a qualitative interview with an entrepreneur.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114762,2023,Media Industries: Trends and Strategies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

column1: Media industries have experienced radical changes in recent years as a result of new digital technologies and distribution platforms (e.g. gaming, the internet, mobile platforms etc.). For companies, workers and policymakers operating within media industries, these changes have severely impacted their operations: previously separated media markets have converged, new media products and business models have been developed, and users are no longer passive consumers but are actively peer producing content (so called user generated content). This seemingly chaotic period media industries find themselves in is the starting point of this course.

During the course, students will familiarize themselves with the latest trends and developments in the media industries. We will start with theoretical foundations that are crucial for understanding and researching media industries and media innovation. We will then turn our attention to trends in the media industries, and discuss how these trends impact the strategic behavior of industry actors (companies, audiences, policymakers). In addition to discussing literature, we will also use guest lectures and online material (e.g. videos) to discuss trends and strategies within the media sector.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key concepts, approaches, developments, trends, problems and governance in theory and empirics of media industries and media innovation,
• Key analytical tools to define and study media industries
• Key analytical tools to define and study media innovation
• Reflect critically on the theoretical viewpoints and research materials presented in class
• Critically reflect upon developments in media industries and assess their impact and newness.
• Analyse current developments and strategies in the media industries using theories and concepts covered in the course

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114818,2023,Media Policies and Markets,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

column1: Governments have long held a significant interest in media markets, and their policies and regulations can profoundly shape the operational boundaries of media organizations. The justification for governmental scrutiny of the media often stems from societal expectations placed on the media sector. The rapid and dynamic changes occurring in the media industry have compelled governments worldwide to reevaluate their media policies. For example, the scandal involving Cambridge Analytica's misuse of Facebook users' data prompted many governments to reconsider their privacy regulations.

This course will employ models from media economics and institutional economics to conceptualize the intricate relationship between government policies and media markets. Additionally, we will delve into theories and developments surrounding policy and regulation, enabling us to analyze, critically evaluate, and contextualize media policies.

The seminar will bridge relevant issues within media policy with corresponding theoretical concepts. We will explore contemporary and international examples, ranging from the impact of fake news to issues of hate speech and AI-regulation. Through engaging discussions and debates, we will scrutinize these developments in media policy. Furthermore, we will strive to formulate alternative policy options that governments could have pursued. The seminar adopts a participatory approach, requiring students to actively prepare for lectures, engage in discussions, participate in debates, and deliver presentations.

column1: A decade ago, a travel agent was a legitimate job. Today, this line of employment has become redundant with online sites such as kayak, priceline and expedia that allow customers to shop virtually for competitive pricing. This new platform economy creates new questions regarding how algorithms shape the competitiveness of the travel and tourism industry and to what extent does this allow for a level playing field for companies in this sector. Further, the rise of the middle class in countries like India and China are producing new user groups that pushes tourism-related companies to rethink their advertising, city branding and packaging strategies that can best tailor to these new demographics.

In fact, across industries we see disruptions taking place with the rise of digital media, novel technologies and platforms, new data policies, governance measures, and new user groups. These trends demand that we reflect and rethink the ways in which these industries are being transformed and the repercussions on the future of work and wellbeing for our societies. This captures not just a shift in the nature of employment, but possibly the  birth of a new worldview, corporate ideology, management, and customer relations strategy where certain intermediaries have become digital.

This course consists of a series of expert lectures provided by various EUR staff. These lectures focus on various themes including (1) the effects of digitalization for media businesses, (2) the state of and trends within global media industries, (3) implications of digitalization for organizations, work and people, and (4) the processes of surveillance, mobilization and personalization, and this through specific case studies from diverse sectors.

Students will explore the global and political infrastructures at play as technology companies, laborers, user groups, and governance structures span across nations, complicating our understandings of a typical business today. We will jointly explore urgent ethical challenges, serious sustainability concerns, and dominant global trends in user behaviors, company practices, and national policies that pushes for a design thinking approach to “good” organizational practice.

Overall, the intent of this course is to gain a more critical perspective on the role of digital media and datafication in different industries  in order to shape more inclusive, ethical and sustainable business models and practices in this digital and global age.

column1: Advertising, materialism, and consumption are central aspects of modern societies across the globe. Contemporary societies are intertwined with consumer culture and marked by peoples continuously growing wants and needs, as well as the conspicuous consumption of mass produced and marketed goods. This course provides a psycho-cultural perspective on consumer culture, and advertising and branded space in particular. We examine the history of advertising, the commercial and social aspects of the messages conveyed by ads, and the advertising industry's influence on social relations and institutions such as politics. Furthermore, we discuss the various ways in marketing to classify consumers, such as the Values and Lifestyle Typology – and learn that individuals differ greatly in their (susceptibility to) consumer values.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
· Current theoretical perspectives and research methods in the field of consumer culture
· The history and commercial and social aspects of advertising
· Integrate knowledge gained from specific topics and integrate this in a focus written report
· Apply a psycho-cultural perspective on consumer culture, and critically reflect on the advertising industry’s influence on society
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110733,2023,Media and Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. L Ripoll Gonzalez'],,Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Complex governance processes in networks are constantly influenced by the outside world. This is especially happening through the media attention and the dynamics this generates in networks. Media have become a separate institution with its own logic (the media logic) and its own rules how to bring news and package it. Media logic is concerned with the content of the news provided as well as the formats in which news is created and processed. The format of an item on the television news bulletin for instance, has to meet certain criteria: the slot allocated for the story is only a few minutes long, it has to have news value and it should attract or keep the attention of the viewers. These criteria influence how reality is constructed in the news story.

column3: Many authors claim that media have profound influence on our daily social life, how policy problems are shaped and on various other institutions in society. And this becomes visible when media pay attention to governance processes. Not only does the visibility of these processes enhance but also the decision dynamics change considerably as agenda forming theories have been arguing for some time.

The mediatized world asks for public leaders who can communicate their messages in clear “sound bites,” who can adapt swiftly to new developments and “media hypes,” and who can create attractive brands which arouse positive associations with citizens and voters. But in this public leaders in modern network society are faced with a growing gap between the front stage of a mediatized political world on the one hand and the daily practical life of complexity of governance processes in networks on the other hand (the backstage).

In this course we explore the media as a separate institution, their influence on policy processes and the requirements it posed on public managers. But we also explore managerial strategies that public managers have to influence media attention, like (political) public relations, and public branding.

column2: </body>

column1: Migration has been a characteristic of societies for centuries. Humans have always migrated to either escape harsh lives, search for better ones, or both. Continuing immigration flows and increasing diversity in many societies have led to more complex processes of integration and the emergence of so-called transnationalism, a phenomenon characterized by cross-border engagements of migrants, organizations and institutions, as well as multiple embeddings of migrants in their (new) homelands. In this course,  we  focus on  the  critical  role  played by media and communication  in  the  different levels of the transnational condition of migration, ranging from mass media representations of migrants and refugees to the mediated communication exchanges conducted in digital spaces, from interactions between relevant stakeholders in the field of NGOs and policy-making through the political and economic side of migrants’ lives to the role played by hands-on intercultural mediation projects.

This course aims to offer a platform for students to develop their research skills for making sense of the intricate relationships between media and migration across different sociopolitical and cultural contexts (Western and non-Western) and drivers of migration (e.g., economic, political, cultural, humanitarian, environmental). In eight weeks, students will work on their own research project, covering topics related to migration, media and technology. Research projects involve building a theoretical argument pertaining to media and migration theories, contacting migration actors and developing digital proficiencies for producing a video essay paper in this field. Throughout this process, students will gain conceptual, empirical and practical knowledge for their master thesis projects.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The research workshop Media and Migration is oriented towards MA students who are interested in developing theoretical, empirical and practical (applied) projects in the field of media and migration, and intercultural communication. This course aims to offer conceptual, empirical and practical tools for building students’ knowledge about current (research) topics and trends in this interdisciplinary field that can also be used in the development of students' master thesis projects.

column2: • Current theoretical perspectives and key concepts in the study of media and migration.
• Video production in research on media and migration.
• Ethical issues and procedures in research involving migrant populations.
• The experiences of migrants in relation to communication practices and networks that involve digital media.
• Produce a video essay project on the topic of migrants and the media.
• Report and present their preliminary and conclusive findings in oral and written form.
• Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research.

column1: This course analyzes the close and multifaceted relationship between media and politics. It is largely through the media that citizens develop an idea of what the world of politics looks like and how it operates. All media are influential in this respect: not just broadcast news, newspapers, and current event magazines, but also (fictional) films and novels, and, increasingly, blogs and social media. Traditional media enable politicians, government officials, and other political actors to simultaneously reach millions of people. New technologies, in turn, intensify the possibilities of citizens themselves to engage politically with one another and to directly challenge politicians and authorities. Fictional media, finally, play an important role in letting us re-live, criticize and imagine politics beyond our everyday experiences. With this encompassing view of the relationship between media and politics in mind, we will pay special attention to politicians, journalists, and citizens/audiences, their interactions and the ways in which these interactions impact democracy. We will discuss different strategies through which politicians and other public figures try to turn the media into their allies, even at the expense of democratic values. We will also analyze journalistic practices and products, approaching them as responses to sometimes diverging interests, including those of politicians, audiences, and media organizations. Finally, we will ponder on political communication's alleged contributions to citizens' re- and/or de-politicization.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Key normative claims about the media in democratic societies.
• The relationships between media institutions and political institutions in international perspective.
• The roles of political reporters and other media professionals, politicians, and citizens in political communication processes.
• The forces and processes that shape political media content in specific ways.
• The effects of media coverage on citizen political attitudes and behavior, as well as the possibilities of citizens in shaping these effects.
• Recognize and articulate political communication concepts as they relate to different media content they encounter.
• Read, critique, and apply major political communication concepts to questions about media and society.
• Build arguments that synthesize and integrate knowledge about the relationship between media and politics.

column1: The idea that the media (can) have the power to change society and culture is at least as old as propaganda and censorship. And yet, questions about the relationship between media and socio-cultural change continue to be at the core of much communication and media research today. How does this relationship look like? (When) Do the media simply reflect social-change? (When) Can they also facilitate change? Do certain media genres, platforms, or media production models lend themselves to more conservative or revolutionary goals than others? What roles can people - activists, producers, and members of the audience, for example - play in this? How has the power of the media changed, especially in the last decades and with new technologies?

This course uncovers the complexities behind these questions. It looks for answers in the academic literature, as well as in students' own identification and observation of contemporary cases. Theoretically, the course relies on communication and media studies, as well as social theory more generally. Special attention is paid, for example, to ideology and hegemony, othering, representation, mediatization, media/technological determinism, structure and agency.
Since the relationship between the media and socio-cultural change is not only complicated, but also fluid and context-specific, the course adopts a historical and cross-national perspective.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

• Different ways in which media stimulate or hinder socio-cultural change.
• Diverse academic perspectives towards media and social-cultural change and key theoretical concepts therein.
• How current socio-political and technological developments are affecting the media’s role in relation to social change.
• Contemporary strategies used and related challenges faced by actors using the media for and against social change.
• Critically reflect upon, compare and articulate the strengths and weaknesses of different perspectives on the topic.
• Take and defend theoretical positions.
• Independently apply academic concepts and theories covered in the course to contemporary case studies and in their own work.

column1: In deze module staat ondernemerschap in de mediasector in het algemeen en in de journalistiek in het bijzonder centraal. We kijken naar bestaande en nieuwe businessmodellen, van zowel grote bedrijven, van jonge startups als van individuele professionals. Tijdens de module lezen studenten literatuur over deze businessmodellen, verdiepen zich in onderzoek op dit terrein en gaan in discussie met gastsprekers over inzichten uit de praktijk. Ze sluiten de module af met een paper of basis van eigen onderzoek. Thema’s als platformisering freelance journalistiek, content marketing, crowdfunding, kunstmatige intelligentie en betaalmuren passeren de revue. De module heeft als doel inzichten uit de theorie te verbinden met de actuele praktijk. Via deze weg leren we over de mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen voor bedrijven en professionals. Tevens komen de maatschappelijke implicaties van deze businessmodellen aan bod, zoals de toenemende vervaging van grenzen tussen journalistiek, amusement, voorlichting en PR.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Studenten hebben kennis van en inzicht in:

column2: • Businessmodellen in de mediasector;
• Onderzoek naar ondernemerschap in de mediasector;
• Actuele voorbeelden van ondernemerschap in de mediasector.
• De verschillen tussen theoretische en praktische kennis op dit terrein;
• De mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen;
• De maatschappelijke implicaties van deze businessmodellen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115437,2023,Media repertoires and their social ramifications,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. MNM Verboord'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>

column1: Media consumption and mediated cultural lifestyles are on the one hand very individual, but on the other hand also deeply social. Yet not all societal consequences of individual choices are immediately clear. Examples are “the wisdom of crowds” (individual knowledge may be limited but put together it becomes quite accurate) or the negative effects of Instagram (the individual incentive to post perfect pictures leads to peer pressure and mental health problems in the population).

This seminar explores how media consumption at the individual level impacts society, in a variety of ways. Starting point are media repertoires: patterns of media consumption that consist of (digital) media practices related to culture, entertainment, news, and social contacts.  We look at how media repertoires are shaped, inequalities in these repertoires, and explanations for these inequalities (in particular the role of cultural, economic, and social resources).

Next, we turn to social ramifications: possible and sometimes complex results of specific actions. For example, economic aspects of media consumption: what is popular in cultural markets, and how is popularity shaped? What does it mean for the cultural supply or what gets attention in the news? We look at symbolic aspects of media consumption: how are media or media products used as ways to distinguish oneself from others, or as identity marker? What gives status? And are there still cultural authorities whose opinions are trusted or followed? And finally, social aspects of media consumption are addressed: How important are social influencers or opinion leaders in a super-connected world? And what is the potential of media consumption to create social change?</body>

column1: This course focuses on the key role of the media and cultural industries in the international spread of culture. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but the past decades witnessed a significant intensification of international cultural flows. Among other reasons, this is a consequence of the introduction of new media technologies and the rise of multinational conglomerates in the media and cultural industries.

We will explore different theoretical approaches to examine the relationship between globalisation in the media and cultural industries, and the symbolic meaning of media products. Furthermore, during the weekly sessions of this course, we will discuss themes such as global cities, multiculturalism, global media events and cosmopolitanism. Both the meetings and the assignments will pay ample attention to the future of globalisation. We will use scenario-building techniques to explore the future connections between media, culture and globalisation. In these activities, theories about globalisation will be applied to societal and organisational problems.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key developments in the global spread of culture and the role of media therein.
• Different perspectives in the scholarly and public debate on the nature and impact of cultural globalisation.
• Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods in the analysis of globalisation processes and their social consequences.
• Critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form.
• Design and write an essay; make an academic argument.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115113,2023,Media, Games, and Creative Industry",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. LA Borges Lima'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: “But do you play games all day for work?” is a question faced by many academics in the realm of play, game, and videogame studies. Indeed, playing, and notably meaningful play, is a major component of such area, but not all there is to it. In this seminar, we invite you to explore the object of games – digital or not – in the encounter of media studies and the creative industry. The course is divided into three parts - production, content, and consumption – that aim to encompass the main characteristics of these different media and their central role in the creative industries. In production, we look at game developers and publishers, independent creators and groundbreaking game auteurs such as Shigeru Miyamoto (father of Mario and Luigi), and Hideo Kojima (Metal Gear Solid; Death Stranding), among others. You will learn the complex inner workings of the games industries and its employees. In the content part, we delve deep into matters of social, political and cultural contexts within games, present in their narratives and mechanics. We discuss examples such as the representation of War in board games and digital games; gender and sexuality in RPG’s; and fantasy and mental health. Lastly, in the consumption part, we turn our attention to players and their myriad of playful experiences. We explore matters related to fandom; online communities such as Reddit; online and couch play; affect, identification and emotion.

The course, although academic in nature, is an opportunity to engage both with the application of concepts into everyday media production, and the workers of games industry. As such, students will deliver assignments that include production of vlogging and gameplay, and an in-depth journalistic review of a videogame in either written or audiovisual form. Due to the nature of the topic, the course is comprised of both academic readings, popularly produced content (e.g. gameplays, journalistic reviews/game analysis, podcasts), and in-class/off-class play and game activities.</body>

column1: In dit vak verdiepen studenten zich in mediation als methode van conflictoplossing. Wat is de positionering van mediation in het brede scala van methoden van geschiloplossing en geschilbeslechting en hoe ziet de ontwikkeling van mediation in Nederland eruit? Harvard onderhandelen vormt de basis van mediation, wat is dit en hoe wordt dit toegepast? Welke verschillende stadia kent het mediationproces, welke interventies kunnen worden toegepast, welke juridische aspecten zijn tijdens het proces en met betrekking tot de uitkomst van dit proces van belang? Wat kunnen we leren van klacht- en tuchtrecht met betrekking tot mediation? Met de docenten en gastsprekers uit de praktijk gaan de studenten aan de slag met mediation in action door het opstellen van een mediationovereenkomst, een procesverslag of vaststellingsovereenkomst en het uitvoeren van mondelinge opdrachten, zoals het voeren van mediation- en onderhandelingsgesprekken.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114122,2023,Mediation advocacy: theory and practice,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. AJ de Roo', 'dr. RW Jagtenberg', 'mr. MM van Campen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In Western society, law students are led to believe that in-court adjudication is the self-evident and thus normal method for settling disputes. This conception, however, is far away from everyday reality. Apart from the fact that many disputes do not lend themselves to authoritative yes-or-no decisions, disputants may experience a series of problems when they choose to assert their rights in court, such as costs, delays, proof proceedings, uncertainty and unpredictability. Where bilateral negotiations are deadlocked and the resourcefulness of a third party is sought, other methods of dispute settlement than adjudication are therefore increasingly considered by disputants, particularly in areas such as construction, employment and family disputes.

Mediation and other modes of dispute resolution such as conciliation, Med.Arb., mini trial, fact finding, all belong to the A(lternative) D(ispute) R(esolution)-family. These methods tend to focus on the parties’ real interests and their future relationships. Possible legal problems relating to ADR are discussed such as the compatibility of ADR with the Right of Access to Court, and the legal status of mediated settlements; also in light of the UNCITRAL Singapore Convention.

In addition, national and European developments on court-annexed mediation shall be highlighted. In this context, the outcomes of inter alia the Dutch and other national mediation projects shall be discussed. Practical training is provided through role plays and other practical exercises, which are essential for a proper and profound understanding of the working of mediation (advocacy) – certainly for those who pursue a career in law practice.
Over the last decades, mediation has become one of the typical services provided by law practitioners. Obviously, law graduates should be abreast of this development, which is here to stay.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The aim of this course is to give the participating student an understanding of the wide variety of dispute settlement processes, with an emphasis on mediation and mediation advocacy. After completion of the course the student should be able to distinguish the various modes of dispute resolution from the perspective of a lawyer assisting client-disputants.
The student shall be assessed on area related knowledge and analytical skills.

<body>Is euthanasia of demented patients in a progressed state morally permissible? When should doctors refuse requests for new technologies of assisted reproduction, such as in vitro fertilisation (IVF)? Do we have a moral duty to fund orphan drugs? What should government, industry and individuals do in order to tackle problems like obesity or organ donation? Are new technologies to enhance the capabilities of human beings (such as cognition, social behaviour and mood, or physical appearance) morally desirable? Are patients with diverse cultural and ethnical background treated equally in the clinic?  Medical ethics and public health ethics are interesting and complex fields of study. In this course, we study pressing ethical issues and how theoretical approaches, concepts and methods may help us to deal with these issues. In the first part of the course, the most important theoretical approaches (utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics) and concepts in ethics and medical ethics (e.g. autonomy, paternalism, informed consent) will be introduced. In the second part of the course, the obtained knowledge will be applied to issues in medicine and public health care and critically reflect on central arguments including the influence of hidden assumptions and technological developments.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; mood, or physical appearance) morally desirable? Medical ethics and public health ethics are interesting and complex fields of study. In this module we study pressing ethical issues and how theoretical approaches, concepts and methods may help us to deal with these issues. The first couple of meetings are devoted to the most important theoretical approaches (utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics) and concepts in ethics and medical ethics (e.g. autonomy, paternalism, informed consent). Next, we will focus on issues in medicine and public health care and critically reflect on central arguments including the influence of hidden assumptions and technological developments.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Upon completion of this course students will have the ability to:

column5: identify and analyse moral problems in medical and public health ethics, notably on issues concerning medically assisted reproduction, end-of-life decisions, organ donation, enhancement technologies, public health measures, and justice in health care;
analyse, criticize and relate core concepts (e.g. autonomy, competence, informed consent, paternalism, justice, responsibility for health etc) to practical debates;
to explain how (anthropological) assumptions play a role in the moral debate;
argue for particular points of view in concrete problem cases and to acknowledge the strength and weakness of relevant arguments;
evaluate their own ethical beliefs and justify their recommended courses of action.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114538,2023,Medical innovation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. A Omidvari', 'prof.dr. MJ IJzerman']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Medical Technologies and Innovation have significantly contributed to a better quality of life and improved life expectancy. Without high-tech equipment in hospitals, many surgeries would not have been possible and communicable diseases would not have been treated. In some other areas, the development of targeted treatments (such as cancer immunotherapy) and advanced (molecular) imaging has enabled more precise diagnoses and treatment pathways, while genomic sequencing has revealed the origin of many hereditary diseases thereby providing new avenues for intervention. And medical innovation continues. New technologies, such as artificial intelligence and predictive analytics, mRNA production technologies or pharmaceutical discoveries can further improve health outcomes. However, against the background of a continued increase in spending on healthcare, concerns about climate impacts, growing disparities in outcomes in our population, the relative small improvements of (expensive) new technologies and the failure of successfully translating new discoveries, it is critically important to take a wider, societal, angle when analysing the value of new medical innovations.

This course covers the principles of innovation in healthcare with an emphasis on (bio-) medical technologies. Taking a technology life cycle viewpoint, this course aims to guide researchers, physicians, data scientists, and engineers to understand the journey of medical innovation as well as to identify the barriers faced when introducing new (bio-) medical technologies. Participants will have also the opportunity to enhance their learning outcomes by engaging with a number of different topics.

Attendance of 8 out of 9 sessions is required to earn 20% of the final grade. It is your responsibility to ensure you have covered the contents of the session you may be absent. Attendance in sessions with guest lectures (if scheduled) is mandatory.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: This course deals with the vast and important area of memory. Memory forms the basis for much of human cognition and behavior. We use our memory not only to remember the groceries we have to buy at the supermarket or to remember where and when to meet a friend, we also need our memory to engage in a conversation, to make calculations, to recognize loved ones, and even to ski downhill. In other words, memory plays an essential role in our daily lives. This becomes even more evident when we consider patients who have severe memory disorders caused by an accident or disease.

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: At the end of the course, students have
- knowledge and understanding of the most important theories and empirical findings of short-term memory (at an intermediate level);
- knowledge and understanding of the most important theories and empirical findings of long-term memory, including semantic and implicit memory tasks and skill learning (at an intermediate level);
- knowledge and understanding of the biological basis of human memory and memory disorders (at an introductory level);
- knowledge and understanding of some important mathematical models of human memory (at an introductory level); and
- basic skills needed to critically evaluate claims in research papers.

column1: Mergers and acquisitions (M&A) are among some of the most important decisions for firms. In boom times, firms have used M&As to expand into new product markets or geographies to increase their future competitive advantage. During economic downturns, firms have resorted to M&As to increase their chances of survival. Many students entering the corporate world are thus likely to be affected by an M&A deal as managers, employees, financial advisors, or stakeholders.

This course provides an overview of topics relating to M&A from a financial perspective. The following broad topics will be covered: (i) drivers of M&A, (ii) considerations underlying deal structures, payment, and financing choices, (iii) capital market implications of M&A, and (iv) valuation, risk management, and corporate governance in the context of M&A.

The course is case-based. It consists of meetings where we discuss case studies on specific deals. Each case has assignment questions to facilitate preparation and analysis. Students are required to arrive to class ready to discuss in detail their views on the decisions at stake in the case and to describe and debate their analysis. Active participation is expected, and students must prepare each case ahead of time. Cases are supplemented with short lectures on theory and empirical evidence (normally after each case discussion), reading assignments, and handouts. Several guest speakers will participate.

Presence in class is important because the learning experience in the classroom cannot be replicated elsewhere. Therefore, presence in class is a requirement. You are allowed to have two absences without explanation (i.e., you do not need to seek any permission). Further absence without a legitimate reason (time clash with exams, illness, etc.) will result in a zero participation grade for the missed meeting.

• Evaluate rationales for M&A. Assess the strategic and economic underpinnings of synergies.
• Understand various deal structuring choices and the financing of M&A bids.
• Value targets and synergies using alternative techniques, critically assess valuation assumptions, and use option valuation techniques to understand complex bid structures.
• Given the deal terms, assess a deal from the perspectives of acquirer and target shareholders.
• Assess the role and function of corporate boards in the M&A process.

column1: This course introduces framing theory and discusses its relevance for media and communication studies. The seminars focus on framing theory and discuss practical challenges in message framing and persuasion.

This course teaches students how organisations (private and public), the news media, and audiences interact through public relations and how communication professionals strategically frame their messages. This has a theoretical and a practical dimension. In the theoretical part, students learn what framing in the media is: The modern public sphere builds on dynamic media technologies and complex networks of media- and communication organisations. Audiences learn about current issues and important developments in business, culture, and society through different types of media. Modern communications and PR professionals need to understand the complex interplay of content (language and visuals), technology (channels and formats) and relationships between relevant stakeholders (the target audience, key media outlets, and other organisations) that underlie and shape framing processes. A successful combination of content, technology, and relationships with media organisations can make a profound impact on how audiences perceive a particular message, i.e., pick up on its framing.

Understanding this process eventually enables communication experts to design and execute effective campaigns that build up, reinforce, enhance, or repair an organization’s public reputation. Practical use cases include e.g., product/campaign launches, policy implementations, or crisis management. In the practice-oriented part of the course, students learn how to frame issues through strategic communication in written and spoken word, using modern technology (mainly via a press kit and press conference).

Public and private organisations are often at the center of news reporting in diverse contexts. It is essential for communication professionals to have in-depth knowledge about how public communication and framing in the media work in a digital society, so that they can represent their organisation strategically and result oriented.</body>

column1: De cursus omvat twee luiken die op elkaar afgestemd worden: een logisch luik en een systematisch luik.

In het logische luik bestuderen we de predicatenlogica. We beschouwen dan ook redeneringen waarvan de correctheid niet alleen steunt op de betekenis van de voegtekens maar ook op de betekenis van de kwantoren “voor alle"" en “er is minstens één"". We onderscheiden het semantische begrip “geldig gevolg van” en het syntactische begrip “afleidbaar uit” en bestuderen de relatie tussen deze twee begrippen.

In het systematische luik worden de centrale problemen uit formele ontologie en de analytische metafysica aan de orde gesteld: universalia, substanties, tijd, compositie, persistentie, causaliteit, responsafhankelijkheid en wereldbeelden.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: 1.. De student is vertrouwd met de formele taal van de predicaten logica (welke naast de logische voegtekens de kwantoren “voor alle"" en “er is minstens één"" bevat), bekend met de (beperkte) uitdrukkingskracht van deze formele taal en in staat om alledaagse deductieve argumenten te vertalen naar de taal van de predicaten logica.

2. De student is vertrouwd met Tarski’s waarheidsdefinitie voor de taal van de predicaten logica en gerelateerde noties zoals model, vervulbaarheid, vrije en gebonden variabele en in staat om, gebruik makend van deze noties, (alledaagse) argumenten op hun geldigheid te beoordelen.

3.  De student is vertrouwd met een tableau (afleidings-) systeem voor de predicatenlogica en in staat om dit systeem  te gebruiken om na te gaan of een argument (on)geldig is en, indien een argument ongeldig is, een tegenvoorbeeld te construeren.

4. De student is vertrouwd met enkele toepassingen van (het modelbegrip uit) de predicaten logica in de analytische filosofie, met name in de analytische metafysica, en in staat om zich hier kritisch tot te verhouden.
5. De student kan standpunten formuleren en onderbouwen betreffende ontische, ontologische en metafysische onderwerpen

6. De student kan zelf aspecten van wereldbeelden ontrafelen, uitwerken, in relatie brengen tot klassieke, ontische, ontologische en metafysische denkbeelden en teksten, en er zich kritisch toe verhouden
7. De student kan de belangrijkste auteurs, begrippen, distincties, en theorieën uit de metafysica identificeren, omschrijven, vergelijken en toepassen.</body>

column1: In het vak maak je kennis met basisconcepten uit de methodologie, zoals de soorten variabelen in een studie, observationele studies en experimenten en eenvoudige experimentele onderzoeksontwerpen. In het statistiekdeel start je met het beschrijven en visueel weergeven van de scores op 1 enkele variabele en de samenhang tussen de scores op 2 variabelen. Vervolgens ga je in op elementaire kansrekening, De tweede helft van het vak richt zich op toetsende statistiek. Toetsende statistiek heeft betrekking op technieken die onderzoekers gebruiken om conclusies te trekken over onbekende populatieparameters op basis van onderzoeksgegevens uit een steekproef.

In de opleidingen psychologie en pedagogische wetenschappen word je opgeleid tot wetenschapper. Dit houdt onder andere in dat je in staat bent om zelfstandig op een methodologisch verantwoorde manier data te verzamelen en dat je in staat bent om de verzamelde data te ordenen in een dataset waarop je vervolgens bewerkingen kunt uitvoeren. Je moet data dus invoeren, beschrijven en analyseren en hiervoor gebruik je een dataverwerkingsprogramma. SPSS is een programma dat veel gebruikt wordt, en het is geschikt voor beginnende studenten vanwege zijn gebruiksvriendelijkheid. In het practicum krijg je daarom een introductie op het werken in SPSS. Je zult merken dat dit practicum nauw verweven is met het vak.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Als je actief meegedaan hebt tijdens dit vak dan heb je basale kennis van en basaal begrip van verschillende methodologische en statistische concepten en procedures. Je bent dan in staat om deze concepten en procedures toe te passen om eenvoudige onderzoeksvragen te beantwoorden, om eenvoudige onderzoeksgegevens te interpreteren en om kritisch te redeneren over eenvoudige onderzoeksvraagstukken.
Meer specifiek heb je als je actief deelgenomen hebt aan het vak dan heb je:

column2: • Basale conceptuele kennis en begrip van methoden van kennisverwerving met een nadruk op de wetenschappelijk methode volgens de empirische cyclus;
• Basale conceptuele kennis en begrip van kenmerken en doelen van wetenschap;
• Basale conceptuele kennis en begrip van verschillende onderzoeksopzetten: observationeel/correlationeel versus experimenteel onderzoek;

• Basale conceptuele kennis en begrip van psychologisch onderzoek: methoden van steekproeftrekking, willekeurige toewijzing, controlemaatregelen in experimenteel onderzoek, confounding en lurking variabelen, binnengroeps en tussengroeps onderzoeksontwerp.

• Basale conceptuele kennis en begrip van typen variabelen, meetniveaus van variabelen, visuele weergaven van de scores op 1 variabele of de samenhang van scores op 2 variabelen, centrummaten, spreidingsmaten, boxplots, relaties tussen twee kwantitatieve variabelen en relaties tussen twee kwalitatieve variabelen;
• Basale conceptuele kennis en begrip van Z-scores, kansdichtheidsfuncties en normale verdelingen;
• Basale conceptuele kennis en begrip van elementaire kansrekening, continue en discrete kansvariabelen;

• Basale conceptuele kennis en begrip van steekproeventheorie, centrale limietstelling, parameterschatting (betrouwbaarheidsintervallen voor een gemiddelde en voor verschillen tussen gemiddelden), statistische toetsing (null hypothesis significance testing) en power;
• Basale conceptuele kennis en begrip van statistische toetsingsmethoden voor 1 of 2 gemiddelden.

• Procedurele kennis van berekeningen van centrummaten, spreidingsmaten, z-scores, correlaties, kruistabellen, nulhypothese toetsing (z-toetsen en t-toetsen) voor 1 gemiddelde of voor twee gemiddelden en statistische power.

column1: Wanneer je actief deelgenomen hebt aan dit practicum dan;

column2: • Heb je kennis van belangrijke componenten van de SPSS omgeving.
• Kun je een eenvoudige dataset maken in SPSS
• Kun je verschillende databewerkingstechnieken uitvoeren in SPSS.
• Kun je SPSS gebruiken om verschillende beschrijvende statistieken te berekenen.
• Kun je SPSS gebruiken om een verschillende t-toetsen uit te voeren.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: Een belangrijk onderdeel - zo niet het belangrijkste - van het verrichten van sociaal wetenschappelijk onderzoek is het beschrijven, verklaren en voorspellen van menselijk gedrag en van fenomenen in de wereld om ons heen. Om de complexe patronen die hier achter schuil gaan in kaart te kunnen brengen, hebben we een hulpmiddel nodig. Het hulpmiddel dat door veel pedagogen wordt gebruikt, is het gebruik maken van ""getallen"". We proberen gedrag te meten en dit om te zetten in getallen, die het gedrag representeren. Door vervolgens de getallen met het juiste arsenaal aan statistische technieken te bewerken, worden de achterliggende complexe patronen ontdekt.

In dit blok leert de student het analyseren van complexere gegevens dan in het eerste jaar. Er wordt relatief veel aandacht besteed aan het zelfstandig uitvoeren van de geleerde statistische technieken op de computer. Hierbij ligt de nadruk op het interpreteren van de output en het trekken van de juiste conclusies. Aan de hand van analyse-opdrachten zal worden geleerd hoe de verkregen resultaten moeten worden gerapporteerd en geëvalueerd. Onderwerpen die aan bod zullen komen, zijn: Proporties, Kruistabellen, Relaties tussen variabelen, Enkelvoudige en meervoudige Regressie, 1-factor-ANOVA, 2-factor-ANOVA, Herhaalde metingen-ANOVA en Onderzoeksmethoden.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • een beschrijving te geven van onderzoeksmethoden en geavanceerde statistische en methodologische concepten;
• deze concepten te hanteren bij het formuleren, beantwoorden en interpreteren van realistische onderzoeksvragen op het gebied van de pedagogische wetenschappen, onderwijskunde en psychologie;
• een beargumenteerde keuze te maken voor onderzoeksdesigns en geavanceerde analysetechnieken.
<title></title>

column4: Dit practicum is nauw verbonden met de inhoud van de onderwijsgroepen. In het practicum leren de studenten statistische analyse uit te voeren met het programma SPSS aan de hand van. een aantal casussen. Elke casus omvat een realistische onderzoeksvraag. Over elke casus beantwoorden studenten met behulp van SPSS een aantal vragen. Ieder groepje geeft voor één casus een presentatie in de onderwijsgroep in de vorm van een onderzoeksbespreking. Daarnaast maakt elke subgroep een onderzoeksverslag van elke casus. Dit resulteert voor elk groepje uiteindelijk in een portfolio van de onderzoeksverslagen.

column1: Een belangrijk onderdeel - zo niet het belangrijkste - van het verrichten van sociaal wetenschappelijk onderzoek is het beschrijven, verklaren en voorspellen van menselijk gedrag en van fenomenen in de wereld om ons heen. Om de complexe patronen die hier achter schuil gaan in kaart te kunnen brengen, hebben we een hulpmiddel nodig. Het hulpmiddel dat door velen wordt gebruikt, is het gebruik maken van ""getallen"". We proberen gedrag te meten en dit om te zetten in getallen, die het gedrag representeren. Door vervolgens de getallen met het juiste arsenaal aan statistische technieken te bewerken, worden de achterliggende complexe patronen ontdekt.

In dit blok leert de student het analyseren van complexere gegevens dan in het eerste jaar van de bachelor. Er wordt relatief veel aandacht besteed aan het zelfstandig uitvoeren van de geleerde statistische technieken op de computer. Hierbij ligt de nadruk op het interpreteren van de output en het trekken van de juiste conclusies. Aan de hand van analyse-opdrachten zal worden geleerd hoe de verkregen resultaten moeten worden gerapporteerd en geëvalueerd.
In dit blok komende de volgende onderwerpen aan bod:

column2: • proporties
• kruistabellen
• relaties tussen variabelen
• enkelvoudige en meervoudige regressie
• 1-factor-ANOVA
• 2-factor-ANOVA
• herhaalde metingen-ANOVA
• onderzoeksmethoden
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • De behandelde onderzoeksmethoden, designs, statistische analysetechnieken en methodologische concepten te beschrijven en begrijpen;

• De behandelde onderzoeksmethoden, designs, statistische analysetechnieken en methodologische concepten toe te passen bij het formuleren en onderzoeken van realistische onderzoeksvragen op het gebied van de pedagogische wetenschappen, onderwijskunde en psychologie;
• Onderzoeksmethoden, designs en statistische analysetechnieken te evalueren, vergelijken en keuzes te maken op basis van argumenten.
• Bij het beantwoorden van de onderzoeksvragen gegevens te analyseren en de resultaten vervolgens kritisch te evalueren.

column1: Het vak Methoden en technieken I biedt een eerste kennismaking met de belangrijkste manieren van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek die in de criminologie worden gebruikt. Tijdens de onderwijsgroepen en de hoorcolleges wordt aandacht besteed aan onderwerpen en begrippen die van belang zijn om gedegen sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek te kunnen herkennen en zelf uit te kunnen voeren. Dit omvat het formuleren van de probleemstelling, het bepalen van het onderzoeksontwerp (ook wel design genoemd), het kiezen van de methoden van data verzamelen, het operationaliseren van concepten, het kiezen van de technieken om de data te analyseren, de interpretatie van de bevindingen en het doen van uitspraken ten behoeve van de beantwoording van de probleemstelling. Zowel kwantitatief als kwalitatief onderzoek komen bij het vak aan de orde. Tijdens de practica gaan de studenten zelf oefenen met het uitvoeren van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek. Tijdens de kwantitatieve practica wordt met verschillende analysetechnieken in SPSS geoefend. Ook zijn er kwalitatieve practicumbijeenkomsten waarin de studenten (in kleine groepen) oefenen met interviewvaardigheden.

</style>

column1: 1.         de basisbegrippen van methoden en technieken van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek omschrijven en uitleggen
2.         design en kwaliteit van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek herkennen, indelen en uitleggen
3.         de kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve onderzoekscyclus beschrijven en uitleggen
4.         uitleggen waarom en wanneer kwantitatief onderzoek en kwalitatief onderzoek wordt gebruikt binnen de criminologie
5.         uitleggen wanneer je op basis van onderzoek generaliserende uitspraken kunt doen en bijbehorende kernbegrippen omschrijven en uitleggen
6.         verschillende methoden van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve dataverzameling herkennen en omschrijven
7.         omschrijven en uitleggen wat beschrijvende analyse en verklarende analyse inhoudt
8.         de basisbegrippen van statistische analyse omschrijven, uitleggen en toepassen bij het maken van statistieksommen en het interpreteren van SPSS output
9.         zelfstandig met SPSS werken: variabelen definiëren en construeren, en enkele beschrijvende analysetechnieken en verklarende analysetechnieken uitvoeren
10.       verschillende soorten interviewvragen kunnen herkennen, beoordelen en zelf formuleren (in een gegeven situatie)
11.       verschillende interviewtechnieken, houdings- en communicatieaspecten kunnen herkennen, beoordelen en toepassen (in een gegeven situatie)
12.       het beheersen van enkele basisfunctionaliteiten van AtlasTi: het uploaden van transcripten en het toekennen van ‘quotations’ aan tekstsegmenten
13.       het interview in verband brengen met de theorie en de onderzoeksvraag

column1: In dit tweede methodevak van de opleiding Criminologie wordt de kennis uit Methoden en Technieken I verdiept. Er wordt een verscheidenheid aan methodes en toepassingen daarvan aangeleerd  met betrekking tot het verzamelen en analyseren van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve gegevens. Na afloop van dit vak is de student er klaar voor om zijn eerste eigen onderzoek te gaan uitvoeren.

Er wordt in dit vak een mixed methods-onderzoek uitgevoerd, waarbij met zowel kwantitatieve als kwalitatieve methoden grootstedelijke problematiek (criminaliteit, sociale veiligheid, armoede en inclusiviteit) in (gemarginaliseerde) wijken wordt onderzocht.

In het kwantitatieve gedeelte van het vak ligt de focus op het analyseren van cijfermatige data. Na de beschrijvende analyses die in Methoden en Technieken I zijn behandeld, worden nu methoden geleerd om (complexe) samenhang tussen variabelen te analyseren. Daarbij gaan we uitgebreid in op situaties waarbij meer dan twee kenmerken onderling samenhangen (multivariate analyse).

In het kwalitatieve gedeelte van het vak ligt gaan we kwalitatieve data verzamelen via diepte-interviews en (participerende) observaties en deze vervolgens op kwalitatieve wijze analyseren in Atlas.ti. Tevens zullen we kritisch en systematisch reflecteren op de manier waarop we kwalitatieve data verzamelen en analyseren (methodologische en ethische reflectie).</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Studenten zijn na dit vak in staat een gefundeerde keuze te maken uit dataverzamelings- en analysemethoden, voor exploratief, beschrijvend, verklarend en toetsend onderzoek. Daartoe hebben zij naast de kennis uit Methoden en Technieken I nu ook inzicht in de basiskenmerken en principes van kwalitatieve dataverzamelingsmethoden als interviewen en observeren en van belangrijke bestaande kwantitatieve databronnen. Studenten kunnen bovendien de gegevens die voortkomen uit kwalitatief onderzoek coderen en analyseren en weten welke methodologische en ethische problemen er kleven aan kwalitatief onderzoek.

Wat betreft kwantitatieve analysemethoden kunnen studenten bivariate en multivariate analyses uitvoeren met variabelen van verschillende meetniveaus en de uitkomsten daarvan interpreteren en daarover rapporteren. Ook zijn studenten in staat methoden en resultatenbeschrijvingen in wetenschappelijke literatuur te begrijpen en kritisch na te gaan of de uitspraken die worden gedaan terecht zijn, gegeven de gebruikte onderzoeksmethoden.
Tot slot kunnen zij hun reflecties en kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve bevindingen integreren en presenteren in één wetenschappelijk eindverslag.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit practicum gaan de studenten actief aan de slag met de praktische uitwerking van wat in het algemeen wordt gezien als de basis voor het handelen in het forensisch werkveld, namelijk het risicobeginsel, het behoeftebeginsel en het responsiviteitsbeginsel. Studenten leren (1) op basis van gevalideerde instrumenten het recidiverisico in te schatten, (2) hoe in behandeling te interveniëren op criminogene en niet-criminogene behoeften van een cliënt en (3) hoe om te gaan met niet-gemotiveerde cliënten en hoe motiverende gespreksvoering toe te passen in de forensische praktijk.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afronding van dit practicum hebben studenten:

column2: • kennis van de in het forensisch werkveld veelgebruikte What works?-principes uit het Risk-Needs-Responsivity model (Bonta & Andrews, 2007; Ward & Stewart, 2003) en daarmee van de uitgangspunten voor effectieve diagnostiek en behandeling in een forensisch kader;;
• kennisgemaakt met de rol van risicotaxatie in het forensisch veld;
• kennisgemaakt met de rol van risicotaxatie in het forensisch veld;
• zicht op de behandeling van criminogene en niet-criminogene behoeften van cliënten en kennen zij het onderscheid tussen statische en dynamische risicofactoren;
• zich bewust van algemene werkzaamheid van interventies en de noodzaak in behandeling rekening te houden met specifieke eigenschappen van de cliënt in zijn specifieke context;;
• basisvaardigheden van motiverende gespreksvoering (Miller & Rollnick, 2012) onder de knie.

column1: De student is in staat om zonder instructie en met enige begeleiding (onderdeel schrijfonderwijs):

column2: • Een samenhangende en heldere rapportage te schrijven;
• Een professionele schrijfstijl toe te passen en deze af te stemmen op een specifieke doelgroep (e.g. kinderen, ouders, leerkrachten en andere professionals);
• Een casusbeschrijving conform NVO-richtlijnen betreffende de BAPD te schrijven.

column1: The course will introduce students to key concepts and arguments surrounding:

A) Theoretical modelling: explanation, understanding, idealization and abstraction, causal tendencies, modal hypotheses, the distinction between the practice of theoretical model building and applied models.

B) Causal inference: the Causal Markov assumption, exogeneity, heterogeneity, choosing an appropriate set of control variables, background causal knowledge, Bayesian methods, and hypothetico-deductive approaches in economics, especially Friedman’s instrumentalism.
C) Econometrics: the Lucas critique / microfoundations debates, structural models, the assumptions of regression analyses, representative agent models, methodological individualism

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: By the end of this course, students can:

1) Clarify the aims of idealized modelling in economics, and critically assess whether these models meet these aims, drawing on the debate between Cartwright, Alexandrova, Sugden, Reiss, Maki, Hausman and Till Grune Yanoff.
2) Examine the extent to which economics is value-laden, and evaluate whether this is desirable or undesirable

3) Explain and distinguish the main obstacles to causal inference in economics, both for observational studies using regression analysis or instrumental variables techniques, or for social experiments.

4) Relate these general obstacles to causal inferences in economics to particular issues arising in econometrics, including the debate over microfoundations for macroeconomic models, influential critiques of macroeconomics by Leamer and Roemer.

column1: This course deepens the methodological expertise that students have gained in previous studies or preparatory trainings. While the course covers the basic features and applicability of various research methods, the emphasis is on students’ own usage of these methods.

The focus is on some of the most commonly used methods of data gathering and data analysis in the social sciences in general, and the field of media and communication in particular. Half of the course will therefore focus on quantitative research methods (such as surveys, experiments, and quantitative content analysis) and how to analyse data (using T-tests, Anova, factor, and regression analysis). The other half will focus on qualitative methods (such as interviews, documents, media content, observations) and how to analyse these data (using thematic analysis, discourse analysis, and visual analysis). Questions regarding validity and reliability of research will be addressed throughout the course.

In the weekly seminars time is spent on practicing methods, while weekly lectures cover the methodological steps more in-depth and from a theoretical perspective. Students will apply some of the methods they practiced with during the course to complete a qualitative- and a quantitative-methods assignment.

The course thus contributes to students’ ability to conduct research independently and strengthens the skills needed in the research workshops and the MA thesis, which follow later in the program. For each MA specialisation, the assignments in the course will be designed to connect to specific foci of the specialisation.

column1: Students have knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Common research methods in the field of media and communication.
• Key differences in how specific research methods are used and the kinds of data they convey.
• Strengths and weaknesses of each discussed research method.
• ethical issues in media and communication research.

column1: Students have developed the skills to:

column2: • Evaluate research designs, measuring instruments, and sampling strategies (for the methods concerned).
• Collect empirical data in a research project.
• Develop their own research designs, measuring instruments, and sampling strategies in relation to concrete research questions about media production, content and usage.
• Reflect on the ethical issues important to the research design and methods proposed.
• Reflect on their use of different research methods.
• Report their analyses in oral and written form.

column1: This course focuses on qualitative research methods employed in the social sciences, particularly when studying phenomena in culture, media, and history. Various qualitative research methods are contextualized, and students are familiarized with their specific characteristics, epistemological approaches, and uses in scientific research. The course dedicates attention to the practical implementation and execution of these methods. Students learn how to formulate fitting research questions, create research designs, operationalize theoretical concepts, and conduct interviews and (participant) observations. They gain practical experience in various methods of data collection and analysis. The primary focus of this course is semi-structured interviewing, but ample consideration will be given to ethnographic field research, qualitative content analysis, and emerging methods within sociology and cultural studies.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: <body>After completing the course, students have knowledge and understanding of the characteristics and applicability of a range of qualitative research methods. They will be able to apply particular methods such as participant observation and (semi) structured interviews, and will be able to argue for and against the use of qualitative data analysis methods like grounded theory and (critical) discourse analysis. Apart from a cognitive approach to qualitative research methods, students will learn how to design and execute a research project from proposal to report.
