column1: The Master thesis - including the thesis proposal – constitutes an important piece of academic work you engage with during the spring semester of the MScBA - Master in Management. The Master thesis requires students to conduct independent, individual research in one of the functional domains (‘profile’) in business administration addressing key managerial issues. The thesis is perceived as a proof of academic level thinking and intellectual and analytical craftsmanship. During the thesis trajectory MiM students study a field in business administration in more depth.

The thesis provides students with an opportunity to deepen their understanding of an area of interest, as they need to critically explore a concrete managerial problem in the chosen domain and come to well-argued and managerially relevant conclusions. It allows them to improve their skills in practical scientific business and management research, and also to develop a personal profile.

While following the regular structure of an academic thesis at RSM[1], MiM students pay special attention to the impact of their results for business and their managerial relevance. In line with RSM’s mission students are also expected to explicitly reflect on how their results contribute to relevant SDGs. The thesis topics cover the main domains in business administration, e.g., marketing, strategy, finance, supply chain etc. but the research objective must be put in the bigger context of supporting good business administration. The title of the thesis will be mentioned on your grade list. Therefore, it is recommended to choose a title clearly indicating the business relevance.

The main objective of the Master thesis is to familiarize students with carrying out business and management research and to gain a deeper understanding of a topic of interest. Knowledge and understanding of business and management research is relevant in both business and academic settings. Training in business research methods prepares students to systematically investigate questions management is confronted with or to evaluate whether studies and proposals prepared by third parties (e.g., consultancy agencies) can serve as a basis for management decisions.

The Master thesis trajectory continues the development of professional skills in practical scientific business and management research. It follows the course on Business Analytics (BM21MiM) where students’ previous methodological training was tested and extended with special attention to quantitative empirical methods.

The research clinic (BMRSCMiM) directly supports the thesis trajectory. It helps students see what it takes to go from an interesting research topic, to specifying a concrete research problem, decide on a research question and research strategy for the thesis.  Furthermore, the research clinic introduces the students to the specific possibilities of either qualitative research or specific quantitative methods for research in finance, depending on the students’ choice of research profile. The research clinic supports the first steps of the thesis trajectory where the students develop their research proposals. During the thesis trajectory the students work with their thesis coach and co-reader.
[1] for more information see the RSM Master thesis manual this can be found at: https://master-services.rsm.nl/support/solutions/articles/80000883381-thesis-submission-process
In case a student misses more than 1 session, an assignment will be set by the lecturer to ensure reflection on and engagement with the relevant materials.

• Acquire deep knowledge on a specific domain in business administration
• Design and execute a complete research project autonomously
• Define a relevant research question in the current business context
• Formulate a research plan
• Review relevant literature
• Collect, process, and interpret data in an ethically responsible way
• Evaluate the findings and relate them to business
• Reflect on the potential implications for implementation

</style>

column1: The Master thesis including the thesis proposal constitutes the heart of the master programme MScBA - Master in Management. The Master thesis requires students to conduct independent, individual research in one of the functional domains (‘profiles’) in business administration and relate and link their insights with managerial insights and relevance. The thesis is perceived as a proof of their academic level of thinking, especially a proof of analytical craftsmanship combined with problem-solving and critical reflection. During the thesis trajectory MiM students study a field in business administration in more depth. The thesis provides students with an opportunity to deepen their understanding of an area of interest, train their capabilities in analysis and problem solving, improve their skills in practical scientific business and management research, and develop a personal profile.

By choosing a research topic in a profile students express their special interest and affinity towards a future employer. The thesis trajectory is considered as the main opportunity to bring in a focus in the program and express one’s affinity towards managerial challenges in a field in business administration. The topics as offered for a thesis cover the main domains in business administration, e.g. marketing, strategy, finance, supply chain etc. MiM students are always required to consider and discuss elaborately the relevance and implications for management.  The title of the thesis will be mentioned on the grade list. Therefore, it is recommended to choose a title wisely to indicate one’s interests.  The thesis is written under the supervision of a coach and a co-reader.   Before working on the thesis a research proposal (or: thesis proposal) has to be crafted.

column1: This course forms an introduction to the fascinating domain of microbes, i.e. the organisms (or entities', such as viruses and prions) that cannot be observed with the naked eye, but have a profound influence on the existence of life on Earth. You will get acquainted with the vast and varied microbiological world and will learn that life can appear in many shapes and forms, and can sometimes tolerate the harshest conditions. Clearly, the saying 'everything is everywhere, but the environment selects' by Dutch botanist and microbiologist Baas Becking (1895-1963) is one of the crucial take-home messages of this course. Apart from the general concepts of microbiology, the course will also zoom in on the world of pathogens: the microorganism that can cause disease. General concepts of infectious diseases will be discussed, and pandemics (worldwide epidemics) from the past will be taken as examples of the devastating outcome that certain infections can have on a population. In addition to studying microorganisms, a major part of this course will be devoted to the human immune system, i.e. the molecular and cellular 'system' that is aimed at recognizing and eliminating harmful microbiological intruders in our body. The different constituents of the immune system will be studied, and their role in the battle between pathogens and host will be explained. Finally, we will discuss the therapeutic options that exist in case the immune system fails to eliminate a pathogen from the human body. The mechanisms of action of the various groups of antibacterial (antibiotics) and antiviral drugs will be studied, as well as the role of vaccination in reducing disease burden.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After taking this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Identify and describe the general characteristics of prions, viruses, bacteria, fungi and unicellular (eukaryotic) parasites;
• Understand the evolution of life and the role of photosynthetic bacteria in creating the Earth's atmosphere;
• Explain bacterial metabolism and recognize what is an autotroph or an heterotroph
• Describe viral replication mechanisms;
• Recognize human pathogens: prions, viruses, bacteria, fungi and protozoan parasites;
• Understand the innate immune system, the adaptive immune system and immune disorders;
• Recognize (emerging) infectious diseases and the interplay between pathogen and host;
• Identify and characterize sexually transmitted diseases (chlamydia, gonorrhea, syfilis, genital herpes and human papilloma viruses);
• Explain zoonoses and pandemics (Yersinia pestis (black death), influenza (Spanish flu) and AIDS);
• Understand diagnostics of infectious diseases;
• Explain antiviral and -bacterial drugs and vaccination, and the mechanism of antiviral and -bacterial resistance.

column1: Na een algemene inleiding in de micro-economie zal de aandacht uitgaan naar de keuzetheorie. Uitgangspunt is dat economische handelingen doelgericht zijn: de beperkte middelen die een subject voorhanden heeft worden zodanig gebruikt dat een bepaalde doelstelling bereikt wordt. Dit algemene uitgangspunt wordt op de handelingen van de consument en producent toegepast. Vervolgens komt het functioneren van markten aan de orde. Ook wordt een begin gemaakt met het analyseren van strategische interactie met behulp van de speltheorie.

column1: The analysis of microbial communities has been fueled by next generation sequencing techniques in the past decade. Microbiota - especially those of the gut - have now been linked to several diseases and traits and analytical approaches, such as metagenomics, metatranscriptomics, metaproteomics and metabolomics, are evolving rapidly. This course will teach how microbiota profiles are generated and how to analyze these profiles.
To give an introduction and hands-on experience in techniques to profile microbiota as well as approaches to analyze these multi-dimensional datasets.

• The student learns advanced econometric models for the analysis of duration data.

<title></title>

column1: This course will provide the basic tools and training in microeconomics. It begins with the study of consumer behaviour and how their choices form the basis of demand in an economy. Firm behaviour is studied next to understand the input-output decisions of firms and to see where supply comes from. The third part brings together both sides of the economy and different market structures are discussed. Finally, strategic interaction between economic agents is the topic of the last part. Throughout, applications are provided to help understand why economic theory can be used to study behaviour in the real world.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of the course students will be able to:

column2: • To understand how consumer choice forms the basis for individual demand, and how individual demand translates into market demand.
• To understand the role of information in decision making.
• To understand how firms decide what and how much (output) to produce, and how they decide which resources (inputs) to use for production.
• To understand the concept of a perfectly competitive market.
• To understand what it means for a firm to have extreme market power.
• To understand that in the real world a whole spectrum of market structures exists between the extremes of perfect competition and monopoly.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• The first part of the course deals with the theory of the consumer. Topics covered include consumer choice under certainty and uncertainty, and individual and market demand;
• The second part focuses on the theory of the firm, and includes the topics of firm production and firm cost;

• The last part of the course turns to market structures (monopoly, imperfect competition and perfect competition),and to the joint analysis of firm and consumer behavior within a market (general equilibrium theory).
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Reproduce and interpret concepts in key areas of microeconomics: individual choice and decision-making; effects of information and uncertainty; firm behaviour; organisations and markets; allocative efficiency and welfare under different markets and firm strategies; basic game and general equilibrium theory
• Reproduce and interpret concepts in key areas of meso-economics: market structure and performance; firm strategy; firm objectives and performance;
• Learn to use basic, standard mathematical methods commonly employed in microeconomics.

column1: Instructors: Dr. V. Karamychev (EUR) and Prof. dr. C.M. van Veelen (UvA)

The course is the fundamental microeconomics course which studies individual decision-making and its relations to market clearing price formation. It builds on classical consumer choice theory. Then, individual behaviors are further integrated into a closed and interrelated system in which the equilibrium values of all variables are simultaneously determined. This is in contrast to the partial equilibrium approach, where all variables, which are not directly related to the problem at hand, are taking to be given. The course develops a theory that attempts to predict the complete vector of individual final consumptions and individual productions from the fundamentals of the economy.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• To be able to identify and explain economic concepts from the theory of individual decision making;
• To know potential links between different elements of individual behavior that follow from the theory, and to be able to use them in an applied work;
• To know how to compute individually rational behavior of an economic agent in any economic environment, and to be able to do so in cases where it is tractable;
• To know the necessary conditions for market efficiency and the factors that lead to inefficiencies;
• To know potential pitfalls for using applied general equilibrium models in complex economic environments;
• To be able to apply the theory of individual decision making to general equilibrium theory.
<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course provides a framework for the analysis of situations of conflict. Emphasis is put on the modelling of situations of strategic interaction. Through the lens of the distinct notions of equilibria, the course offers ways to restrict the set of possible outcomes in games. The course discusses many well-known examples of strategic interaction.

Since the 1970s, questions about material supply and demand have become less central in economics, and questions about human interactions and information have become more central. Game theory provides the basic tools for investigating the societal inefficiencies due to selfish strategic behavior of individuals, and ways to minimize those inefficiencies. In its first years, game theory was purely theoretical, so as to develop its basic concepts. It was later extended to experimental economics, and nowadays its tools are used in virtually every economics discipline.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• can use general techniques to determine outcomes, usually equilibria, in many strategic situations,
• can see through conflicts, incredible threats, possibilities for cooperation, bargaining, voting, proper incentives, moral hazard, and adverse selection.
• learn the subtle counterfactual reasoning typical of strategic interactions between two or more rational beings.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113398,2023,Microeconomics III (Information and Contract Theory),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. BSY Crutzen'],,Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Economics is about the creation of value through markets, organizations and other institutions. Asymmetric information and bounded rationality may get in the way of value creation. This course presents a number of insights from contract theory for dealing with these twin problems. It starts with moral hazard and adverse selection in elementary settings, then it turns to multidimensional incentive problems, contracts for teams, relational contracts, incomplete contracts, decision rights and authority, and asset ownership. It also includes a discussion of cheap talk and communication. These topics are approached by applying contract theory to problems in labour economics, organizational economics, and corporate finance.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: By the end of the course, students will be

column2: • Familiar with basic models and techniques used within contract theory.
• Able to solve for the optimal contract in some standard contractual settings studied in the literature using game-theoretic techniques.
• Aware of the implications and limitations of contract theory for making sound empirical predictions.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113399,2023,Microeconomics IV (Behavioral Economics),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. PP Wakker'],,Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Instructors: Prof. Dr. P.P. Wakker (EUR) and Prof. Dr. T.J.S. Offerman (UvA)

This course consists of two parts. One part deals with the behavioral revolution in economics, where differences between homo sapiens and homo economicus require a remodeling of risk behavior, intertemporal behavior, social behavior, individual utility, and, thus, of virtually all economic models. The other part considers the path-breaking insights of behavioral economics into interactive decision making. Special attention will be paid to how behavioral economics changed our thinking about learning, equilibrium, social preferences, strategic communication, and markets. The course gives a broad perspective, showing how behavioral ideas impact virtually every field in economics.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Learning goals for this course: students should have an understanding of, ability to apply, judge, and communicate

1. Get a broad understanding of behavioral and experimental economics, i.e,, how to incorporate empirical realism (reckoning with irrationalities and borrowing from psychology) in theoretically proper manners.
2. Empirical measurements, quantitative predictions and economic applications of psychological insights into the area of their own research interest.
3. Independent processing of relevant behavioral economics literature.</body>

column1: Microscopic images contain much more information than normally is retrieved. Especially time-lapse image data contains a wealth of information. Extracting this information by visual inspection and manual measurement is not only cumbersome but also subjective. Automation of image analysis tasks by using a computer and the right software tools allows for higher efficiency, accuracy, objectivity, reproducibility, and completeness.

Participants should bring their own laptop to the course for the practical exercises. Software and sample image data will be provided during the course (USB stick). No prior knowledge of image processing is required.

column2: • Obtain a deeper theoretical understanding of image analysis methods
• Obtain practical experience with image analysis software tools (in particular ImageJ) and learn how to use them intelligently, on their own computer.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115905,2023,Middeleeuwen en Renaissance,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. JA van Ruler', 'prof.dr. L van Bunge']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten.

De middeleeuwen beginnen wanneer West-Europa in economisch en cultureel opzicht tot een primitief stadium terugvalt. Eerst rond 800 trad in de kloosterscholen een voorzichtig herstel van de wetenschappen en de wijsbegeerte op. Daar doceerde men een neoplatonisme, dat men onder meer via Augustinus kende. In de twaalfde eeuw ontstaan de eerste universiteiten, waar de wijsbegeerte van Aristoteles de grondslag van het onderwijs vormt. Dit was mogelijk doordat de hele Aristoteles onder meer door vertalingen vanuit het Arabisch wordt herontdekt. Vanaf dat moment oefent zij bijna een half millennium een ‘despotisch’ gezag uit over de geesten. In de cursus zal worden stilgestaan bij de vernieuwingen met name in de metafysica en de kentheorie, die ondanks de conserverende werking van het ‘schoolse’ onderwijs aan de universiteiten plaatsvonden.

De Renaissance wordt - de naam zegt het al - gekenmerkt door de wedergeboorte van de klassieke cultuur. Deze werd mogelijk door het humanisme: het ontstaan van het hermeneutisch probleem. In de filosofie betekende dat de aandacht voor andere vormen van klassiek denken dan Aristoteles. Uit de herleving van het platonisme en het scepticisme komt ook iets nieuws voort: de moderne natuurwetenschap, die in Francis Bacon haar eerste programmatische pleitbezorger vindt. Bijzondere aandacht gaat uit naar de zogenaamde ‘pyrrhonistische crisis’ die in de tweede helft van de zestiende eeuw haar eerste woordvoerder vindt in Montaigne.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Overzicht van de verdere ontwikkeling van de filosofie vanaf de oudheid. Na deze cursus is de student in staat het verband te leggen tussen religieuze en wetenschappelijke ontwikkelingen aan de ene en de wijsgerige ontwikkelingen aan de andere kant. Verder heeft de student een praktische vaardigheid opgedaan in het interpreteren van een filosofische tekst uit de middeleeuwen en zich vertrouwd gemaakt met de historische wijsgerige terminologie.</body>

column1: Over the course of the past decade, the region known as the Middle East has been undergoing a revolutionary moment, causing monumental political shifts and disruption, and captivating observers across the world. Yet, for all the attention, it remains subject to widespread misconceptions and is often viewed as if suffering from unique, intractable problems.

In order to grasp political change of this nature, this course introduces you to the comparative politics of the Middle East. We will ask questions such as; which structures and practices define politics? How do state and society relate to one another? Why does authoritarianism seemingly hold sway in the region? What have the uprisings changed in the region’s politics? What is the role of identity and ideology? It will also invite you to look critically at the modes and production of knowledge, combining empirical and critical traditions in Political Science.

The state, a key object of inquiry in Political Science, represents a major theme in the course. Beginning with its historical formation at the end of World War I, we will continue to examine the ideological and coercive apparatuses that underpin postcolonial states as well as the forces that challenge their legitimacy. At the heart of the region’s politics is an ongoing struggle between citizens demanding more democratic institutions and the so-called counter-revolution of regimes defending the status quo. Yet contentious politics manifests itself not only as uprisings against state repression but also in myriad other forms of resistance and the politics of the everyday.

Although grounded in Comparative Politics, this course adopts an interdisciplinary perspective, incorporating Area Studies, Postcolonial Theory, International Relations, Political Economy, and History.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • identify and comprehend major themes in Middle East Politics
• demonstrate insight in historical dynamics and current developments
• locate and explain sources of tension and conflict in the region

column1: Nederland en de meeste andere landen in Europa en Noord-Amerika zijn door doorgaande processen van internationale migratie in toenemende mate etnisch en cultureel diverse samenlevingen geworden. In de literatuur wordt zelfs gesproken van “superdiversiteit” waarmee niet alleen bedoeld wordt dat een steeds groter wordend deel van de bevolking van de westerse landen een migratieachtergrond heeft, maar ook dat daarbij steeds meer verschillende landen betrokken zijn. De minor Migratie en Diversiteit biedt verdiepend inzicht in al zulke vraagstukken van migratie en diversiteit en het op deze gebieden gevoerde overheidsbeleid, zowel in de Nederlandse samenleving als internationaal. De minor maakt vanuit sociologisch en bestuurskundig perspectief een analyse van de aard en omvang van internationale migratie, dominante verklaringen voor migratie, en de betekenis van migratie en diversiteit voor de ontvangende samenlevingen in het algemeen. Daarnaast is er in deze minor veel aandacht voor beleidsvraagstukken op al deze gebieden en voor het ter zake gevoerde beleid (migratiebeleid, integratiebeleid, stedelijk beleid, enz.). De minor vertrekt vanuit sociologisch en bestuurskundig perspectief, maar stelt studenten vanuit andere opleidingen ook in staat om een verbinding te maken tussen de eigen bachelor en de thema’s migratie en diversiteit.
Centrale thema’s in de minor zijn:

column2: • Historische en geografische schets van de voornaamste migratiepatronen wereldwijd, in West-Europa en in Nederland.
• Verklaringen van internationale migratie en integratie vanuit diverse sociaalwetenschappelijke disciplines.
• Het ‘management’ van gewenste en ongewenste migratiestromen: visabeleid, grenscontroles, detentie, uitzetting, ‘zelfstandige terugkeer’.
• Theoretische modellen van integratie en integratiebeleid (multiculturalisme, differentialisme, assimilationisme, universalisme en interculturalisme)
• Vraagstukken van vooroordelen en discriminatie, inclusief het gevoerde beleid om dit tegen te gaan
• De betekenis van migratie voor de samenleving; hoe hebben deze migrantengroepen de Nederlandse samenleving veranderd?
• De gevolgen van diversiteit of “superdiversiteit” voor steden en het beleid dat steden daarop voeren
• Beleid t.a.v. migranten en diversiteit op verschillende bestuursniveaus: lokaal, nationaal, Europees, internationaal.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Internationale migratie gaat van oudsher samen met regulering, uitsluiting en restricties. Het zijn processen die zich vooral, maar niet uitsluitend in urbane gebieden manifesteren. Ook wordt migratie al heel lang met criminaliteit in verband gebracht. Door diverse vormen van migratie en de positie en integratie van migranten in m.n. Nederland en Europa centraal te stellen, willen wij in dit vak criminologische en juridische kennis toepassen op een actueel maatschappelijk onderwerp. Thema’s die hierbij aan de orde komen zijn het criminologische taboe op etniciteit; (ir)reguliere migratie en het toezicht op en de beheersing van migratiebewegingen; migratie gerelateerde criminaliteit als mensensmokkel en mensenhandel; de constructie van het ‘integratieprobleem’; racisme, radicalisering en extremisme; beschrijvingen en verklaringen van ‘allochtone’ criminaliteit; de constructie van het ‘illegalenprobleem’, bestaansstrategieën van onrechtmatig verblijvende vreemdelingen, vreemdelingenbewaring, uitzetting en terugkeer. Je verwerft tijdens het vak niet alleen inhoudelijke kennis op deze terreinen, maar maakt ook kennis met de bedoelde en onbedoelde effecten van het Nederlandse en Europese beleid op deze terreinen waardoor je na afloop kunt reflecteren op deze actuele migratie gerelateerde vraagstukken.

• de gelaagdheid en complexiteit van migratieprocessen duiden in relatie tot mogelijke onbedoelde effecten van restrictiever beleid op deze migratieprocessen.

column1: In this course we explore food as culture, place of contention, cultural transmission, and power relations. We investigate foodways and how foods (products, ingredients, and dishes), food practices and technologies, food-related knowledge but also eating habits and consumption behaviours travelled or were borrowed, reinvented, or appropriated across cultural boundaries. To achieve this, we will trace the movements of people and their culinary knowledge as part of globalization. In the context of twentieth century globalization, dubbed the ‘Age of Mobility,’ contact, exchange, and dissemination of cultures through migration have resulted in diverse and geographically distributed human identities. These phenomena have affected virtually all social groups, home and away from home, albeit in diverse ways. Eating, preparing, preserving, talking, remembering, writing about food evokes identities and meanings. Among those to be discussed are ethnicity, race, class, gender, and religion, as well as the concepts of national belonging, authenticity, materiality, collectivity, and other less-conventional identities. This course aims to sensitize students to the ways in which various actors continuously negotiate the impact of globalization processes on their identities and integrate migration and food as aspects of culture that figure more prominently in world history today. In addition, students are invited to develop and apply creative and critical skills to their research, including the incorporation of non-written sources and more inclusive historiography.

column2: <title></title>

column1: Upon completing the course, students will be able to:

column2: • Select and employ different theorizations of identity, identification, diaspora, diasporic culture and other relevant concepts to support their academic discussion.
• Critically analyse the complexities of food as culture and explain the main questions and contemplations in food history.
• Identify actors and processes of migration and relate them to identity building processes and foodways.
• Combine different methods of argumentation and create a convincing argument through visual narration and photographic analysis.
• Produce academic presentations and papers of relevant topics in an analytical, creative, and inclusive manner.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Globalization, understood as the massive increase in flows of goods, services, ideas and people across borders and the widening and deepening of global interconnectedness and interdependence between places, is without a doubt among the most profound societal transformations of the last centuries. By definition, globalization is a transnational, boundary-crossing process that depends on the mobility of not only capital, but also labor. Technological and technical advances have created communication and transportation networks that allow for unprecedented levels of human mobility for transnational elites. Yet, paradoxically, the situation of refugees and ‘undesirable’ migrants is characterized by immobility despite these advances. We will therefore investigate how (im-)mobility is produced, experienced and governed in a globalized world.

In this course, we explore the intricate and complex relationship between globalization and migration in further detail. We draw on insights from the sociological literature on globalization to grasp how global migration brings about changes in various spheres of social life. First, we review sociological theories on the meaning of ‘globalization’ as a process of societal transformation. Next, we investigate the effects globalization has had on the scale, composition and dynamics of migration patterns and, vice versa, how migration has facilitated global change. In the remaining sessions, we further dissect and examine the relationship between globalization and migration by zooming in on its economic, cultural, political and social dimensions.

Throughout, we learn to consider how globalization at times operates as a force of universalization and homogenization and, at other times, as a force of polarization and heterogenization. Globalization can lead to the formation of integrated labour markets, cosmopolitan cultures and transnational social ties, but it can also give rise to global inequality, localism and right-wing populism. Both the ‘winners’ and ‘losers’ of globalization are considered in this course, ranging from hyper-mobile transnational elites to immobilized undocumented workers. Rather than solely conceiving of globalization in trans- and supranational terms, we will also explicitly investigate how globalization manifests itself at the local level.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Learning goals
After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Discuss theories and empirical research on globalization and migration
• Analyse the impact of globalization on global migration patterns and vice versa
• Summarize and present theories and the results of scientific studies on the economic, cultural, political and social aspects of globalization
• Apply theoretical insights from the globalization literature to a case study on or ongoing debate around migration
• Research and write a paper about a subdimension of globalization and its impact on migration

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114686,2023,Migration, Citizenship and Identity in a Globalizing World",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. I Gusc', 'L Zurné, MA', 'prof.dr. G Oonk']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Which passport is the most accepted passport around the world and why is this (un)fair? How many generations does it take for a settler and his family to become 'native'? What is the potential of global citizenship in relation to patriotic realities? These are just some of the pressing questions which are fully explored in this course on Global Migration, Citizenship and Identity. Migration and ethnic minorities have always challenged the ‘nation’ in the Nation State. In this series of lectures we will discuss the development of cosmopolitan citizenship and its discontents. We will take examples from Europe, the US as well South Africa, Japan, Brazil and India. We discuss issues as slavery and citizenship, birth right lottery, paper citizens, multiple passports and loyalties. Global migration has forced us to re-think the construction of the nation state. States increasingly compete with each other for international prestige and economic development. They wish to attract skilled laborers (including sportsmen and women and scientist) and investors or rich consumers. In addition, however, especially western welfare states wish to restrict migration from poor countries to protect the welfare levels of its citizens. Cosmopolitism may be seen as an asset, a challenge and a burden.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: Students study three different perspectives on migration and citizenship; (1) Egalitarian liberalism, (2) Communitarian and (3) libertarian perspectives. With these three perspectives in mind they learn how to debate national self-determination, migration and multiculturalism and global distributive justice and migration. By the end of the course they are able to write a critical review of an academic monograph on migration, citizenship and identity.

column1: This minor introduces students to the study of sports from the perspective of three distinct social sciences: philosophy, economics, and history/media studies. Each social science perspective has its own module. The first 7 weeks of the academic year are each devoted to one sports-related theme with a large societal impact. Each module covers this theme from the perspective of its own social science. The list of themes is (subject to change):
1. Importance of sports in society and social science

During the lectures the teacher will discuss societal questions related to these themes. You could think of questions like: what are the ethical views on the gender pay gap in sports? Or, how have historical events shaped the role of sports in our society? And what are the economic benefits of organizing large sport events?
In week 8 the students pass separate exams for each of the modules.

During the final two weeks the students work in groups to write an academic paper related to one of the themes. The students can choose the theme according to their own preferences. They formulate a research question related to this theme. In their paper they then investigate this question from the perspective of each of the three social sciences in the minor. This groupwork paper is optional for ESE students.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After taking this minor, students should be able to
1. Understand the importance of sports in today’s society.
2. Explain the main theories of sports developed by historians, media scientists, philosophers, and economists.
3. Place the main current societal trends and problems in sports in a broader historical, philosophical, and economic perspective.
4. Reflect critically on current issues in sports governance, media relations, ethics, and economics using insights form history/media studies, philosophy, and economics.
5. Write an academic research paper on sports which integrates perspectives from different social sciences.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: 'Modernity’, the French poet and angry young man Baudelaire once wrote, ‘is the transient, the fleeting, the contingent (….)’, a formulation that has become as famous for its heuristic power as it has become infamous for its interpretative flexibility. In this course we will discuss this elegant, yet slippery statement on the “essence” of modernity by looking into at least two of its many levels of interpretation, i.e. Modernity’s social structures and its structures of experience.

Modernity, conceived as a historical period, is often sharply distinguished from so-called traditional societies by way of the manifold structural changes that occurred in the nineteenth and eighteenth century (and some would even point to the seventeenth century).

We will discuss this radical break or gradual transformation by means of several key witnesses that have been living through (and sometimes even actively shaped) the developments that have come to define modernity. We will pay particular attention to the Enlightenment and the industrialisation process. By reading texts from Enlightenment thinkers such as Immanuel Kant and Georg W. F. Hegel and critical thinkers such as Karl Marx, Hannah Arendt and Michel Foucault you will gain an understanding of the social situation in which they wrote and the historical moment they tried to grasp in words.

While reading and discussing texts from disciplines such as History, Philosophy and the Philosophy of History, we will focus on four interrelated questions that all circle around the notion of ‘Timely Reflections.’ What is the historical context of some of the most canonical thinkers on modernity? What can these thinkers teach us about their historical context? Why did all of these thinkers reflect on History (with a capital ‘H’) and the relation between the past, present and future? And why are their texts still relevant today?

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course students are able to

column2: • Describe and explain in which ways Modernity is rooted in the Enlightenment;
• Describe and explain the emergence of typically modern institutions, such as the state, civil society, the family, and the market;
• Describe and explain the industrial revolution and the industrialization of society;
• Describe and explain the ways in which industrialization is related to wider developments such as the emergence of capitalism and urbanization;
• Describe and explain the ways in which modern institutions produce docile bodies by means of disciplinary techniques.
• Describe and explain the ways in which modern institutions are mobilized and have dissolved with the emergence of totalitarian movements and regimes.
• Describe and explain in which ways Enlightenment Reason has been incorporated and criticized in the dominant tradition of modern (continental) philosophy;
• Describe and explain the ways in which canonical thinkers – i.e. Kant, Hegel, Marx, Foucault and Arendt – have reflected on their own times and the concept of History.
• have an understanding of the continuities and discontinuities in the rise of the natural sciences in the 16th to 18th Century;
• have an understanding of the rise of the social sciences and humanities in the 19th Century;
• have knowledge about the ways in which scientists and others (i.e. non-scientists) engage in engage in discussions on ‘objective knowledge’;
• have a understanding of the consequences of the democratization of science
• have a clear understanding of the relations between science, policy and practice.
• can explain how science and technology are as much the products of the societies in which they are embedded as that the give shape to those societies

column1: This module is part of Blok 9, together with GW309AVV and GW309I.
This module is exclusively for students Gezondheidswetenschappen.

Many decisions that you will make as a health care manager or policy maker have an ethical component. Think for instance about decisions concerning national vaccination policies, organizational policies that encourage healthy behavior from staff and government and organizational policies emphasizing the autonomy of patients. Different values are at stake in policies such as these which can conflict with each other. This makes it crucially important for you, as a future healthcare manager or policy maker, to be able to recognize the values at stake and to weigh such values in your decision-making. In the course choices and dilemmas we will provide you with the necessary knowledge and skills to do so.

In this course we use insights from the different disciplines of ESHPM, building on the knowledge you gained in previous courses. In addition we use insights from ethical theory to deepen your knowledge about ethical choices and dilemmas. We also provide you with different tools, such as moral deliberation, for ethical reflection.

In the first part of the course we introduce different ethical values (autonomy, nonmaleficence, beneficence and justice) and different ethical theories. In the working groups we practice with several methods of ethical reflection. In the second part of the course we go into more detail on specific ethical dilemmas stakeholders experience in practice. In the working groups we reflect on ethical questions you identify in your internship organizations. In the third and final part of the course you write an individual essay on an ethical question or dilemma of your choosing.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After completion of this module, you can:

column2: • Analyze the origin of choices and dilemmas in healthcare using ethical theory.
• Analyze cases concerning choices and dilemmas in healthcare from different points of view (including different stakeholders, disciplines, and ethical theories).
• Reflect on your own role as a healthcare manager or policy maker with regards to choices and dilemmas in healthcare.
• Use reflective tools such as moral deliberation when analyzing cases concerning choices and dilemmas in healthcare.

column1: This course will introduce you to the fundamental principles of 'life', with a focus on molecular and cellular biology. Cell biology studies the structure, function, and behaviour of cells, whereas molecular biology describes the molecular basis of biological activity between various biomolecules (like DNA, RNA and proteins). The course begins with an overview of the main features of bacterial, plant and mammalian cells and goes on to introduce the key molecular players in the cells, i.e. proteins. Techniques that enable characterisation, isolation, and manipulation of cells and biomolecules are central in molecular and cellular biology, and these techniques therefore also play a principal role in this course. Specifically, we will take a close look at microscopy, cell culture, DNA cloning and the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) technology. We will then move on to study the regulation of gene expression and the eukaryotic cell cycle. We will see how cells are organised in tissues and how intra- and intercellular signalling pathways are involved in controlling cell division, differentiation, and maintenance of the stem cell state. The final part of the course will focus on how DNA can be damaged and repaired, and which molecular events are involved in the generation of cancer.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: After taking this course the student will be able to:
• Understand the principles of biological systematics, taxonomy and the classification of ‘life’;
• Identify and describe the structure of bacterial, animal and plant cells (similarities and differences);
• Recognize the vital compartments and organelles of eukaryotic cells and describe their particular function;
• Explain intracellular sorting and transport of molecules (in animal cells) and how this is related to the cytoskeleton and cell movement;
• Recognize excitable animal cells, understanding membrane and action potentials and the cellular interactions within neural pathways;
• Describe the cell cycle: DNA replication, cell growth and division (mitosis and meiosis);
• Explain molecular genetics and epigenetics: the organisation of genomes (emphasis on the human genome); genes and chromosomes; dominant and recessive alleles; inheritance;
• Characterize signal transduction pathways: from an extracellular ligand to transcription activation;
• Understand the regulation of gene expression: the function of promoters, enhancers, transcription factors and small RNAs;
• Describe the various steps involved molecular carcinogenesis;
• Explain the concepts of DNA modification and cloning, including transgenesis;
• Understand the principles of DNA and (whole-) genome sequencing.

column1: In this practical course, you will become acquainted with microscopy as well as a variety of microbiological and molecular biological techniques. The preparation, planning and execution of the experiments, and the use of specific laboratory materials and equipment, will provide a solid introduction to many aspects of lab work. As a part of the microbiological experiments, you will focus on basic techniques such as the production of culture medium, plating, staining and quantification of bacteria. The molecular biological techniques that you will perform include the isolation of plasmid DNA and determination of the purity of the DNA by spectrophotometry. The length of the isolated plasmid DNA will be determined by both restriction enzyme digestion analysis and PCR. This course provides both practical training, theoretical understanding of the selected methods and the organisational skills required in the biological lab.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: At the end of the course the students will:
• Be able to accurately work with a variable micropipette
• Work according to the general safety rules and the current safe microbial techniques (SMT; in Dutch 'veilige microbiologische technieken' or VMT) rules
• Be able to prepare culture media
• Estimate the quantity of micro-organisms (colony-forming unit)
• Be able to make a DNA UV spectrum and interpret it
• Be able to isolate plasmid DNA from a bacterial culture
• Be able to execute electrophoresis using agarose
• Be able to determine the size of an unknown DNA fragment by means of the electrophoresis data
• Be able to execute a simple PCR experiment and interpret the results
• Be able to operate the light microscope quickly and correctly
• Be able to make various microscopic preparations
• Be able to keep the labjournal in an organised fashion and write lab reports
• Be able to do the calculations involved in these experiments

column1: <body>This course provides an in-depth coverage of the fascinating field of molecular genetics. We will question how many genes it takes to make a human, how these genes are being regulated at the molecular level, and how genome variation contributes to our individuality. Also, we will discuss the clinical manifestation of the patterns of single-gene inheritance and the complex inheritance of common multifactorial disorders. Using this knowledge, we will see how genetics is being used in a clinical setting for risk assessment, genetic screening and counselling. Furthermore, we will study how (defective) genes can be modified both in humans, animals, and plants through gene editing technologies, with the aim of providing gene therapy, or developing transgenic animals and plants. At the end of this course, you will understand that having an exact count of the necessary number of genes will not be nearly as important as understanding the functions of each gene and how they interact to build the living organism.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course you will be able to:

column2: • Understanding the functional differences between genes, pesudogenes and non-coding RNA's
• Ecplain how genes are organized on chromosomes and how they are expressed, i.e. transcribed and translated

• Describe the molecular techniques, such as comparative genomic hybridization (CHG), fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH), quantitative PCR (qPCR), gene expression profiling (array technology), DNA/RNA sequencing using next generation sequencing technology (NGS), which enabl chromosome and genome analysis that are commonly being used for gene mapping and identification, clinical and prenatal diagnosis and cancer cytogenetics
• Understand the relationship between the genome and proteome, and how proteogenomics can provide valuable additional information on the composition of the genome

• Understand the typical Mendelia pattern of inheritance, or the pattern of transmission of single-gene disorders. You will be able to describe the molecular and genetic mechanisms by which mutations in genes result in recessice, dominant, X-linked and mitochondrial inheritance patterns
• Understand the genetics of common diseases with compex, non-Mendelian, inheritancem and how this relates to disease-predisposing alleles
• Explain the difference between genetic and epigenetic inheritance and the difference between and the molecular mechanisms of X-inactivation and the histone code
• Understand how determination of the recurrence risk is an important aspect of genetic counseling
• Explain the difference and underlying mechanisms of genome, chromosome and gene mutations, and be able to interpret the mutation nomenclature
• Understand how genetic polymorphisms - or single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) determine genetic diversity
• Understand the Hardy-Weinberg law in population genetics and how it's used in genetic counseling
• Understand the principles of linkage and genome-wide association studies (GWAS)
• Explain how susceptibility traits can have high or low risk allele frequency and what the impact of risk allele frequency is on clinical phenotype
• Understand what gene knock-out is and how molecual techniques, such as the Cre-lox and Crispr/Cas systems, enable gene modification in transgenic animals and plants
• Explain how and what type of viruses are being used for enabling gene therapy, and which diseases can be targeted
• Recognize and understand the ethical issues that are connected to prenatal and diagnostic screening, genetically modified organisms (GMO's), and gene therapy

column1: Monetary economics is a very broad topic area that deals with the effects of money, monetary institutions, and monetary policy on macroeconomic variables such as output, inflation, interest rates, and exchange rates. In this course we focus on monetary policy in the euro area. We discuss the costs and benefits of monetary union, how monetary policy is implemented by the ECB and how the incompleteness of the monetary union may lead to financial instability.

column2: • What is money and what does it do?
• Monetary policy strategy and implementation.
• The various transmission channels of monetary policy.
• Monetary policy rules and reaction functions.
• Understanding inflation.
• Lessons from the eurocrisis.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Understand key theoretical principles behind the modern monetary policy.
• Learn practical issues of monetary policy implementation by various central banks.
• Learn the transmission channels of monetary policy monetary policy to macroeconomic outcomes such as output, inflation, and unemployment.
• Read academic and policy papers related to monetary economics
• Work with the economic data and use econometric techniques in order to empirically test the key relationships between monetary and macroeconomic variables.

column1: The goal of this minor is to provide students with the key concepts that are critical to understanding how the financial system, the banking system, the money supply process and monetary policy work. Some of the questions addressed in this course are:

column2: <li>
What is money and how is it created in the financial system?
<li>
How do capital and money markets work?
<li>
How are interest rates on different bonds determined?
<li>
What is the role of commercial banks and central banks?
<li>
Why and how are banks regulated?
<li>
Why can financial crises have such devastating consequences for the real economy?
<li>
How do central banks implement conventional and unconventional monetary policy?
<li>
How does monetary policy transmit to the real economy?

column1: All these questions will be discussed in the context of current developments in financial markets and economic policies. A special emphasis will be put on recent academic and policy debates. For example,

column2: <li>
Why has inflation been increasing, and what can central banks do about it?
<li>
Should central banks target climate change-related goals?
<li>
Can cryptocurrencies take over the role of traditional fiat money?
<li>
How do unconventional measures such as quantitative easing work?
<li>
What are the pros and cons of very low interest rates for the banking system and the economy as a whole?

column1: Compare the financial system of different countries

Investigate the build-up, the evolution and amplification mechanisms of financial crises throughout history using different models of financial crises

Calculate relevant concepts around interest rates including present value, yield to maturity, expected return, the risk- and term-structure of interest rates, as well as the difference between nominal and real interest rates
Analyze how aggregate demand and aggregate supply affect aggregate output and inflation, and how they interact with monetary policy

column4: In this course students will study the tension between fine art and money, and the problems of commercializing artistic processes. The course will be divided into three parts: in the first part, we will discuss different exchange models for art goods illustrated by historical and contemporary case studies and, in the second part, the focus will be on the specifics of contemporary art market (prices, values, indices, rules and conventions, and actors). The third part focuses on globalization of the art market (for example: emerging art markets).

column2: </tbody>

column1: The aim of this course is twofold: to gain insight into the economic dimensions of the art world; and to alert students with a variety of interests (like business or society) to the intricate and often problematic interaction between the art world on one hand and the world of money and finance on the other.

Having completed the minor, students will have gained a cultural-economic perspective. They should have a wide-ranging knowledge and critical understanding of the cultural economic perspective and of the structures and dynamics of art markets.

column1: The 2007/8 global financial crisis and 2011 Euro crisis demonstrate the importance of well functioning financial markets and organizations. In addition, banks play a crucial role in the allocation of capital and credit in the economy. This course teaches you to recognize the common mechanisms behind current and past crises.

First, you will conceptually understand why we have a financial system in the first place, what financial institutions do, and how you can understand and recognize even the most obscure and complex institutions. We spend some extra time on the social role of finance, especially in relation to climate change.

Then we will turn to banks, see why they are special, and better understand the business they are in. As it turns out, their main contributions to society are also the source of the vulnerability, and we study which  bank risks are important and how they are measured. Then we will turn to financial markets, and show how banks, money, and credit are connected and created. These processes help shape a financial system that can INHERENTLY lead to crisis periods. We will then use these concepts to better understand how the 21-st century financial system actually works, and apply this to a case study by a investment professional from a lange financial asset manager
Main topics of this course are:

column2: • Financial systems and the link between money and credit:
• Banks
• Financial markets
• The creation and sudden evaporation of elasticity in the financial system:
• Regulations that manage discipline and elasticity in financial institutions and markets
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• At the end of this course, students should understand the mechanisms through which money and credit markets work, and roles and functions of banks.
• Students know these characteristics, have contributed to recent crises, and may contribute to future crises.
• Students will understand liquidity inside financial institutions and in financial markets
• Students will understand the policies of central banks directed at managing such liquidity, or otherwise

column1: What is right and wrong, virtue or vice? What ought we to do? What is the (Highest) Good? The course considers normative ethics and discusses four major moral theories that attempt to formulate basic principles of morality: virtue ethics, deontology, utilitarianism and contractualism. We will also turn to meta-ethics and moral psychology to discuss more foundational issues: What are the background assumptions of the theories? Where do they show their limits? And what about their applicability to concrete moral problems in different fields of moral agency? We will discuss so called “moral dilemma cases”. In such cases, agents seem to be condemned to moral failure, they have a choice between plague and cholera. In which way and to what extent can each of the four theories help to evaluate and / or (re-)solve such dilemmatic situations?
The course is accompanied by a training of philosophical debating skills.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: As a student of the introductory course into Moral Philosophy you will learn how to argue in a critical philosophical debate about major theories of moral philosophy and their application to so called “moral dilemma cases”.
To reach this aim we will proceed in the following steps:
1. You will understand the four major moral theories: virtue ethics, deontology, utilitarianism and contractualism.
2. You will learn to compare the four theories as well as different theories of “moral dilemmas” by reference to a meta-ethical perspective.
3. You will reflect about the criteria of a sound philosophical debate.
4. You will critically evaluate the scope and limits of the four theories by means of applying them to “moral dilemma cases”.
You are expected to read the mandatory literature thoroughly and to participate actively in fair and objective discussions.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111166,2023,Motivatie, zelfregulatie & prestaties",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. M Twemlow'],,"Inhoud

Why do some people perform better than others on work or study related tasks? Why does one person manage to faithfully adhere to an exercise regimen or a healthy diet while others succumb to the temptation of fast-food? Why is it sometimes difficult to put forth the effort to take on a task? Why do you sometimes postpone tasks even though you know you will regret this later? Why are some good intentions doomed to fail from the start? What is the purpose of planning ahead and setting goals? How can people be properly motivated to reach their potential and reach their objectives? These are just some of the central questions within the domain of motivation, self-regulation, and performance that will be addressed in this course. In addition to a short overview of the major theoretical frameworks, you will read empirical research on these topics. Emphasis is put on critical reading of the literature. The theoretical frameworks or topics that will be addressed are emotion regulation, control theory, social cognitive theory, achievement goal theory, self-determination theory, regulatory focus, procrastination, and the possible limitation of willpower.
At the end of the course:

column2: • Students are able to differentiate between and compare the different theoretical frameworks on motivation and self-regulation (e.g., achievement goal theory, self-determination theory, regulatory focus, ego-depletion).
• Students are able to apply these theories on situations in daily life.
• Students can give examples of self-regulatory mechanisms and are able to describe these mechanisms.
• Students can describe the relationship between motivation, self-regulation, and behavioral outcomes (e.g., performance, learning outcomes, health).
• Students can give examples and explain situations of self-regulatory failure (e.g., procrastination).

column1: Organizations are not only part of markets, but also an alternative them. They tend to have characteristics that set them apart from markets, such as employees supplying a subset of their liberties to management, specific human capital, and various possibilities to do more (make better decisions) than any single individual. These features raise issues regarding the determinants of value-creating organizations, such as ‘Who decides?’ (the allocation of authority, formal versus real authority, access, ratification and monitoring in decision control, and initiation and implementation in decision management, task design, conflict resolution, enforcement mechanisms, talent allocation across hierarchical positions, …) and the structure of ‘Benefits and Costs’ (payment schemes; hiring policies; …). The handling of an issue depends to a large extent on whether it is characterized as a conflicting interests / motivation question, a joint interests / alignment challenge, or a cognitive limitation problem. The insights are aimed at helping managers to take effective and efficient decisions.

• Apply, i.e. improve your integrative HR and organizational thinking by developing a framework for thinking about organizational design as a whole
• Redesign, i.e. enable you to develop better enterprise strategies and policies

column1: In this elective, we will look at the role social movements in and around organizations play in the process of societal change. We will examine the different structural and cultural building blocks available to social movements and activists to make their voice heard and achieve their aims. We will explore the relationship between social movements and corporations and compare the different manners in which they may interact, with antagonistic and confrontational dynamics on the one extreme and responsive and collaborative interactions on the other.

The elective builds on the wider GBS programme by zooming in on social movements and collective action behaviour as potential motors for societal change. On the one hand, the elective explores the side of the social movements: what resources do they have available to express their discontent and push for change? How can they convince others to participate and when is the right moment to act? On the other hand, the elective sheds light on the interactions between organisations and movements, as adversaries and as allies, and the ways in which activists may engender change from within the organization.

All lectures and workshops are mandatory. Students are allowed to miss 1 session. If more classes are missed, students will have to do a compensation assignment or risk failing the course. Please find the complete course schedule including room information at timetables.eur.nl.

• Reflect on the interconnections between structural, relational and cultural elements of movement activities
• Relate to the opportunities and risks attached to movement activities
• Empathize with perspectives from different backgrounds and organizations in relation to movement issues

column1: This course introduces students to basic qualitative and quantitative research methodologies for designing and conducting development-oriented research. It covers research problem formulation, collection of information and data, and presentation and interpretation of both qualitative and numerical data. Students are introduced to a variety of qualitative and quantitative data collection techniques, with an emphasis on mixing of qualitative and quantitative methods and its impact on the analysis of data. Ethical considerations will also be examined. The course is problem-oriented in that students are guided and asked from the very beginning to develop their own solutions to challenges involved in doing research. After its completion, students will be prepared to work on their research paper and to conduct a research project based on secondary and/or primary data.

All students must have an ECDL score for Excel of at least 70%. Students without any background in statistics may want to take the remedial class in quantitative skills (9103) but this is not a necessary requirement.
O’Leary, Zina (2017) The Essential Guide to Doing Your Research Project. 3rd Edition. London: Sage.
Bryman, A. (2016) Social Research Methods. (5th Edition) Oxford: Oxford University Press.
Hennink, Monique; Inge Hutter and Ajay Bailey (2011) Qualitative Research Methods. London: Sage.
Laws, S., C. Harper and R. Marcus (2003) Research for Development: A Practical Guide. London: Sage in co-operation with Save the Children. Available as e- book at EUR library.
Morgan, D.L. (2014) Integrating Qualitative and Quantitative Methods: A Pragmatic Approach. Thousand Oaks; London: Sage. Available as e-book at EUR library.
Plano Clark, V.L. and N. V. Ivankova (2016) Mixed Methods Research: A Guide to the Field. Thousand Oaks; London: Sage. Available as e-book at EUR library.

column1: The overall objective of the course is for students to acquire key skills and knowledge for conducting and using development-oriented social science research, both for MA work at the ISS and for professional work later, as an investigator, or client, or study evaluator.
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

column2: • Distinguish different ways of asking and addressing complex research questions through multiple quantitative and qualitative, theoretical, and interdisciplinary approaches and practices;
• Critically assess the appropriateness of methodological choices in social research;
• Design their own research by formulating an appropriate approach and mixing multiple methods;

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111218,2023,Multicultureel Ontwikkeling en Onderwijs,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. WWP Smets'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Tot voor kort was de pedagogische en onderwijskundige wetenschap vooral gericht op wetenschappelijke studies op het gebied van westerse populaties en culturen. Dit heeft voor een westers vooroordeel in kennis en theorie gezorgd. Door mondialisering en migratie ontwikkelingen kan deze kennis over pedagogische en onderwijskundige zaken niet automatisch meer toegepast worden op andere culturen of etnische minderheidsgroepen in Nederland. In de afgelopen jaren is echter veel onderzoek verricht en zijn theorieën ontwikkeld die fenomenen op het gebied van opvoeding en onderwijs in multicultureel perspectief kunnen beschrijven en verklaren. Dit onderzoek en deze theorieën staan centraal in dit blok. Enerzijds worden de basistheorieën behandeld zoals acculturatie theorieën. Anderzijds komen theorieën aan bod die op ontwikkeling en opvoeding betrekking hebben en theorieën die over het onderwijs gaan.

Daarnaast leren de studenten niet alleen over methodologische en theoretische zaken met betrekking tot de wetenschappelijke studie van multiculturele gemeenschappen, maar zij worden ook aangemoedigd om een kritische en beschouwende blik en een ethische en onbevooroordeelde houding te ontwikkelen in de studie naar de ontwikkeling en onderwijs van kinderen vanuit een multicultureel perspectief.

column1: The ‘global South’ can be considered the birthplace of many of the intersecting ideas on resistance, solidarity and social justice that today resonate across the world—think of Black Lives Matter and calls to decolonise educational systems, for instance. This course is an invitation to explore such entangled histories with the global South at its centre, and seeks to highlight voices and perspectives that have traditionally been un(der)-represented in traditional curricula.

Through a combination of texts and audio-visual materials, we will think through global history from a non-Western perspective. The starting point is the idea of ‘multiple modernities’: differing experiences departing from the notion of ‘modernity’ as standing in for Western civilisation. We will study the global South as a politically, economically, and culturally imagined space by adopting the Global History approach within the study of history.

By critically engaging with the histories rooted in the production of knowledge that has generated binary oppositions in geographies (‘North/South’, ‘East/West’, ‘developed/developing’, ‘First/Third World’) and relations (insider/outsider, inclusion/exclusion, us/them, coloniser/colonised, rich/poor), we will look at the power dynamics inherent in such binaries and connections that transcend them.

An online project will have you build an archive as both a method as well as a tool to reframe and reconstruct ‘forgotten’ or ‘silenced’ histories. Topics covered in the course include revolution, (colonial) violence, and the struggles of decolonisation, including attempts to forge transcontinental solidarities. Finally, we will look at our own historical moment and think through the present-day reverberations of colonialism and racism, as well as the promise of potential history.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and describe the scholarly debate on the roots of ‘Western Civilization’.
• Formulate a personal position within the scholarly debate.
• Trace the evolution of ‘the Other’ in ‘Western’ and ‘Eastern’ societies from Ancient times to the present.
• Problematize ‘Europe’ as a cultural construct.
• Compare concepts of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Trace the current-day iconography of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Discuss the link between Ancient Greek, Muslim and ‘Western’ thinking on the relationship between the spiritual and the temporal.
• Explain the decolonization process in the African continent.
• Critically analyze (political) debates on the role of China in the African continent.
• Explain the basic history of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Discuss the current day cultural, economic and political effects of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Explain Edward Said’s critique of orientalism.
• Explain Samuel Huntington’s theory of the Clash of Civilizations.
• Position a historically and theoretically underpinned view within the discursive debate on ‘East’ and ‘West’.

column1: This course is about museums. There are museums of every imaginable topic and genre with varied organisational and financing structures, large and small, located in different contexts and following a variety of approaches to collecting, curation, exhibition, social engagement and digitization. Overall, as central institutions for cultural heritage and change, as crucial sites of public arts provision, cultural engagement and knowledge production, as key players in the arts markets, as local providers of jobs and as important tourist destinations, museums are key concerns of contemporary cultural policy and have undoubtedly play an important and multidimensional part in society. As such, museums find themselves at the forefront of contemporary cultural trends and politics, of socio-economic developments and technological transformations. In this connection, their position in and role for society is intensely debated. Whether it is museums’ profound entanglements with inequalities of class, gender, ‘race’ and/or (post)colonial legacies, their changing role for arts education, audience engagement and taste-making or their ambivalent implication in sustainability debates, scholars and cultural workers alike are critically thinking through museums’ work, creative impact and social effects.

In this connection, this course sets out to analyse the museum institution from an interdisciplinary perspective – combining insights primarily from sociology, but also from museum studies and cultural economics – to discuss the complex social contexts in which museums operate. In particular, we will discuss different theoretical approaches to the study of museums, to their social role and value(s); we will explore museums’ role for cultural heritage and think through them as barometers for social and cultural change; we will reflect on the relationship between the museums and cultural policy; we will look at museums as creative industries; we will consider their position in wider debates around sustainability and climate change; we examine different forms of visiting and using a museum; and we reflect on how digital technologies and social media impact on the workings of museums today.

While this course therefore familiarises students with different theoretical and conceptual vantage points to the topic of museums, it also offers students the opportunity to apply their interdisciplinary theoretic framework to hands-on cases. Indeed, we will grapple with a number of ‘wicked problems’ that museum institutions are currently facing. In small teams, students will be asked to zoom into one of such problems in more depth and to develop an appropriate, independent research project in this context. In so doing, students will choose/develop a research question, think of an appropriate museum or exhibition case study and conduct their own empirical research project, drawing on the class materials and outlining some practical recommendations.

By encouraging students to carefully think through the different topics of this course and to apply different theoretical perspectives to the study of museums, the course thus aims to support students in developing independent research and writing skills which will help them, amongst others, with their Master theses.
