column1: In dit vak besteden wij aandacht zowel aan nationale geschillen als aan grensoverschrijdende geschillen. In toenemende mate zien wij geschillen met een internationale dimensie, waarin vragen van internationaal privaatrecht spelen: welk (materieel) recht is toepasselijk op de zaak, welke rechter is internationaal bevoegd en hoe het zit met de grensoverschrijdende erkenning en tenuitvoerlegging van een eventuele uitspraak? Als de procedure zich afspeelt voor de Nederlandse rechter, betekent dat niet dat zich geen ‘grensoverschrijdende’ vragen kunnen voordoen, zoals vragen rondom internationale betekening, bewijs dat uit het buitenland moet worden verkregen en toepasselijkheid van ‘buitenlands’ materieel recht. Ook voor de ontwikkeling van het procesrecht wordt steeds meer gekeken naar de wijze waarop het procesrecht elders is ingericht en in de EU zijn de eerste stappen gezet naar harmonisering van procedures.

Na een introductie in de leerstukken, begrippen en rechtsregels van het internationaal privaatrecht, zullen wij ter aanvulling op en verdieping van het bachelorvak burgerlijk procesrecht een aantal actuele procesrechtelijke thema’s behandelen vanuit nationaal en internationaal perspectief. De actuele discussie in Nederland over de verhouding tussen rechter en partijen komt aan de orde en biedt een aanknopingspunt om ons te verdiepen in het fenomeen forumshopping, dat vooral in internationale zaken een rol speelt. Incassozaken grijpen wij bijvoorbeeld aan om de ontwikkelingen rond digitalisering en vereenvoudiging van procedures te bestuderen alsook de vragen die spelen in internationale zaken om grensoverschrijdende incasso te vergemakkelijken (harmonisering van procedures). Een ander voorbeeld van een thema dat in dit vak aan de orde zal komen is (de modernisering van) het bewijsrecht. De bewijsgaring biedt een mooi aanknopingspunt om over de grenzen te kijken. Deze en andere actuele aspecten van het nationaal en internationaal procederen zullen na de tussentoets in de seminars van dit vak centraal staan. In dit vak wordt tevens een brug geslagen naar de praktijk door colleges van gastdocenten en door de aandacht voor ethische dilemma’s in de beroepspraktijk.</body>

column1: Het Studentenparlement is een landelijke debatwedstrijd die elke 2 jaar wordt georganiseerd door de docenten van alle rechtenfaculteiten in Nederland, onder auspiciën van de Staatsrechtkring. De bedoeling is dat elke faculteit een fractie van 3 tot 8 studenten afvaardigt die een standpunt formuleert over een - door een werkgroep van docenten opgesteld - fictief wetsvoorstel. Net als bij de wetgevingsprocedure voor de Tweede Kamer is er eerst een schriftelijke fase (in de periode van oktober - februari) en vervolgens vindt in mei een mondeling debat tussen alle fracties plaats in de vergaderzaal van de Tweede Kamer.

Een onafhankelijke jury - doorgaans bestaande uit een hoogleraar staatsrecht, een of meerdere politici en een parlementair journalist - beoordeelt vervolgens de prestaties van de verschillende fracties. Winnaar is die fractie die zowel in zijn bijdrage aan het Verslag, als in het mondelinge debat de beste prestatie heeft geleverd, dat wil zeggen met het oog op het politieke karakter van het evenement, zo goed mogelijk heeft gedebatteerd.</body>

column1: Dr. Meike Morren (VU) and Prof. Dr. Bas Donkers (EUR)

Natural Language Processing (NLP) comprises statistical and machine learning tools for automatically analyzing text data to derive useful insights from it. Vast amounts of information are stored in this form, and hence NLP has become one of the essential technologies of the big data age. In this course, core concepts and techniques from the area will be studied, with a focus on methods that are popular in business applications. These include n-gram models, word vectors, sentiment analysis, word embeddings and topic modelling.

This course offers students a theoretically informed understanding of NLP. It aims at broadening the knowledge of the methods involved in NLP, as well as a hands-on experience with the steps that need to be taken in an NLP project. We focus on three aspects:
a) to create deep(er) understanding of the main methods in NLP (n-gram, lexicon approach, word embeddings and other advanced machine learning methods);
b) to obtain an experience to scrape and clean the data yourself;
c) to apply this knowledge and experience in a group assignment which gives you the possibility to show your creativity.

By the end of this course, you will be able to analyse and evaluate NLP approaches. Moreover, you will apply this knowledge and skills in a real-life setting, enabling you to translate and apply theoretical knowledge into practice.

column2: • Information theory, regular expressions and scraping (tokenization, stemming, lemmatization, parsing).
• Word vectors and dimension reduction based on bag of words (n-grams)
• Sentiment analysis (lexicon-based vs model-based)
• Word embeddings (Word2Vec, GloVe, BERT)
• Topic models (LDA)

column4: KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING
Demonstrate knowledge of Natural Language Processing, from data cleaning to advanced machine learning approaches, including:
Information theory, regular expressions, scraping and data cleaning (tokenization, stemming, lemmatization, parsing).
Word vectors and dimension reduction based on bag of words (n-grams, PCA)
APPLICATION OF KNOWLEDGE
Apply this theoretical knowledge and experience in group assignments. Analyze and evaluate NLP approaches.
MAKING JUDGEMENT
Evaluate the effectiveness of marketing expenditure, evaluate the appropriateness of a model
COMMUNICATION
Written and oral presentation of results within the research project.
LEARNING SKILLS
Work on the research project in a team.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The way we work is changing. The era of holding a full-time job for twenty years at a single company is becoming a thing of the past. Emerging generations seek greater workplace flexibility, a diverse range of professional experiences, and a dynamic approach to their careers. How does this transformation relate to the rapidly changing business environment?

This course explores the dynamic interplay between shifting work paradigms and the contemporary business ecosystem. As we witness the ascent of innovative business models, digital platforms stand out as prominent game-changers. Companies such as Uber, Deliveroo, and Upwork epitomize the fast-paced, technology-driven environment of our era. They leverage cutting-edge digital technologies, embrace on-demand workforce sourcing, and offer the freedom to work from virtually anywhere in the world.

Moreover, the relentless advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) is profoundly shaping the way we work. AI's applications extend to workforce coordination, monitoring, and surveillance, significantly impacting various professions. For instance, Uber drivers answer to sophisticated algorithms rather than traditional bosses, as these algorithms assign tasks, dispense rewards, and administer penalties.

The emergence of novel business models like platforms, the transformative power of AI, and the expansion of remote work opportunities compel us to reevaluate our values and priorities. Do we prioritize careers or seek a better work-life balance? Is flexibility more valuable than job security? Is privacy more important to us or personalized opportunities? Beyond individual perspectives, business leaders must reassess their priorities and the kind of societies they wish to cultivate. They face critical decisions, such as choosing between equitable working conditions and short-term profit gains. As future managers, you'll learn to critically evaluate different business decisions and assess their potential impact on the society.

This course explores the evolving nature of work, with a particular focus on digital platforms as a case study. We also examine algorithm-driven workforce management and surveillance, as well as the societal repercussions and regulatory complexities associated with these changes.
We delve into the critical questions that define this paradigm shift:

column2: <li>

Rise of New Business Models: How are platforms reshaping the way we work, and how do they exemplify broader shifts in work-related expectations? What are other forms of organizing, beyond mainstream platform, that are emerging, and can they offer more equitable value distribution and better working conditions?
<li>

AI at Work: What role does AI play in coordinating, managing, and monitoring workers? We investigate how automated decision-making can enhance productivity and when it raises concerns about worker well-being and autonomy.

• Societal Impact and Ethical Considerations: We analyze the far-reaching consequences of these innovative organizational models on society at large. How do they influence our work practices, and what opportunities and challenges do they present for individuals, businesses, and policymakers?

column1: Attendance and class participation make up 5% of the grade, which students can obtain by attending all lectures (in exceptional situations students may miss one lecture to obtain full points for attendance) and actively contributing to class discussions. The latter is important because students benefit by hearing perspectives of others and reflecting upon their own, thus contributing to the discussions benefits the class as whole.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Discover Novel Business Models: Gain a deep comprehension of the platform business model, including its core principles, advantages, and how it differs from traditional business models. Learn about new organizational forms – platform cooperatives, going beyond mainstream platforms to tackle challenges of the new ways of working.

• Evaluate Societal Implications: Assess the broader consequences of cultural shift, new business models, and the use of AI at work. Critically evaluate the impact on the future of work, challenges, and opportunities these changes present for individuals, businesses, and policymakers, and develop informed perspectives on these issues.

• Understand Applications of AI at Work: Familiarize yourself with the role AI plays in coordinating, managing, and monitoring workers. Which automated decisions can improve the way we work and when does it present a threat to workers' well-being and autonomy? Investigate the concept of algorithmic management within platform ecosystems, exploring its role in work allocation, performance monitoring, and its impact on both workers and organizations.

column1: Een cursus Nederlands bestaat uit tien wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 2,5 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt na afloop van de cursus plaats op een vooraf vastgestelde datum (zie onderstaande planning). Aan het einde van de cursus is de stof van één cursusniveau behandeld.
Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands A1?
Tijdens deze cursus leer je de basis van de Nederlandse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, schrijven en spreken in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen

column2: • jezelf voorstellen;
• begroeten en afscheid nemen van mensen;
• afspraak maken;
• café, markt, restaurant en kledingzaak;
• grammatica;
• vocabulaire;
• de Nederlandse cultuur.
<title></title>

column1: Aan het einde van de cursus beschik je over een bescheiden woordenschat zodat je in veelvoorkomende en alledaagse situaties kunt communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is A1 volgens het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR).

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Het Language & Training Centre organiseert driemaal per jaar cursussen Nederlands (oktober-december / januari-maart / april-juni).
• Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
• De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Nederlands gesproken.
• Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 43,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen.
• Het speciale tarief geldt alleen voor PhD studenten van Erasmus Universiteit Rotterdam. Daarbij is het cursusmateriaal wel inbegrepen.
• In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 15 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.

• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.
• Lees ook onze voorwaarden.

column1: Being able to negotiate successfully is essential in establishing and maintaining fruitful business relationships and transactions. In this course, we utilize a psychological perspective to develop professional negotiation skills. We will focus on cognitions, emotions and motivations that impact the negotiation process and outcomes, and explore different negotiation strategies and their outcomes in terms of potential value, efficiency and relationship quality. We will also address some basic knowledge about individual decision making. This course is very hands-on and will give you ample opportunity to practice your negotiation skills by learning how expand the pie and create value.

All RSM electives have mandatory attendance. This means that you are expected to attend the on-campus seminar sessions. Sessions will start at the indicated time. Please make sure that you are there and ready to start a few minutes before the session begins. Many sessions feature practical exercises and being late may mean that you will not be able to participate in the day’s exercise. Each student may miss one class session without consequences. For further absences (with a maximum 2 total absences), students can compensate with a substitute assignment (please see Canvas for details on the assignment and regulations). In case you need to miss more than two sessions, you need to apply for an exemption with the RSM study advisors.</body>

column1: Negotiation is one of the most important skills that a manager should have in professional life. In our curriculum, however, this important skill has been underemphasized. This course aims to help you be a better negotiator. I will provide you with negotiation tools to effectively persuade others. The specific topics of this course include seeing and expanding the pie, dealing with someone who has a very different perspective on the world, disagreeing respectfully and productively, etc.
If you're unable to attend the majority of the course sessions, completing the assignments will be challenging, making it improbable for you to pass the course.

column1: Social Networks shape many aspects of how people and organizations interact, take decisions, and ultimately perform. With the advent of Social Media (e.g., Facebook and Twitter) and with the increasing digitization of all forms of communication and business processes, Network Analytics has become a valued asset to better understand how different agents interact and how to best take advantage of the network structure to increase overall system performance. This course will cover the fundamentals of network science, the methods, theories, and the procedures for data collection and analysis in very large social networks. Covered topics include clustering, information diffusion, organizational design, viral marketing, social media, and others.

This course provides the basics of network data analytics, including fundamental network- and node-level metrics, as well as more advanced analysis methods, with attention to the application areas where these can and have been used. Students will engage in in-class projects in which they collect and analyze network data using the tools and methods covered in class. Students will apply these methods to specific networks, such as social media networks (e.g., Twitter), co-worker networks, organization networks, and product networks.

column1: <body>In solving social problems and providing public services, governments depend on a variety of other actors, including other governments, political actors, executive organizations, interest groups, businesses, media and citizens. These actors, in turn, depend on governments to make policies to address societal problems. Tackling social problems therefore often happens in networks of mutually dependent actors - these actors need each other to arrive at solutions. We call these networks governance networks. The focus of the course Network Governance is on these governance networks, the processes that occur in them - substantive and relational - and how these networks can be managed. </body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: By the end of this course, students will be able to..

column2: <li>
Differentiate Network Governance from other approaches to decision-making, more specifically Traditional Public Administration and New Public Management;
<li>
Explain how substantive, strategic, and institutional complexity arise in collective decision-making processes;
<li>
Evaluate real-world examples of collective decision-making processes, using concepts of the Network Governance approach;
<li>
Evaluate network management strategies used to tackle the complexity of collective decision-making processes;
<li>
Evaluate different negotiation techniques and tactics in complex decision-making processes;
<li>
Describe the normative implications of the Network Governance approach for democratic legitimacy and accountability in decision-making.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115013,2023,Neuroeconomics: how the brain decides,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MAS Boksem', 'LD van Brussel, MSc', 'prof.dr.ir. A Smidts']",,"Inhoud

Economics, psychology, and neuroscience are converging into the unified discipline of Neuroeconomics with the aim of providing a single, general theory of human choice behaviour. Neuroeconomics can provide social scientists, consumers, and managers with a deeper understanding of how they make their own decisions, and how others decide. How is a “good” or “fair” decision evaluated by the brain? What does our brain perceive as valuable? How do we learn the value of features of our environment? Is it possible to predict the purchasing intentions of a consumer? Are we hard-wired to be risk-averse or risk-seeking?

Neuroscience combined with psychology, economics and management theory provides powerful models and advanced brain-research methods to explain how and why people make certain choices. Risky decision-making in financial markets, the role of emotions versus rationality, competition and cooperation in teams, consumer persuasion, are some of the central issues in this course in neuroeconomics. You will be provided with the most recent evidence from brain-imaging studies, and you will be introduced to the explanatory models behind them.

The course will consist of five modules. In Part 1: “Introduction to Neuroeconomics”, we discuss the history of neuroeconomics and provide a crash-course on the anatomy of the brain, as well as an introduction to neuroscience methods. In Part 2: “How the Brain Decides about Things”, students will be presented with the main theories and neuroscientific findings accounting for how the brain makes (optimal) economic choices. We will focus on the neural mechanisms of the computation of value and preference, and how the brain deals with risk and losses. In Part 3: “How the Brain is Biased in Decisions about Things”, we discuss how choices are often biased and that people often rely on heuristics instead of ‘rational’ analysis of decision problems. In Part 4: “How the Brain Decides about People”, we will review current theories and scientific findings on social decision-making, focussing particularly on evaluations of fairness, cooperation, trust and empathy. In addition, we will investigate individual differences in choice behaviour and how decision-making changes across the lifespan. We also discuss brain processes underlying moral decisions. Finally, the practical applications of brain research in the fields of economics, marketing, business, and other aspects of society will be discussed in Part 5: “Neuroeconomics in Business and Society”.

Each lecture will be given by a researcher with specific expertise on the topic. Lecturers either have a background in cognitive neuroscience or in economics and management research, and they are all collaborating in the Erasmus Centre for Neuroeconomics (see our website for further information: www.erim.nl/neuroeconomics).

Students are required to show active participation in the course by attending the lectures and actively participating in the discussion forum (see below). The basic concepts of the course will be examined by means of a written exam and a research proposal.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: After completion of this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Name and identify the brain areas involved in choice behaviour.
• Select the appropriate (neuro)scientific method for investigating different aspects of choice behaviour.
• Explain which cognitive processes (decision parameters, heuristics) produce certain biases in choice behaviour.
• Name and identify the brain areas that constitute the brain’s reward and punishment systems.
• Explain how these systems work together to produce choice behaviour and apply this knowledge to explain various choice phenomena.
• Name and identify the brain mechanisms that are involved in social choice behaviour.
• Explain individual differences in choice behaviour by referring to the underlying neurobiological mechanisms.
• Apply your neuroscientific knowledge to come up with methods to improve choice behaviour in real life.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116787,2023,Neuromarketing,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MAS Boksem', 'prof.dr.ir. A Smidts']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course introduces the interdisciplinary field of neuromarketing. This new and exciting area in marketing aims to understand the neurobiological mechanisms underlying customer responses to marketing actions, and to better predict customer behavior using brain markers. Neuromarketing is proposed to reveal information about customer preferences and reactions to marketing actions that other techniques cannot provide (Ariely and Berns, 2010). This is based on the assumption that customers are not always able or willing to express their true preferences in questionnaires. Furthermore, measures of brain activation could assist in the early stages of the product or advertising development process thus reducing the likelihood of failures.

In recent years, the application of neuroimaging and psychophysical techniques in marketing has surged both in academia and in marketing practice. Modern brain imaging techniques of electroencephalography (EEG) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) are commonly applied, for example, to track the emotional response to brands and TV commercials, to assess which scenes of a commercial attract attention and are memorable, to evaluate the beauty of a package or how customers trade-off price and quality. Psychophysical techniques such as eye-tracking, galvanic skin response and heart rate measurement add additional insights into the customers’ heart and mind.

Currently, most marketers are not trained in these techniques and thus have difficulty in properly evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of these methods. Clients of neuromarketing companies may get easily impressed by colorful pictures of activations in the brain which may not be truly insightful or predictive. In this course we provide the student with an up to date insight into the current body of knowledge in consumer neuroscience and neuromarketing. Accordingly, this course will provide both theoretical and practical insights to develop neuromarketing skills. In lectures and on-line demonstrations, the main neuroimaging techniques of fMRI and EEG will be introduced, showing you the basics of analyzing this type of data.
Attendance of the workshops (practical sessions) and the guest lectures are mandatory. Attendance of regular lectures is not mandatory, but highly recommended.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Understand the basic anatomy and workings of the brain, and the main neural processes underlying consumer decision making and consumer reactions to marketing actions

• Understand and explain the intuition behind the neuroimaging methods of fMRI and EEG, and apply these insights by analyzing and reporting neuroimaging data, and drawing inferences from neuromarketing data of relevance to marketing managers
• Design a neuromarketing study and communicate and justify managerial recommendations from neuromarketing studies
• Understand the main opportunities and challenges of modern neuroscientific techniques for marketing purposes, including its ethical concerns and societal implications

column1: Brain damage can cause cognitive, emotional and behavioral dysfunctions. A clinical psychologist, who works in the mental healthcare sector, has most likely to deal with brain-damaged patients. Think for instance about injuries resulting from a car accident, or about people, who suffered a stroke or patients, who suffer from neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease.

During the block, you will study the anatomy of human brain, as well as the functions of the cortical and subcortical areas. In addition, you will be familiarized with the techniques applied in science and in clinical settings, which contribute to our understanding of the brain, and to the diagnoses of neuropsychological disorders.

During the course, students are required to 1) fill in weekly Individual Readiness Assurance Tests, 2) to attend the weekly team sessions, and 3) to provide peer feedback to all fellow team members. These activities are mandatory and will be evaluated with a pass/fail qualification.

column1: This block has three main learning goals
• To know the structure and organization of the central nervous system (CNS).
• To link the brain anatomy to the psychological processes like sensory perception, motion, learning and memory, emotion, language, attention, and other executive functions.
• To apply the knowledge about brain anatomy and psychological processes to better understand the symptomatology of the neuropsychological disorders and their causes.

G. Jansen', 'dr. M. van der Werf', 'dr. R. Osterthun', 'drs. E. Grauwmeijer', 'K. Nieuwenhuis', 'R.F. Pangalila']",,

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: The way your brain works, governs how you interact with the world, how society works and what we consider as reality, among other things. So why not learn a little bit of how the brain works? This is a multidisciplinary course in which you will be able to define several concepts from the neuroscience perspective, such as sensory perception, the concept of “self”, behaviour, and learning and memory. You will further recognise how different disciplines, like Neuroeconomics, Psychology and Philosophy, apply neuroscientific knowledge in their practice. Finally, you might have the opportunity of participating in a (animal) brain bisection practical to bring into reality what you have learnt during the course.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

After completing the course students will be able to discuss the link between music (perception) and human movement, especially in terms of evolutionary auditory specialization, in terms of interpersonal coordination and in terms of the effects of musical training on the brain. Students will be able to argue that without movement, there is no music, neither played nor perceived. Students will have had an introduction to several behavioral measurement techniques, digital audio analysis, experiment design, as well as scientific reporting. Finally, students will be able to bridge gaps between research fields in the sense of applying existing research methods and questions to a field that these methods were not developed for.

column1: Most students from RSM will be confronted with new business development at some stage in their careers. This course aims to serve as a pilot test for you, assessing your strength and weakness in entrepreneurial practices. To do so, this course will collaborate with multiple companies and provide tangible business projects for you, with the aim to address real business challenges related to new business development. As a result, you will face the full complexity of new business development. To assist you navigate the project, a reference contact from the company will actively work with you during the six weeks of the course.

</style>
• Developing a comprehensive understanding of the organizational problems that entrepreneurs must face when aiming for new business development
• Gaining a critical attitude towards the understanding of new business development practices in context with significant time and resource constraints
• Putting entrepreneurial theories into practice by interacting with the business community in a complex, real business case

<body>Towards behavioural economics 2.0? Several proposals have been made to move (behavioural) economics beyond the stage in which economics has been enriched by psychological findings and insights. In this course, several directions are identified and discussed: Brains, Evolution, Morality, Complexity, Culture and Welfare & Policy.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

At the end of this course, students will have developed an informed and nuanced overview of several directions in which behavioral economics can further evolve. Testimony for this will have to be provided by writing an research paper in which students show that they have a clear idea about the about both the prospects (merits and demerits) of behavioural economics moving forward into one of these directions.

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: The aim of this minor is to explore new futures of the economy by critically engaging with transformative entrepreneurs and in academic debates around economic transitions as well as by diving into the everyday practices of new value propositions advanced by social entrepreneurs. The minor involves case-based learning together with enterprises and start-up companies that aim at making a difference by creating wider societal impact through innovative value-creation.

The current economic system is under pressure because of unsustainable exploitation of resources and increasing pollution of our planet. Climate change and severe biodiversity losses are accelerating at an unprecedented scale while societies are facing rising inequalities in wealth and access to opportunities. These problems are not separate crises, but they can all be rooted in fundamental flaws of the current economic system and imply a transition towards an economy that is sustainable, circular, prosperous, and inclusive. Even though more and more societal actors (such as companies, governments, consumers) acknowledge their responsibility to contribute to addressing global issues like climate change, poverty, and biodiversity losses, they often struggle to develop appropriate responses (e.g., through governance or new business models) that help to guide and accelerate transitions to a sustainable economy and society. At the same time, diverse innovators, entrepreneurs, and pioneers start building economic activities on principles of the circular, sharing or solidarity economy, or practice social entrepreneurship or impact investment as alternatives. They adopt different perspectives on and approaches to value creation and use new value propositions.

New economic thinking brings along new types of relations and partnerships, requires behavioral and institutional change, and implies structural changes in markets and power relations. Transition research can help to understand the complex nature of these processes on the macro level. New value propositions and purpose driven business models analyzed in impact studies contribute to understanding dynamics towards new economic thinking on micro level. In this minor we focus on understanding why and how transformative dynamics in socio-economic systems evolve, how system change may come about and how sustainable business models emerge.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Using interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary perspectives, combining insights from economics, management, and transition studies in this Minor you will:
1. Obtain an overview of alternative economic theories, their implications, and critiques.
2. Get insight into sustainability transition theory and understand how societal change occurs and become able to map sustainability transition dynamics.

3. Become familiar with new value propositions and alternative business models, and with the ways in and why businesses change and innovate in response to societal transitions and societal or environmental challenges.

4. Better understand business challenges and opportunities of diffusing such innovative business models from an academic and practitioners’ perspective including financing, management, and governance lenses.
5. Become familiar with the value proposition of impact thinking and impact measurement.

6. Work in a group project in which you will apply your new academic knowledge and insights on a practical case. With your group, you carry out a consultancy project for a social entrepreneur. At the end of the course, each group will share their advice, ideas, and suggestions in a pitch to the social entrepreneurs during a “Dragon’s Den” event.

The minor will combine lectures by academics and will include both group and individual assignments. Next to that we will help you to improve your soft skills, like debating, presenting and or working in teams.

column1: If you want to participate in this minor, we expect you to be open minded, curious and – at times – provocative and interested in solving the grand challenges society is facing. You will engage in critical debates and be able to reflect critically upon offered theories. Multidisciplinary perspectives, applied research and problem oriented learning approaches have your interest. As this minor is delivered in English, you need to have a sufficient command of the English language in speech and writing to actively participate in class. We strongly encourage students from diverse disciplines to apply.

column1: At the core of this course, we explore the transformative impact of new media on interaction. The main question emerges: “How do new media platforms influence our personal and social reality by shaping the way we meet, communicate, and ultimately construct our personal and social world?”

This essential question prompts us to closely examine the multifaceted nature of contemporary communication. We delve into (1) the diverse types of new media, exploring media convergence. We explore theories such as affordance theory and social presence theory. We inspect (2) the role of new media in interpersonal contexts such as digital identity, virtual friendship and dating.  Finally, we confront (3) ongoing debates and concerns in new media. From discussions about mediated identities, and algorithms to ethical considerations including privacy concerns and cyberbullying, we address the challenges and consequences of our digital lives.

Throughout this seminar, we draw on theories and research cases from media and communication studies. Each week, we aim to deepen our understanding of the profound ways in which new media platforms intersect with our lives, not only moulding how we communicate but also shaping our self-perception and how we engage with others.</body>

column2: <title></title>

column1: New media and social media have become central to everyday life, and how these can be used effectively within international business has become an important topic for business and communication research. From mobile apps and gaming to social media including Instagram, Facebook and Twitter, new media have changed the way international business gets done. While these changes have transformed logistics, resource management and hiring practices, this course will specifically focus on how new media have affected (and been affected by) marketing practices and the growing importance of social media as a channel of strategic communication. That is, the course will focus on two areas. First, it will evaluate marketing practices that employ new media, most specifically the practices on social media through Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, YouTube, and more. Second, the course will look at a new wave of marketing strategies that involve influencers, participatory publics/audiences, gamification, and fandoms.

In the first few weeks of the course, students will be oriented to a practice theory focused approach to understanding the use of new media in context, exploring readings and examples ranging from traditional media to videogames to the rise of independent content creators. This is then further focused on the three focus areas within the course. During the latter part of the research workshop, students will engage in qualitative research focused on new media and international business, examining the practices and technologies involved in the marketing of specific media/mediated products – streaming content, videogames, apps, theme parks, and music, among others. They will, through the use of qualitative and/or mixed methods, empirically examine the ways in which companies and content creators promote themselves through social media as part of a marketing strategy, how they interface with each other and users in creating buzz about new products, how gamified advergames are used to enhance attraction (and also, at times, mislead consumers), and other related topics. In order to gain both conceptual and methodological knowledge, students will take several reading comprehension quizzes, engage in in-class exercises, group work, develop their own line of research, execute and present on research work that is subsequently integrated into a final research paper.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • How marketing and business practices shape markets through various technologies and techniques
• Differentiated levels of control (and their implications) attained by international businesses in the use of new and social media (with particular attention to marketing and human resources)
• How new and/or social media choices affect the distribution and control of information and communication
• The use of empirical cases studies in studying new media practices
• Develop and execute a small research project either focusing on new media and marketing or new media and workplace contexts
• Effectively research new media practices through empirical case studies
• Evaluate practices within international businesses, focusing on the potentials and problems that come with the use of new media
• Define problematic potentials for practices and policies within international business in relation to new media
• Report their research findings in a scientifically substantiated manner
• Work with (international) peers and reflect on their own development

column1: Back in the mid-1990s, the rapid popularization of the Internet had raised the hope of technologically-enhanced citizen engagement in political decision-making. How did the vision of an electronic democracy, where new media enable citizens to monitor and participate in the life of their polis, turn out in practice? On the one hand, our own use of new media is oriented towards consumption and entertainment. On the other, political content circulated online is often dubious or problematic, while political debates online often become heated and even toxic. From cyberwarfare and fake news, to citizen digital activism, online political communication appears to be in a state of constant transformation. Each year, the instructor focuses the course around a salient topic in the field of online political communication (e.g. deliberation; populism; etc.) asking how citizens and politicians engage in political talk online and to what effect on the quality of our democracies and or our polities. In addressing the topic, we focus on the ways in which new media both hinder and enable political communication. Since the secondary purpose of this course is to improve your empirical research skills, you develop and conduct a small research project on the topic of the course. You gain methodological knowledge and skill necessary for assessing and doing scientific research. The course thus improves your qualitative research knowledge and skill. Furthermore, the knowledge about online political communication gained in this course improves your own civic performance and prompts you to consider how, as a communication professional, you can help create democratic communication.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115123,2023,New Media and the Creative Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. ML Wayne'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>

column1: This is an exciting and transformative moment for creative industries across the globe. As the economics of media industries shift from advertising-based revenue models to subscriber-based revenue models, streaming platforms that provide different types of content directly to consumers are becoming increasingly important. For example, the global expansion of streaming video on-demand services like Netflix both reflect and drive change within traditional audiovisual media industries like television and film. Yet, the proprietary nature of streaming audience data and the near total lack of data transparency offered by streaming companies themselves creates a variety of challenges for media industry researchers.

The main goal of this research workshop is to help students to overcome these challenges using the “production culture” approach. This approach, sometimes called media historiography, media industry studies, or trade press analysis, is grounded in the academic perspective that understands media industry discourse as centrally important to understanding media industry practice.

Students will learn how to gather and analyze relevant data about the creative industries from a variety of publicly available sources including but not limited to trade press articles, press releases, trade and popular press interviews, videos of industry events, and financial documents. Students will formulate a research question related to a specific streaming service situated within a broader streaming industry. Students will create a qualitative research design, collect and then analyze data. Their efforts culminate in an academic research paper.

column2: <title></title>

column1: Entertainment and cultural products shape the identities of audiences and fans all over the world. Music, TV shows, movies, videogames and anime are all different ways of contacting with different cultures and connecting with strangers. In a time where nationalism and divisions are on the rise in some parts of the world, this course explores how people connect, share experiences and produce new content related to their favorite cultural products. How do fan groups and forums organize themselves online? How do cultural products create conflicts or encourage friendships? What is the impact of new media on community building? Do entertainment products help bridge tensions and reduce polarization between different groups?

Using quantitative content analysis, we will learn how to conduct research in the world of entertainment and explore the interactions between cultural products and audiences. Furthermore, students will learn that research about communities and new media is not limited to the field of entertainment, but that similar research methods and concepts can also be applied to other communication fields like brand communities and national identities.

column2: <title></title>

column1: Perceptions of the political are evolving due to widespread transformations in society and new media play an important role in these transformations. Yet, the debate on whether advances in new media technologies are impacting democracy positively or negatively remains complex and open to constant revision. This seminar looks at the role that new media (particularly social media, but also more classic forms like websites and blogs) play within such an evolving political context with a focus on political campaigns. Throughout the course, we build a theoretical background allowing us to assess contemporary dimensions of (internet) politics. For our discussions, we focus on three types of campaigns: electoral, grassroots (or citizen-led), and public information campaigns. Each week, we introduce the relevant debates and classical concepts associated with each type of campaign. We then explore how these debates and concepts are affected by the reliance on new media. In the end, this helps us inquire into how political campaigns are evolving (or not) in relation to new media, and how communication via new media impacts the political world.

• Critically reflect on the impact of new media in the political arena.

column1: In this course students are introduced to various advanced marketing research techniques.
In marketing, often rich data are available in customer databases or in reviews and blogs on the web. The techniques introduced in this course enable firms to transform these data into knowledge.
At the same time little information is available about consumer preferences for new products. In these cases efficient data collection and analysis are needed to obtain knowledge at low cost.

Students will develop a deeper understanding of the techniques introduced in the course. They will also learn how to design and analyze conjoint choice experiments to study consumer preferences. Finally, they will learn how to present consumer preference research results and to evaluate and interpret the outcomes of such research.

• Students will learn how to design and analyze conjoint choice experiments to study consumer preferences.
• Students will practice how to present consumer preference research results and to evaluate and interpret the outcomes of such research.
• Students will practice writing a team research report.

column2: <title></title>

column1: Companies and institutions are often surprised when confronted with the variation of judgements and decisions of their members and employees. For instance, sales forecast, performance ratings and hiring proposals will often vary greatly between individuals. In most cases, this variation is considered noise, i.e. unwanted variation around the true value, that is risking the quality of managers decision processes. To reduce noise, however, the sources of variation must first be identified to second, implement tactics to reduce variation. In contrast to that, most companies are not even aware about the amount of noise in their processes.

In this course, we will study different sources of noise in human judgement and decision making. We will understand differences between stable, e.g. a manager that always gives a more lenient evaluation, and random, e.g. managers will not always enter precisely the same numbers, sources of variation and learn techniques to reveal the amount of noise and diminish noise if desired. To that goal, the course discusses theories of judgment and decision making, statistical models of choice and judgment, and their managerial implications.

Accordingly, the background literature is spread across psychology, marketing and economics but mostly related to the recently published book NOISE by Nobel laureate Daniel Kahneman, Olivier Sibony and Cass Sunstein.

The course consists of two sessions per week. One of these sessions is a more theory heavy lecture with a short discussion and clarification questions. The second session is a more interactive workshop. Here students are asked to implement or experience the newly gained knowledge, also with the statistical programming language R. No prior knowledge of R is required to take the course, but some experience is advantageous.
The R workshops are designed to make them maximally useful for your Master theses!
Attendance is not forced but getting an excellent grade in the final assignment will be difficult without attending the course. Participation in class is part of the grade.

• Being able to implement a line search algorithm to approximate the minimum of a continuous function (if it cannot be found analytically).
• Explain what the different options for line search are.
• Prove what the minimum is of a continuous function on an algebraic set.
• Explain what types of algorithms are used in practice to solve continuous optimisation problems.
• Determine the dual of a continuous optimisation problem.
• Create logically valid theoretical proofs in the context of non-linear optimisation.
• Implement simple algorithms in a high-level programming language.

column1: In many industries the dynamics of competition are constantly changing as a result of technological innovations and new business models. While some companies manage to adapt to new developments, many previously successful companies fail to do so and lose their competitiveness. What differentiates these two groups of companies? This course focuses on how companies can successfully adapt their offerings and business models to the changing competitive landscape. We will first examine why once-great companies could not sustain their competitiveness despite their established positions in their industries. We will then focus on two important capabilities to strategically change a business: to adopt new business models by re-organizing existing competencies in innovative ways, and to locate and benefit from new knowledge outside the company to develop new competencies. We will then analyze how leaders can influence the success or failure of strategic change. This course allows students to acquire relevant knowledge about navigating an increasingly complex competitive landscape and to apply it through case discussions and group exercises. Throughout the course there will be a healthy mix of theory and its application in real-life cases.</body>

column1: After finishing this course students will be able to:

column2: • Analyze why previously successful companies fail to sustain their competitiveness in the wake of new technological and/or business model innovations;
• Develop ideas to revise a company’s business model to leverage its core competencies in innovative ways;
• Appraise the value of external knowledge for innovation and identify appropriate sources for valuable external knowledge;
• Define a company`s innovation ecosystem and describe the role of complementary external parties in developing new strategies to maintain competitive advantage;
• Select appropriate leadership practices to guide a company through strategic change;
• Analyze: (a) developments that change the dynamics of competition; and (b) ideas to leverage the core competencies of the firm in innovative ways;
• Create, evaluate and make decisions about options for new strategies and business models to: (a) respond to changing dynamics of competition; and (b) leverage core competencies.

column1: Strategic management is a discipline at the forefront of business research and practice. In this advanced course on strategic management, focus is particularly on what is perhaps the most pressing issue for practicing managers: how can I make my firm outperform its competitors? To formulate such value-creating strategies, managers must identify a suitable business model, formulate strategies, identify core capabilities, learn from their and others’ experiences, and develop new ways of outcompeting their rivals. Firms also must increasingly navigate more complex environments such as business ecosystems as well respond to rapid technological innovations, such as for example new digital technologies. Typically, managers must make such choices and formulate their strategies in conditions of uncertainty or ambiguity. To develop such a holistic view on business, students in this course will be exposed to the key aspects and challenges of putting in place a system that delivers and captures value under such conditions.

The emphasis does not lay on identifying the “right” answer. Instead, the focus of this course is on creating a learning environment that stimulates students’ critical engagement with the study material. Teaching methods therefore include a combination of lectures, group assignments, and online quizzes. To develop their knowledge, skills, and attitudes, students will read articles from leading academic and managerial journal as well as analyze business cases. Students must prepare the assigned material prior to each class to be able to be able to contribute to the interactive classroom discussions as well as being able to complete the group assignments. To support students learning experience, the instructor will be available for questions during these assignments.</body>

• to evaluate what capabilities influence firms’ ability to successfully outperform their competitors in dynamic industries; and
• to formulate potential solutions to a key strategic problem to the satisfaction of a real-world company.

</style>

column1: Positioning: In contrast to business-level strategy, which is about the question how firms can secure a competitive advantage in a single product or service market, corporate strategy is about corporate advantage and the question how firms can secure advantages from different business activities being incorporated into a single business entity: a corporation. While the Corporate Growth and Development (BM03SM) course focuses mostly on the question how to optimally manage (potential) synergies between different business activities and resources by growing or acquiring/merging them into a single corporate entity, the Corporate Ownership and Governance course (BM04SM) will focus more on the question how to understand and manage the governance costs that result from managing (different) business activities, or business models within the boundaries of a single corporate entity. As such, this course confers the concepts, theoretical frameworks, empirical knowledge, as well as the analytical skills and critical attitudes that are required to evaluate the ownership and governance of firms, with the ultimate objective of learning how to develop the ownership and governance strategy for a firm as a critical component of its overall corporate strategy.

Substantial focus: Corporate governance is about ‘the rules of the game’ within which firms develop and exploit their resources and undertake business activities to create and appropriate value. These ‘rules of the game’ are shaped both at the country level (e.g. markets, laws, culture) and at the level of the firm (e.g. ownership, the board, alliances, etc.), at which level they are most flexible. At the firm level, these rules of the game include the ownership of the firm, its basic decision-making structures and practices, as well as the accountability structures and practices through which those who make and/or execute decisions can be held accountable by those bearing residual risk from those decisions. In publicly listed firms, for example, executives make the bulk of everyday decisions, while dispersed and therefore mostly uninvolved shareholders (as well as other stakeholders) bear the risks that result from them. This has traditionally made the question how dispersed, and uninvolved shareholders can secure maximal returns from the firm a central corporate governance challenge for publicly listed firms. A striking fact about economic reality, however, is that there do not just exist publicly listed firms, but many different forms of ownership, such as: partnerships, cooperatives, family firms, state-owned firms, and non-profit organizations, that each dominate specific industries, such as accounting, agriculture, defense, higher education, and healthcare, for example. These different forms of ownership face their own distinctive corporate governance challenges, and will therefore need to develop a set of equally distinctive set of corporate governance structures and practices to meet these challenges. As a result, there does not exist any single corporate governance model that is suitable for all firms.

Overarching aim: Given that is there exists no best single solution to questions of corporate ownership and governance, the overarching aim of this course is to develop a strategic understanding of corporate ownership and governance. In this view, the ultimate aim of corporate ownership and governance is to align the firm’s ownership, decision-making, and accountability structures and practices, on the one hand, with its strategy, core activities, key resources, and critical resource dependencies, on the other. In order to develop a strategic understanding of corporate governance, we will discuss various forms of ownership, such as publicly listed firms, (professional) partnerships, family firms, and new ventures, for example, in order to explore a variety of corporate governance structures and practices that can be implemented to meet these challenges. Because the ownership of the firm generally involves the most fundamental ‘governance choice’ to be made, we will begin by discussing the costs and benefits of different forms of ownership and the specific governance challenges that arise from them. We will also discuss the stakeholders of the firm, however, as well as the governance practices that firms can implement to secure stakeholders’ continued involvement in, or support for, the firm. Finally, we will explore how firms can secure their societal license to operate, because firms as institutions of private ordering, and only exist and function within an institutional context that partly comprised of public ordering (e.g. the state, the law, society, etc).

column1: As the overarching aim of this course is to develop a strategic understanding of the ownership and governance of firms, the course seeks to develop a thorough understanding of the concepts and theories that can be used to strategically analyze questions of ownership and governance of firms, as well as the research (including methods) and available empirical evidence in support of these theories and conceptual frameworks. Because questions about the ownership and governance of firms cannot be resolved in any simple mathematical or deterministic way, the learning goal is not to know everything discussed in every reading or every lecture by heart. Instead, the main pedagogical aim of the course is to develop a basic but thorough understanding of the concepts, theoretical frameworks, and knowledge about their empirical support that is required to analyze questions of ownership and governance at an academic level of professional competence (i.e., general and evidence-based). And because the study of ownership and governance is nothing like rocket science, the course also seeks to develop a critical attitude of students with respect to the concepts, theories, and research discussed, as well as some basic practical skills in applying the learnings of this course. After successfully completing the course, therefore, students should master the following:

column2: • Identify and understand theoretical concepts and frameworks at the intersection of corporate strategy, corporate ownership, and corporate governance;
• Integrate theoretical insights, conceptual frameworks, and relevant empirical evidence that shape our understanding of the strategic ownership and governance choices of firms;
• Apply concepts, theoretical insights, and frameworks to real-life cases involving the development and implementation of a corporate ownership and governance strategy for firms;

• Collect, process, and analyze data required for critically evaluating a firms’ current ownership and governance practices in order to to develop the ownership and governance part of a firm’s overall corporate strategy;
• Analyze opportunities and challenges in developing strategic options for ownership and governance changes in firms;
• Understand and apply financial valuation methods at a basic level in corporate break-up scenarios;
• Develop the corporate ownership and governance part of the overall corporate strategy of a firm;

• Demonstrate an ability to work in teams on the skills assignments for this course, showcasing a basic level of competence in working with a high level and incomplete information in an effective and ethically responsible way.

column1: In today's world competitive advantages erode faster and faster. Globalization, technological development and industry convergence pressure organizations to put more emphasis on corporate strategy. Corporate strategy revolves around the 4 themes of boundaries, diversification, synergy, and innovation. Traditionally, corporate strategy involves the choice in which markets a company is active and managers decided mainly about diversification and resource allocation. These days corporate strategy also concerns leveraging resources across a company’s businesses to create both cost-reducing and value-enhancing synergies and to spur innovation. To get access to relevant resources they do not possess, firms increasingly look beyond their boundaries and seek to acquire and ally with organizations. Such corporate development decisions have become an essential activity of corporate strategy, making corporate development departments central units in many organizations.

The objective of this course is to help participants develop a conceptual and practical understanding of corporate strategy and the role of corporate development. After successfully completing the course, students will have to their availability a toolkit and skills that help them steer corporate strategy decisions. This includes tools to assess, transform and organize a corporate portfolio of businesses. It also includes tools to make a choice between acquisitions and alliances, and attention will be paid to the implications and managerial challenges alliances and acquisitions pose by addressing the levers of successfully creating value, selecting targets and partners, integrating acquisition targets and controlling alliances. Finally, in addition to accessing new resources through alliances and acquisitions, the shedding of resources through corporate divestments will be addressed. As part of the skills trajectory across the core courses, this course develops two important corporate skills: portfolio analysis and target valuation. Overall, the course develops state-of-the-art understanding of the risks and returns associated with corporate strategy and corporate development, and the managerial skills and capabilities needed to be successful.</body>

column1: In zowel wetenschappelijk (ortho)pedagogisch onderzoek als in de professionele praktijk is het gedegen kunnen observeren en registreren van interacties tussen kinderen en volwassenen van groot belang. Deze observaties vormen de basis voor allerlei wetenschappelijke conclusies en professionele (stappen tot) interventie. Kennis van verschillende observatie- en registratiemethoden en codeersystemen (zoals verschillende schalen en variatie in gedragsduur/intensiteit/frequentie), alsmede de voor- en nadelen van deze methoden en systemen is nodig voor een goed begrip van de interactiepatronen tussen volwassenen en kinderen. In dit practicum worden verschillende observatiemethoden en codeersystemen geschikt voor de kindertijd tot de adolescentie behandeld. Ook komen de ethische aspecten rond het gebruik van observaties aan bod en wordt de validiteit en betrouwbaarheid van observaties besproken. Het practicum wordt afgesloten met een eindverslag.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111072,2023,Occupational Health and Safety,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. D van der Linden'],,Inhoud
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit blok leer je de basis voor het ontwerpen en       organiseren       van       gezond       en       veilig       werk.       Werk       is       een       belangrijke       spil       in       het       leven       van       veel       mensen.       Voor       de       meeste       mensen       geldt:       werken       maakt       gezond.       Behalve       bron       van       inkomsten,       kan       werk       regelmaat       en       uitdagingen       bieden,       uitzicht       op       sociaal       gewaardeerde       posities,       zelfontplooiing       en       leuke       collega’s.       Werk       kan       echter       ook       een       belangrijke       bron       van       stress       en       frustratie       zijn.       De       manier       waarop       het       werk       en       de       organisatie       zijn       vormgegeven       spelen       hierbij       een       minstens       zo       belangrijke       rol       als       de       cognities       en       het       gedrag       van       het       individu.       Uitgangspunt       voor       deze       cursus       is       daarom       dat       je       bij       het       ontwerpen       van       werk       in       eerste       instantie       moet       aansluiten       bij       de       capaciteiten       en       beperkingen       van       de       mens.       Verkeerd       ontworpen       functies       en       taken       kunnen       leiden       tot       fysieke       en       cognitieve       overbelasting,       vermoeidheid,       fouten,       en       op       de       lange       termijn       tot       gezondheidsgevolgen       zoals       burnout.

Dit blok       biedt       inzicht       in       deze       problematiek       vanuit       verschillende       psychologische       invalshoeken,       zoals       de       gezondheidspsychologie       (bijv.       psychosociale       voorspellers       van       gezondheid       en       welbevinden),       cognitieve       psychologie       (bijv.       aandacht       en       perceptie,       en       de       koppeling       tussen       perceptie       en       actie)       en       de       sociale       psychologie       (bijv.       groepsklimaat).       Een       belangrijke       vraag       hierbij       is       wat       deze       wetenschappelijke       inzichten       betekenen       voor       de       praktijk.       Onderwerpen       die       aan       bod       komen       zijn       bijvoorbeeld       functieanalyse       en       taak(her)ontwerp.       Ook       is       er       aandacht       voor       het       ontwerpen       van       interventies       op       het       werk,       gericht       op       het       verbeteren       van       de       veiligheid       en       gezondheid       van       werknemers.
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Dit blok is een verdieping in de Arbeids- en     Organisatiepsychologie.     Het     biedt     studenten     een     psychologisch     kader     voor     het     analyseren     en     (her)ontwerpen     van     arbeidstaken     en     de     psychosociale     werkomgeving,     gericht     op     het     bevorderen     van     de     gezondheid     en     veiligheid     van     het     bedrijf     en     zijn     werknemers.

<body>In een interactief Hoor-Werkcollege onderzoeken we vigerende opvattingen van gezondheid en ziekte, lichamelijkheid en sterfelijkheid binnen de geneeskunde, alsook de filosofie aan de hand van werk van o.a. Lingma, Nordenfelt en Slatman. Tevens reflecteren we op de evt. beperkingen van die opvattingen en exploreren we het belang van andere perspectieven (met name het verschil tussen het eerste en het derde persoons perspectief), o.m. aan de hand van het werk van Nietzsche, Heidegger en Carel.</body>

column1: De omzetbelasting (btw) is een verbruiksbelasting die beoogt de particuliere consumptie te belasten. Daarmee heeft deze belasting een ander karakter dan belastingen op winst en inkomen, zoals de vennootschapsbelasting en inkomstenbelasting. De belasting wordt geheven via de ondernemers die btw aan hun afnemers in rekening brengen en die de btw op aangifte voldoen. Uiteindelijk drukt de belasting echter bij de consument.

Als geen andere Nederlandse belasting is de omzetbelasting binnen de Europese Unie sterk geharmoniseerd. In dat kader zal bij de behandeling van de Wet op de omzetbelasting 1968 de relatie worden gelegd met de EU-richtlijnen die zijn voortgevloeid uit het harmonisatieproces. Na een behandeling van de verschillende methoden om een verbruiksbelasting te heffen wordt de aandacht met name gericht op de Wet op de omzetbelasting 1968.
Aan de orde komen onder meer:

column2: • Het ondernemersbegrip als belastingplichtige:
• De leveringen en diensten als belastingobject en de plaats van handeling:
• De wijze van heffing, waarbij in het bijzonder aandacht wordt besteed aan de maatstaf van heffing, de vrijstellingen en aftrek van voorbelasting:
• Intracommunautaire transacties.

column1: De heffing van omzetbelasting over onroerende zaken wordt niet behandeld. Deze problematiek komt aan de orde in FEB43008-Belastingheffing op onroerende zaken.

column1: De omzetbelasting (btw) is een verbruiksbelasting die beoogt de particuliere consumptie te belasten. Daarmee heeft deze belasting een ander karakter dan belastingen op winst en inkomen, zoals de vennootschapsbelasting en inkomstenbelasting.
De belasting wordt geheven via de ondernemers die btw aan hun afnemers in rekening brengen en die de btw op aangifte voldoen. Uiteindelijk drukt de belasting echter bij de consument.

Als geen andere Nederlandse belasting wordt de omzetbelasting beheerst door Europese regelgeving. De uitlegging daarvan vormt een belangrijk aspect bij de toepassing van de nationale wetgeving inzake de omzetbelasting.

In dit blok wordt gestart met een introductie tot het Europese btw-systeem waarbij wordt beoogd, naast het rechtskarakter, de feitelijke werking van dit systeem duidelijk te maken. Het is belangrijk de werking en Europese context van de btw goed te doorgronden omdat dit een rode draad vormt voor de rest van het blok. Na deze introductie komen kernbegrippen aan de orde zoals het ondernemersbegrip en de heffing bij grensoverschrijdende leveringen en diensten binnen de Europese Unie (EU).

Bij deze laatste speelt de mogelijke verlegging van de heffing naar de afnemer een belangrijke rol. Later in het blok komen ook nog btw-verleggingsregelingen bij binnenlandse transacties aan de orde, zoals de verleggingsregeling in de bouwsector.

Gaande het blok worden meer specifieke onderwerpen behandeld. Ten eerste de complexe regelgeving voor transacties met betrekking tot onroerende zaken en de daarbij voorkomende samenloop met de heffing van de overdrachtsbelasting.

Vervolgens de verschillende vrijstellingen en de gevolgen die deze hebben voor de btw-aftrek bij de ondernemer. Andere uitsluitingsgronden voor aftrek, die zijn ingegeven door het consumptief karakter van bepaalde zakelijke uitgaven, komen daarna aan de orde.
Daarbij wordt ook aandacht besteed aan de formele eisen die de wet aan aftrek stelt.

Ten slotte wordt aandacht besteed aan de btw-heffing ter zake van in- en uitvoer. De handel met niet-EU landen geeft aanleiding tot restitutie van btw bij uitvoer, maar anderzijds heffing bij invoer. Met deze heffing wordt beoogd ingevoerde goederen
op dezelfde wijze te belasten als goederen die binnen de EU zijn voortgebracht. De werking van btw bij invoer wordt met een viertal situaties geïllustreerd.

In deze cursus wordt de stof in eerste instantie benaderd vanuit de nationale regelgeving. Omdat de nationale bepalingen moeten worden uitgelegd in het licht van de richtlijnbepalingen, wordt de Europese regelgeving en jurisprudentie behandeld voor zover dit relevant is voor deze interpretatie.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Ben je op de hoogte van de beginselen van de indirecte verbruiksbelasting, begrijp je het rechtskarakter en de werking van het btw-systeem, en ken je de Europeesrechtelijke grondslagen en de (Europese) rechtsgang.
• Ken je de verschillende tarieven en begrijp je de rol die deze binnen het btw-systeem vervullen.
• Ben je op de hoogte van de begrippen levering en dienst, waaronder de fictieve leveringen en diensten.
• Ken je de werking van de btw bij grensoverschrijdende transacties binnen de EU, waaronder de afstandsverkopen en de positie van ‘gelijkgestelden’ en kun je dit toepassen op een casus.
• Kun je beoordelen of een (rechts-)persoon al dan niet ondernemer is voor de btw en kun je beoordelen of overheidslichamen in specifieke omstandigheden ondernemer zijn.
• Weet je wanneer het ondernemerschap aanvangt en eindigt.
• Kun je de criteria van de fiscale eenheid toepassen op een casus.
• Ken je de regels voor aftrek van voorbelasting en de materiële en formele beperkingen die daarbij gelden, waaronder het Besluit Uitsluiting aftrek, en kun je hiermee een casus oplossen.
• Ken je de formele gevolgen van de btw-plicht zoals facturering, eisen die gelden voor de factuur, verschuldigdheid en wijze van afdracht.

• Ben je op de hoogte van de vrijstellingen (inclusief de voorwaarden die daaraan verbonden zijn) en kun je deze situaties herkennen in een casus, waarbij je de impact van vrijstellingen begrijpt ten aanzien van de aftrek van voorbelasting.
• Leer je de regels kennen voor de heffing van btw en overdrachtsbelasting bij onroerend goed transacties en kun je deze toepassen op een casus.
• Ken je de specifieke regelingen zoals de landbouwregeling, de margeregeling, veilingregeling, en kun je deze in een casus herkennen en toepassen.

• Ben je op de hoogte van de specifieke regels voor heffing bij in- en uitvoer en kun je deze in specifieke situaties toepassen, zoals bij op zee verkochte goederen en vervoer tot eerste plaats van bestemming.
• Beschik je over kennis ten aanzien van de begrippen btw- en douane-entrepot.

column1: De omzetbelasting (btw) is een verbruiksbelasting die beoogt de particuliere consumptie te belasten. Daarmee heeft deze belasting een ander karakter dan belastingen op winst en inkomen, zoals de vennootschapsbelasting en inkomstenbelasting.
De belasting wordt geheven via de ondernemers die btw aan hun afnemers in rekening brengen en die de btw op aangifte voldoen. Uiteindelijk drukt de belasting echter bij de consument.

Als geen andere Nederlandse belasting wordt de omzetbelasting beheerst door Europese regelgeving. De uitlegging daarvan vormt een belangrijk aspect bij de toepassing van de nationale wetgeving inzake de omzetbelasting.

column1: Unsure about where to be? Where to find information about your classes? Curious to meet your fellow students? Stuck with questions about what to expect? In that case you can sign up for the ESE Onboarding and kick start your master’s programme. This Onboarding offers a live session on campus with a mentor where you can ask your questions and where you will get to know some of your fellow students, the school, and the university. Students are also offered the opportunity to have one or more individual meetings with their mentor to ask questions and discuss their expectations. You can also browse through the online onboarding modules to learn about the digital systems ESE uses. By signing up and attending the ESE Onboarding you will be completely set to start your classes with all the right information!
