https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116774,2023,Organizations & natural environment,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. JS Lodge'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Across the globe the natural environment is in an increasingly precarious state. In many natural environment areas, humanity has already crossed the boundaries leading to an increased risk of generating large-scale abrupt or irreversible environmental changes.

Organizations – entities comprising one or more individuals with a particular purpose – such as businesses, institutions, or associations across many different sectors and in various forms have been shown to play a role in this development. How they behave can have substantial implications for the natural environment around us.

But how exactly are organizations and the natural environment related? What implications do organizational actions have for the natural environment, and the natural environment for organizations? And how do organizations respond to and manage their relationship with the natural environment?

In this elective we consciously move beyond the frequently and broadly discussed topic of climate change and pay particular attention to a range of extremely important yet often less examined natural environment topics, including the themes of water, (chemical) pollution, and biodiversity (loss).

In so doing, the aim is to extend your understanding of natural environment issues in and around organizations and to enable you to have informed managerial conversations on an array of natural environment issues in your roles as future organizational leaders. Further, this course will also develop your skillset by getting you to learn about and then apply a range of tools to assess natural environment issues.
Students are expected to attend all sessions.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Explain how organizations and the natural environment are connected holistically
• Analyze the challenges and opportunities for organizations attempting to integrate natural environment issues
• Apply natural environment analytical tools in order to make informed organizational decisions
• Evaluate different organizational approaches and strategies for addressing natural environment topics

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112062,2023,Organizing for technological transformation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. PA Distel'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Technological change (e.g., new advancements in Artificial Intelligence or the development of mRNA technology for the treatment of diseases) leads to major challenges and opportunities for firms in different industries. In recent years, the investments in industrial research and development (R&D) have increased in many sectors. To provide a beneficial organizational context for the exploration, assimilation, retention, and exploitation of new technological knowledge, firms need to consider specific organizational and management concepts, which are addressed in detail in this course.

The students gain detailed knowledge about fundamental issues concerning strategies, organizational capabilities, and organizational designs with respect to technological change. Among other aspects, the course addresses organizational issues related to technology forecasting, timing of entry, overcoming resistance to change, firm adaptability and agility, R&D processes and structures, absorption of new external knowledge, as well as external commercialization of internally created technologies.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Understand why and how some companies survive technological changes, while others do not, using concepts from strategic technology management.
• Apply theoretical frameworks related to the exploration, assimilation, and exploitation of new technological knowledge to solve real company case problems associated with strategic challenges.
• Judge various organizational and management dimensions of technological transformation and agility in businesses based on scientific and practical insights.
• Analyze the effects of different organizational design elements on companies’ technological transformations.
• Develop strategies for companies to take advantage of technological disruptions based on relevant concepts and case studies.
• Produce own insights from real-life examples to extend or modify concepts and tools related to the management of technological change.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112657,2023,Oriëntatie op het onderwijs-beroepsveld,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. LAL de Meijer'],,Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: De pedagogische praktijk is breed en omvat onder meer het onderwijs, de jeugdhulp en de (preventieve) opvoedondersteuning. Pedagogische vraagstukken die hier spelen zijn bijvoorbeeld: ‘Hoe zorg je ervoor dat ieder kind, ongeacht achtergrond en talent en vanuit zijn of haar individuele behoeften, passend onderwijs en zorg krijgt?’ En ‘hoe vergroot je de betrokkenheid van opvoeders bij het onderwijs van hun kind?’ Deze vraagstukken kenmerken zich vaak door (a) complexiteit en (b) diversiteit. Bij het zoeken naar mogelijke oplossingen voor deze vraagstukken dienen we daarom met verschillende factoren rekening te houden, waaronder: hoe de verschillende systemen rondom een kind (school, gezin, wijk) met elkaar samenhangen; met ethische en juridische kaders; met persoonlijke opvattingen en overtuigingen over de rol van onderwijs en opvoeding; en met onze eigen normen, waarden en (voor)oordelen.

In het vak ‘oriëntatie op het onderwijs-beroepenveld’ maak je allereerst kennis met actuele pedagogische vraagstukken, die je (ook) in het onderwijsveld kunt tegenkomen. Daarbij leer je over het handelen volgens de beroepscode van pedagogen en onderwijswetenschappers, rekening houdend met juridische en ethische kaders.

Als academische Pabo-student leiden wij je op tot academische leerkracht in het basisonderwijs, waarbij je de opgedane pedagogische en onderwijswetenschappelijke kennis en vaardigheden toepast in het (grootstedelijke) onderwijs-beroepenveld. Voor je ontwikkeling als professional is het essentieel dat je inzicht verkrijgt in en bewust wordt van je eigen normen, waarden, vooroordelen, visie en competenties (i.e. het handelen).

In dit vak besteden we dan ook aandacht aan je professionele identiteitsontwikkeling. We doen dit door je (1) (nogmaals) voorlichting te geven over de specialisaties van de opleiding Pedagogische Wetenschappen; (2) een verkenning te laten maken van het eigen beeld van de rol die pedagogen en onderwijswetenschappers kunnen hebben in het onderwijs; (3) informatie te geven over mogelijke rollen van academische leraren in het onderwijs; en (4) te laten reflecteren op het ontstane zelfbeeld en toekomstperspectief op de toekomstige rol.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Aan het einde van dit vak zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • Juridische bronnen te gebruiken en te interpreteren voor juridische en beroepsethische kwesties in de (ortho)pedagogische praktijk; (MC test)
• De beroepscode voor pedagogen en Nederlandse wetgeving toe te passen op (ortho)pedagogische casussen; (MC-test)
• Te reflecteren op voor een pedagoog belangrijke beroepsethische kwesties; (Formatieve opdracht)
• Te beschrijven hoe de structuur van het (ortho)pedagogische en onderwijswerkveld is vormgegeven; (Formatieve opdracht)
• Inzicht te krijgen in en te reflecteren op eigen stereotypen en (voor)oordelen; (Formatieve opdracht)
• Inzicht te krijgen in de eigen visie, normen en waarden als pedagogisch professional; (Formatieve opdracht)
• Op een opbouwende professionele feedback te geven aan en te ontvangen van medestudenten en docenten. (Formatieve opdracht)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111228,2023,Orthopedagogiek: Stoornissen bij kinderen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['A Vreeker', 'dr. NK Schoemaker']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Blok 2.7 is het logisch vervolg op blok 1.6 Orthopedagogiek I. In Blok 1.6 heb je kennis gemaakt met de discipline van de Orthopedagogiek als oorspronkelijk handelingswetenschap en tegenwoordig steeds meer als empirische wetenschap. Daarnaast ben je bekend met de grondleggers en werkvelden van de orthopedagogische praktijk en het gebruik van de diverse cycli bij theorievorming, diagnostiek en hulpverlening door orthopedagogen. Blok 2.7 is een verbreding en verdieping van orthopedagogische kennis en handelen met als centraal thema stoornissen bij jeugdigen.

De primaire taak van orthopedagogen is opvoeders te ondersteunen in de opvoeding van hun kinderen zodanig dat kinderen zich optimaal kunnen ontwikkelen en ontplooien. Wanneer kinderen een ontwikkelings- of andere stoornis hebben, kan dit leiden tot een verzwaarde opvoedingsopgave of -last en rust er een zware verantwoordelijkheid op de schouders van de orthopedagoog om opvoeders (ouders, andere gezins- en familieleden, maar ook groepsleiders en leerkrachten) op wetenschappelijk onderbouwde en cultureel gepaste wijze te ondersteunen in hun opvoedingstaken.

In dit blok worden de meest voorkomende gedragsproblemen, ontwikkelingsstoornissen, persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en leerproblemen behandeld aan de hand van prevalentie, vermeende oorzaken vanuit diverse wetenschappelijke perspectieven, co-morbiditeit, prognose, (de geschiedenis van) diagnostiek en meest belangrijke of populaire vormen van behandeling of ondersteuning met betrekking tot deze problemen en stoornissen.

Kinderen met internaliserende en externaliserende gedragsproblemen (zoals angst, depressie, Conduct Disorder/ODD) en ontwikkelingsstoornissen (zoals Autisme Spectrum stoornissen, ADHD), persoonlijkheidsstoornissen (zoals borderline persoonlijkheidsstoornis) en leerproblemen (dyscalculie, dyslexie) staan centraal in dit blok. De focus ligt op het orthopedagogisch handelen. Er zal dus worden bekeken hoe zo’n probleem is ontstaan, wat dit betekent voor het kind, voor de ouders en voor de directe leefomgeving van het kind en hoe, vanuit een orthopedagogisch perspectief, het kind, zijn/haar gezin en de bredere sociale omgeving ondersteund kunnen worden.

Naast de blokken 2.6 en 2.8 maak je in dit blok kennis met de vraagstukken waar pedagogen en onderwijswetenschappers in de beroepspraktijk voor staan en welke instrumenten en interventies daar veelal bij gebruikt worden.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • een beschrijving te geven van kenmerken, prevalentie, prognose, co-morbiditeit van ontwikkelingsstoornissen, (internaliserende en externaliserende) gedragsproblemen, persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en leerproblemen en deze stoornissen/problemen onderling te vergelijken (eindtermen 3 en 5);

• de meeste belangrijke wetenschappelijke theorieën en verklaringen vanuit diverse perspectieven voor deze ontwikkelingsstoornissen, (internaliserende en externaliserende) gedragsproblemen, persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en leerproblemen te beschrijven en de daarmee verband houdende wetenschappelijke onderzoeken te beschrijven en deze theorieën en verklaringen over stoornissen/problemen heen te vergelijken (eindtermen 4 en 6);

• het proces van diagnostiek en hulpverlening aan de hand van de klinische cyclus te beschrijven en de bijbehorende theoretische modellen te kennen voor de eerder genoemde problematiek, waarbij oog is voor overeenkomsten en verschillen over problematieken heen (eindterm 5);

• voorgenoemde wetenschappelijke theorieën en verklaringen, onderzoeken en orthopedagogische toepassingen te evalueren op sterke en minder sterke (of ronduit zwakke) punten en –op basis hiervan- het geëvalueerde op wetenschappelijke, praktische waarde te beoordelen (eindtermen 6, 11 en 14).

column1: The winterschool consists of two days, focused on inter- & transdisciplinary research, transformative change and network analysis.

On the first day of the Winter School, we will focus on the differences between multidisciplinary, interdisciplinary, and transdisciplinary research, and how these methodologies relate to your own research. We will present both theory and small exercises to explore these methodologies.

To prepare for this day, we ask participants to investigate to what extent they use a multi-, inter-, or transdisciplinary approach in their own research. What are the experiences with this? Are there difficulties participants encounter? Is there something missing to successfully apply this?

During the morning program, an external speaker, along with the participants, will explore the theory behind multi- and interdisciplinary research. Participants will reflect on their own research projects and their role as researchers. Furthermore, we will present a case in which collaboration takes place with fellow PhD candidates in an interdisciplinary setting.

During the afternoon, the discussion will expand to transdisciplinary research. An external speaker will discuss the theory behind transdisciplinary research and demonstrate how this can be successfully implemented in participants' own projects. Additionally, obstacles and pitfalls of this approach will be discussed.

A brief presentation on the importance of transformative change in research. An external speaker will share insights into how transformative change can influence the academic world and why it is relevant to research. Breakout sessions in which participants learn practical tools and strategies to apply transformative change to a complex problem and in their specific research context. Sessions will be led by experts in change management and transformative research.
Using various formats, the PDPC network will be explored. Further development of content in collaboration with PDPC Next.

column2: <li>
Develop skills to integrate knowledge and methods from multiple disciplines into a cohesive framework that transcends disciplinary boundaries.
<li>
Explore different approaches to transformative research in case studies.
<li>
Connect with a growing network of diverse researchers to further your inspiration and capability to undertake research in collaboration with others.

column1: *the program may be subject to change.
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column1: An internship can help students to apply their theoretical knowledge as well as develop their professional attitude including skills, such as organizing, planning, analyzing data and professional collaboration with co-workers. This course offers students the opportunity to conduct an internship on a topic of their own interest. The practice-based internship allows students to replace one free elective course in the program with a full-time (or equivalent) internship centered around one of the themes taught in the MSc People, Organisations and Change. Any elective block may be selected.

The duration of the internship needs to be at least seven weeks (168 hours) of fulltime equivalent and needs to be conducted within the time period  end of January – mid August 2023. The internship can cover a longer period when conducted on a part-time basis or when the internship is longer than seven weeks. However, a minimum of 168 hours is expected and a maximum of 6 ECTS is credited.

This course offers the opportunity to do internships via different tracks; a practice-based, a research-based track or other learning opportunities. Students are themselves responsible for finding a company-based internship, while we can do our best to place students interested in a research-based internship on an ongoing project of the faculty. This can include a project that is offered by staff working on issues in human resources management, organizational change, organization theory and/or organizational behavior. For practice-based internships, a list of available internships can be found through the RSM Career Services. Students are also welcome to contact companies directly.

Please note that the internship and the thesis are entirely separate courses. While the internship and the thesis may be related, this is not a requirement nor it is advised by RSM. If the two are linked, the internship course will be assessed separately from the thesis itself and must contain another focus than the thesis. Please consult your thesis coach if you want to combine your internship with your thesis and take into account that RSM's take on this matter is to not combine an internship of any kind with the thesis.

THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR POC STUDENTS ONLY. To graduate you must complete at least two other POC program electives. The internship elective also does not pertain to a specialism. Students need to ensure that their other POC program electives are chosen based on a specialism if they want to obtain one. Students themselves are responsible for finding an internship.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111102,2023,Pain: Psychological factors and treatments,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['A Aslanidou, MSc', 'prof.dr. MJ Wieser']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Pain is an all-too-familiar problem and the most common reason that people see a physician. Pain is an adaptive process and serves an important purpose by alerting us to potential tissue damage and injuries and thereby inducing protective reactions. For a long time, pain was considered as a purely physical sensation and symptom of an underlying somatic disease. In the last decades, it has become clearer and clearer that pain is a psycho-biological experience including sensory and emotional components.

In this course, students will be introduced to the biological and psychological underpinnings of pain and experimental paradigms to investigate pain in the psychological laboratory. The main focus will be on psychological factors of pain such as the influence of emotions, attention, expectations (placebo-effect). Other topics of this course include phenomena such as phantom limb pain or chronification of pain and their underlying neurocognitive mechanisms. Furthermore, diagnostics of pain and different psychological treatment approaches will be discussed.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of this course is to increase students' knowledge of a topic, which has gained increased interest in Clinical Psychology in recent years: Pain and its modulation by psychological factors. The main goal is for students to learn about recent scientific insights into the neurobiological basis and psychological models of pain, its modulation by psychological factors, and (psychological) treatment methods.

column1: Nowadays, even mobile phones and tablets have multiple core central processing units (CPUs), as do have the simplest laptop and desktop PCs. Using their combined compute power, however, is not trivial. This is as true for the small systems, as well as (worlds) largest compute systems. In data science, making use efficiently of all compute power is a required skill that needs to be learned. In this course you will be taught how to have all cores take part in a single task, or to have each core working on its own share of the total task.

Many data scientists either run on MacOS or Linux on the desktop/laptop. Both these operating systems are, or are based on, UNIX. Furthermore, many researchers in the Netherlands make use of the national supercomputer clusters, Lisa and Snellius, at SURFsara. Like most other large shared computer systems in research, these systems have UNIX, or Linux, running as operating system. Therefore, during the course students will get hands-on experience with UNIX.

After practicing with UNIX, the different types of parallel programming will be taught with Python as programming language. Although C and Fortran are very common in high-performance computing (HPC), it is also possible to use parallelism in Python, the language of choice for many researchers in the data science field.

The contents of this course comprise a BASH (Unix shell) course, an introduction to Jupyter Notebooks and Numpy, and a programming course to learn how to work with different parallel modules and packages in Python. For the latter, the “Python Parallel Programming Cookbook” is used, which will be provided by the teacher.

• write parallel code in Python

column1: This seminar takes the ubiquity of digital media technologies as a starting point and aims to understand and explain how traditional roles of (media) audiences have changed. Although the Web2.0 enthusiasts are overtly positive about active user roles and applaud the online possibilities of user participation, others approach the activities of users with caution and skepticism. Some critics claim that self-publishing undermines our sense of what is true and what is false and corrupts our culture.

The central topic of this seminar is the reconfiguration of the traditional consumer/producer relationship in the online media domain. Theoretically, the approach is informed by different approaches. The Social Shaping of Technology perspective, the concept of spreadability and Uses and Gratifications theorizing provide prominent and specific interpretative focuses. In class, we will study and critically assess these different theoretical perspectives on participation.

The selection of compulsory literature contains sources that have attained a classical status (e.g., O’Reilly, 2005) and sources covering contemporary theoretical and practical developments. Cases are on purpose chosen from different periods aiming to advance theoretical understanding.

Students are expected to critically engage with the theoretical matter and actively participate in and contribute to an open and inspiring learning environment. Individual engagement is combined with team efforts through mini lectures, and poster presentations. The classroom is partially ‘flipped’ by means of quiz questions supplied on Canvas.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• The value of different theoretical perspectives on (participating) online media users.
• The value of empirical research on new media users.
• The ways in which scientific knowledge can be applied to a relevant case study.
• Analyze recent and future trends in new media usage.
• Reflect critically on the claims made by researchers and theorists from different perspectives.
• Take and defend different theoretical positions.
• Independently analyze an empirical case study.

column1: This course in the Politics & Society specialization focuses on the political relevance of different types of globalization for political parties, governments, and domestic and international policy. First, we focus on the new challenges that political parties face due to globalization. It inspires their reconsideration of actions, strategies, and guiding principles, poses threats to some of these, while it provides opportunities for other ones. Hotly debated topics that will be addressed in this course are questions such as whether globalization explains the rise of new populist parties, whether it leads to fragmentation of the party landscape, and whether it affects party ideologies. Second, contemporary governments have to deal with all abovementioned aspects and political corollaries of globalization. The general question is how governments behave in a globalized context. Governments and their constituting political parties increasingly have to navigate between the often conflicting demands of their constituency and international obligations, such as those stipulated by the European Union (EU). Do they, for instance, pursue a politics of austerity as agreed upon in response to the European financial and debt crises, and consequently reform the welfare state? And how do governments respond to other globalization-related issues, such as immigration and asylum applications? Do governments become less generous? And what role do party ideology, party competition, public opinion, and business interests play in the process?

Third, we discuss the increased impact of supranational organizations like the EU, transnational networks and civil society organizations on citizens and policies. How do citizens perceive the EU and what factors explain the differential support for EU integration across individuals and countries? Moreover, does public opinion and the changing party landscape affect the EU and its institutions as well?

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Differentiate among the types and aspects of globalization processes taking place;
• Explain social-scientific theories on how globalization influences party systems, party ideologies, and government behavior;
• Explain social-scientific theories on the way in which governments and policies related to global issues are influenced by tensions between domestic politics and international obligations;
• Apply the above-mentioned social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalization and politics to contemporary political phenomena;
• Discuss the similarities and differences between social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalization and politics;
• Critically reflect on social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalization and politics;
• Formulate theoretically informed hypotheses related to the impact of globalization on political institutions</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims to provide students with a thorough understanding of the underlying mechanisms of heart diseases. The students will be able to integrate the information acquired in other disciplines such as Life Support, Human Anatomy, and Human Physiology. The general approach to study the different diseases will include four essential components: cause/aetiology, mechanisms of development (pathogenesis), structural alterations of cells (morphologic changes), and the consequences of changes (clinical manifestations). During this course, students will also learn skills that will help them to structure the acquired knowledge in a clinical context.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The aim of this course is to acquire a basic knowledge of the pathology and pathogenesis of diseases affecting the heart. At the end of this course, you will:

column2: • have obtained fundamental knowledge about the pathology and pathogenesis of diseases within the domains of cardiology.
• describe, distinguish and analyze how specific diseases affect the function of the heart, disrupting the homeostasis of the organism (pathophysiology);
• explain why particular symptoms are presented in patients with these diseases;
• know how to apply diagnostic tools and clinical skills;
• distinguish and evaluate the different available therapeutic approaches for the various diseases.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, the students will distinguish essential principles in evaluating pulmonary complaints and patients. They will learn to recognize the cause/aetiology, mechanisms of development (pathogenesis), structural alterations of cells (morphologic changes), and the consequences of changes (clinical manifestations) of pulmonary diseases.

column1: In this course, we will study the pathology and pathogenesis of a selected set of diseases affecting nutrition and the gastrointestinal tract. Student will expand their knowledge of the physiology of the GI tract, pancreas and liver in health, and they will be able to describe the pathophysiological mechanisms leading to disease. They will recognise gastrointestinal signs and symptoms, gaining practical knowledge on how to treat a patient with GI complaints.

column1: In this course, the students will integrate the knowledge obtained in the previous Pathology and Pathogenesis courses. They will learn about the role of the endocrine system in maintaining homeostasis, and they will be able to describe how the secretion of hormones is regulated, and how disruption of the normal physiology can lead to different diseases. Finally, the students will develop the ability to evaluate, treat and monitor common endocrine disorders, and also familiarise themselves with less common endocrinological afflictions.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

</style>

column1: During the course ‘Patient Centred Care Delivery’ (PCCD) students will be taught the most important theories, systematic reviews and empirical findings regarding PCCD. PCCD has been on the healthcare agenda for decades and has received increased attention. The concept of patient-centredness has grown into an important dimension of high-quality healthcare. Organisations aim to deliver care that is patient-centred in order to improve patient outcomes. In healthcare, increasingly important are the patient’s perspective and involvement, shared decision-making and patient-reported outcomes. The literature advocating patient-centred approaches in healthcare is widespread and research has shown that PCCD can result in improved health, health behaviours, and quality of life of patients and their family/caregivers. However, the evidence remains inconclusive and many organisations and professionals remain unknowledgeable or struggle on how to improve PCCD. During this course we will focus on different dimensions of PCCD and its impact on patient outcomes, innovative solutions (e.g., integrated care programmes), the role of organisations/teams, neighbourhoods and communities, as well as the patient’s context.

Insight into the concept of PCCD will be provided, including different models, theories and definitions. Different innovative approaches to PCCD will be introduced as well as their impact on (patient) outcomes (Theme 1). Attention will be given to various forms of interactions between professionals and patients. We will focus on legal aspects of informed consent and shared decision-making (Theme 2). Behind every professional, there is a team that influences the quality of care delivery to patients. Nowadays, with an astonishing rise of chronically ill patients and patients with multimorbidity, professionals are dealing with patients with complex and multiple needs. These changing needs from acute to chronically ill patients ask for a different approach in care provision.  Interprofessional collaboration is needed to support the needs of these patients, which requires communication and coordination between professionals from various occupational backgrounds and a supportive team climate (Theme 3). In turn, effectiveness of these teams is influenced by the culture, structure and availability of resources within the larger organisation. Also, leadership affects interprofessional collaboration between professionals and in turn quality of care delivery to patients (Theme 4).

In order to create co-care delivery between professionals and patients, diversity in care delivery is needed. Just as professionals operate within a team and organisational context, patients are influenced by their individual/personal environment as well. For example, patients differ in their educational level, their ability to self-manage their well-being, and their way of coping with diseases or illnesses. Special attention will be given to the continuing rise of socioeconomic health inequalities and how culture influences effectiveness of care delivery (Theme 5). Patients are not only influenced by their individual/personal environment, but by the community context as well. The neighbourhood context plays an important role in (improving) healthy lifestyles or fostering active and healthy ageing in the community. We will discuss the role of neighbourhoods and innovative solutions in the community (e.g., community health nurses, collaboration between health, social care and informal networks) on PCCD and patient outcomes (Theme 6).
Language: Workgroups and field trip/session are in Dutch

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students are able to analyse important theories and conceptual models concerning PCCD

• Students are able to argue how the organisation of care delivery and interprofessional collaboration contribute to PCCD with the help of theories, models, and instruments from the scientific literature and innovative solutions in healthcare practice.
• Students are able to assess pros and cons of shared decision-making (SDM) compared to other medical decision-making models.

• Students are able to discuss transformations in healthcare delivery from acute to chronic care, which result in changing demands, roles and expectations of patients as well as different interactions between professionals and patients and different approaches to the organization of healthcare to improve PCCD.

• Students are able to defend that diversity in care delivery is needed to improve patient outcomes and enhance PCCD with the help of theories and empirical evidence about the influence of the patients’ context on the effectiveness of care delivery.

• Students are able to assess the role of neighbourhoods and communities in health (behaviours) and quality of life using different theories and models from the scientific literature and innovative solutions in healthcare practice.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Bij het creëren van een inclusief pedagogisch klimaat, speelt jouw pedagogisch handelen een belangrijke rol. Je hebt als leerkracht een voorbeeldrol. Je leeft inclusiviteit als het ware voor in de manier waarop jij met de kinderen en de groep omgaat. Je leert in het pedagogisch handelen deel van deze module elementen uit Deep Democracy en groepsdynamica in te zetten om verbondenheid in de groep te creëren. Je leert achtergronden van gedrag van leerlingen te verstaan en te begeleiden zodat een inclusief klimaat ontstaat waarin de acceptatie van iedere leerling centraal staat.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Je maakt een begin met het ontwikkelen van onzekerheidstolerantie. Je wordt je bewust van momenten van ‘het niet weten’ en ontdekt wat je dan kan doen (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & 1.2: Handelt met pedagogische tact).

• Je leert je verder verdiepen in de achtergronden van gedrag van leerlingen in de context van hun leefwereld en leert scherper gewaarworden wat jij zelf in interactie met hen ervaart en meebrengt (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & 1.3: Neemt de leefwerelden van de leerlingen mee in het pedagogisch handelen & 1.5: Baseert het handelen op een pedagogische opdracht).
• Je maakt kennis met de principes van Deep Democracy en probeert korte werkvormen uit in de praktijk (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111941,2023,Pedagogisch handelen onderdeel: Eigen opvattingen en impliciete bias,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['drs. H de Graaff', 'drs. M Galje, MA', 'MM Wentzel']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Aansluitend hierop leer je in deze periode in de pedagogisch handelen lijn om individuele leerlingen en interactieprocessen tussen leerlingen, en de leerlingen en de leraar te observeren en te analyseren. Je leert daarin aanknopingspunten te vinden voor het eigen pedagogisch handelen. Je maakt kennis met theorieën en instrumenten van reflectie. Je leert gedragspatronen te herkennen en je eigen aandeel hierin onderzoeken en maakt daarbij gebruik van de zogenaamde theorie U. Je wordt je bewust van de complexiteit van observaties en van je eigen verwachtingen en impliciete bias. Ook gaan we aan het werk met de Self Determination Theory (SDT). We maken een vertaling naar de praktijk: welke aanknopingspunten vind je in de SDT voor jouw pedagogisch handelen? Het perspectief van de psychologische basisbehoeften gaan je helpen beter af te stemmen op de behoeften van de kinderen.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Je kent de Self Determination Theory en kan deze in de praktijk gebruiken als observatiekader en reflectie instrument (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & indicator 1.2: Handelt met pedagogische tact).

• Je maakt kennis met Theorie U en leert deze te gebruiken als reflectie instrument. Je kent de centrale begrippen uit de theorie en kan deze bij jezelf herkennen en beschrijven (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & 1.2: Handelt met pedagogische tact & 1.4: Fungeert als rolmodel voor de leerlingen).

• Je leert patronen herkennen in pedagogische situaties, je (h)erkent je eigen aandeel hierin en experimenteert met het doorbreken van patronen en het uitbreiden van je handelingsrepertoire (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115189,2023,Pedagogisch handelen onderdeel: Klaar voor de start en wat daarvoor nodig is,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['RJ Zijderveld, MSc']",,"Leerdoelen

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Je kunt verantwoordelijkheid nemen en steun zoeken voor je eigen ontwikkeling, met oog voor de kwetsbaarheid van dit proces (Rol 3: Strategisch partner, Indicator 3.3: Toont leiderschap).

• Je experimenteert met manieren om steun te zoeken en steun te bieden in de pedagogische reflectie met studenten onderling en met de collega’s van je stageschool (Rol 3: Strategisch partner, Indicator 3.2: Werkt constructief samen met collega’s).

column1: <body>In het pedagogisch handelen onderdeel van deze periode draait het om de vragen: wie ben ik en wie zijn mijn leerlingen? Je onderzoekt je eigen levensloop en waarden en word je bewust van de invloed daarvan op je pedagogisch handelen. Je brengt jezelf mee als je met kinderen werkt, daarom is het goed te weten waar je vandaan komt en wat je belangrijk vindt. Ook verdiep je je in deze periode in de leefwereld van je toekomstige leerlingen. Hoe kun je je, vanuit wie jij bent en wat jij meeneemt, verbinden met de superdiversiteit in de doelgroep waar je mee gaat werken? In de PH-lijn gaan we ook op zoek naar de betekenis hiervan in de dagelijkse onderwijspraktijk. Wat zie je ervan terug in de dagelijkse praktijk op school? En voor welke vragen en dilemma’s staan jij en jouw collega’s op school?  Je schrijft de eerste versie van je pedagogische opdracht.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Je ontwikkelt een doorleefd beeld van de leefwereld van jouw toekomstige leerlingen en bent in staat dit te relateren aan jouw pedagogische opdracht (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.3: Neemt de leefwerelden van de leerlingen mee in het pedagogisch handelen).

• Je leert open en verbonden observeren en gesprekken te voeren. Je bent in staat om bij jezelf waar te nemen wat een geobserveerde situatie met je doet en wat daarvan de pedagogische betekenis is. Hier wordt ook aandacht aan besteedt in de onderzoekslijn (Rol 4: Onderzoeker, Indicator 4.1: Reflecteert en leert op basis van wetenschappelijke inzichten).

• Je hebt inzicht in jouw eigen achtergrond en biografie en bent je ervan bewust hoe dit jouw pedagogische opdracht en handelen beïnvloedt (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.4: Fungeert als rolmodel voor de leerlingen & 1.5: Baseert het handelen op een pedagogische opdracht).

• Je bent in staat om het thema diversiteit te analyseren vanuit jouw pedagogische verantwoordelijkheid (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.3: Neemt de leefwerelden van de leerlingen mee in het pedagogisch handelen).

Je leert je eigen mindset kennen en leert hoe je in de klas met de mindset en attributiestijl kunt werken (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & 1.2: Handelt met pedagogisch tact & 1.3: Neemt de leefwerelden van de leerlingen mee in het pedagogisch handelen).

• Je maakt kennis met begrippen als rekenangst en aangeleerde hulpeloosheid en wat de betekenis daarvan is voor jouw pedagogisch handelen (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat).

• Je breidt het didactisch coachen verder uit, je kunt bijdragen aan eigenaarschap van de leerlingen t.a.v. hun leerproces (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat).

column1: <body>In de pedagogisch handelen lijn staat tijdens deze module de vraag centraal: Wat is de pedagogische boodschap van de dingen die je doet en zegt? Je leert jouw taalgebruik en gespreksvaardigheid in te zetten om leerlingen te sterken en uit te dagen. Je maakt kennis met de concepten bemoediging en gedifferentieerde feedback (Beate Letschert). En je leert de basisbeginselen van didactisch coachen (Voerman en Faber) als instrument in de begeleiding van leerlingen.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Je krijgt zicht op je eigen attitudes rondom lees- en schrijfvaardigheid (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.3: Neemt de leefwerelden van de leerlingen mee in het pedagogisch handelen & 1.4: fungeert als een rolmodel voor de kinderen).

• Je maakt kennis met het concept bemoediging van Beate Letschert. Je leert signalen van ontmoediging bij kinderen en volwassen herkennen en weet wat deze mensen nodig hebben. Je kan vanuit het concept bemoediging je pedagogisch handelingsrepertoire uitbreiden en aanpassen op de behoefte van (ontmoedigde) leerlingen en ouders (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & 1.2: Handelt met pedagogisch tact & 1.3: Neemt de leefwerelden van de leerlingen mee in het pedagogisch handelen).

• Je wordt je bewust van de pedagogische betekenis van taal en taalgebruik en verschillende vormen van feedback en gespreksvoering (Rol: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & 1.2: Handelt met pedagogisch tact & 1.5: Baseert het handelen op een pedagogische opdracht).
• Je maakt kennis met de principes van didactisch coachen (Rol: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat).

column1: <body>Pedagogische opdracht in de praktijk: inspiratie uit verschillende onderwijspraktijken</body>

column2: <title></title>

• Je verbreedt je kijk op onderwijs door kennis te maken met verschillende onderwijsvormen in verschillende contexten (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & 1.5: Baseert het handelen op een pedagogische opdracht).

• Je leert je verhouden tot verschillende onderwijspraktijken/voorbeelden en daaruit te halen wat voor jouw praktijk relevant is. Je past het toe in je eigen handelen en/of gebruikt nieuwe inzichten om dat wat je al doet verder te onderbouwen (1.1, 1.2 en 1.5) (Rol 1: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.1: Bevordert een veilig en uitdagend leerklimaat & 1.2: Handelt met pedagogisch tact & 1.5: Baseert het handelen op een pedagogische opdracht).
• Je leert je openstellen voor inspiratie en wat je daarmee kan ten aan zien van je eigen pedagogische opdracht (Rol: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.5: Baseert het handelen op een pedagogische opdracht).

• Je maakt via praktijkvoorbeelden kennis met verschillende manieren om te werken aan de kerndoelen oriëntatie op mens & wereld en de doeldomeinen van Biesta (Rol: Pedagoog, Indicator 1.5: Baseert het handelen op een pedagogische opdracht).

column1: Most organizations today collect a wealth of data that could help people management become more evidence-based and impact-driven and, in turn, help employees live up to their full potential. However, few companies manage to use their people data to the benefit of business results. People Analytics could potentially fill this void.

People Analytics constitutes the analytic approach to and statistical analysis of Human Resource (HR) and workforce data for the benefit of employee performance and the organization’s return on investment in human capital. This phenomenon gained traction as a movement that could evolve the way we make decisions concerning people management. It seeks to add value to organizations by leveraging novel data sources, statistical techniques, and analytical processes – i.e., datasets, mindsets, skillsets, and toolsets.

In this course, you learn how People Analytics can be used to improve business outcomes and make better management decisions. Through a sequence of readings, lectures, cases, and experiential exercises, you learn what questions to ask, how to determine which methods to use, and how to communicate ideas effectively. This should not only help those who seek to become an HR professional, but should help you stand out as a manager in general.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Explain the various perspectives on what People Analytics entails and the value it could provide to the organization (POC Expert, Communicator)
• Design solutions to issues concerning human capital that build on Human Resource Information Systems (HRIS) and advanced statistical techniques (POC Expert, Critical Thinker)
• Critically evaluate ethical and legal issues in People Analytics research and practice (Positive Impact Agent, POC Expert)
• Convince practitioners and scholars of theoretically sound and practical recommendations, drawing from People Analytics (Communicator; Collaborator)

column1: What would you say if you could approach your own professional development and job search process with clarity of purpose (knowing what you want) and confidence about how to secure and succeed in job interviews?
The overall objective of this course is to provide you cutting-edge tools and methodologies to:

column2: <li>
Reflect on your professional development, including what makes you uniquely attractive as a job candidate
<li>
Help you figure out and decide what you want to do
<li>
Build a network of people eager to help you & conduct successful informational interviews
<li>
Find out about the less visible job opportunities
<li>
Secure job interviews
<li>
Pass job interviews with style

column1: To pass the course, you are expected to attend all 4 Lectures, not only because you will need the insights and concepts from class to complete your Assignments correctly, but also because classroom learning hinges on class discussions.

The professional development seminars by Dr. Kamila Moulaï are optional, but recommended if you would like to align yourself with your aspirations and shape the kind of success that resonates with you. They also allow you to complete two assignments that count toward passing the course. Note, however, that only limited seats are available, so registration for these seminars is required.

The 4 alumni sessions also require registration. To pass the course, you will need to attend at least one alumni session, though we strongly recommend you to attend as many sessions as possible.  Please direct all your questions about the alumni sessions to Janneke Batenburg-Suijker at jbatenburg@rsm.nl.

• Formulate their career aspirations on a basic level
• Talk about themselves and their experiences effectively in recruiting contexts
• Build and engage professional networks to identify career opportunities
• Develop job interview strategies and execute them

column1: For most students, the start of their first year of university is an interesting, but hectic period. Not only will you face new exciting experiences, you may also encounter more demanding responsibilities than before. You are faced with the challenge of choosing a career path and how to develop yourself professionally, as well as the challenge of balancing your new responsibilities with different aspects of your life. To promote the attitudes and skills that help you to become more resilient to life’s demands and to develop yourself in various domains, EUC offers its students the Personal Development Track (PDT). The aim of this track is precisely to help you through the process of self-development.

column1: In this course students apply their skills from the core course and the ""reflective bootcamp"" to improve on their personal development and their entrepreneurial competencies in particular. Students do so in small groups. They further extend knowledge, skills and attitudes from the core courses to develop into their better entrepreneurial selves.
Attendance for online and offline sessions is mandatory. If more than one session is missed, the student cannot finish the course, unless major reasons are confirmed via study advisor.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Know and understand the basic strands of strategic entrepreneurship theories
• Know and apply the RSM roles and competencies to own and mutual personal development
• Engage in reflective personal growth
• Define personal mission, vision, core values, goals and habits
• Develop initial self-awareness of entrepreneurial skills and areas for improvement
• Help others in developing their entrepreneurial skills and mission
• Show resilience and persistence in learning (growth mindset)
• Take responsible and reliable actions with empathy for others
• Be creative, impact-driven and open-minded

column1: In this 2-day course you will create awareness about yourself and how to be most effective as a professional in life and work. Time management is often a very difficult aspect of research. How do you prioritize and how do you communicate about that with others, such as your supervisor, colleagues and team members? Whether it is in cooperation or in negotiation or even in conflict situations, it’s good to know yourself and optimize your strengths and be honest about your weaknesses.

In this training we will work on personal effectiveness, negotiation skills, communication skills, giving and receiving feedback to all colleagues (supervisor, students) and how to plan your daily, weekly, monthly schedules in order to finish your PhD project on time. Therefore, we look at the most effective way of planning your research project and use the rules of project management.
This practical 2-day course has a pre-assignment and a homework assignment in between (2 weeks) where you work on a few assignments individually and prepare a case together with other participants.

column2: • How to prioritize and practice daily, weekly planning.
• Negotiate and create awareness about the importance of your own goals.
• Insights in communication styles and how to adapt and connect with others.
• Conversations and communication skills. Discuss the process with your supervisor. How to give and receive feedback?
• FeedBack and Communication. Giving feedback to students and colleagues.
• Planning, time and project management

column1: *The program may be subject to change.
Pre-assignment – The Pre-assignment is mandatory for this course
Participants of this course are required to do a pre-assignment as intake for the course. Please find information about the pre-assignment here.

This pre-assignment needs to be performed and sent to rosemarie@smitbertens.nl one week prior to the start date of the course. Participants who fail to submit or submit the pre-assignment after the deadline will be excluded from the course. Please note that the cancellation policy will apply.

Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.
Assignment – The assignments are mandatory for this course
One week after the end of the course, your assignment and attendance will be registered in OSIRIS as PA (=completed), NO (=not completed) or O (=fail).

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column1: This course focuses on personality pathology. Personality disorders are defined by the DSM-V and can be divided into three broad clusters. Cluster A includes the paranoid, schizoid and schizotypal personality disorders, cluster B includes the antisocial, borderline, histrionic and narcissistic personality disorders, and cluster C includes the avoidant, dependent, and obsessive-compulsive personality disorders. During the course we will look at the clinical picture and the aetiology of the different personality disorders, consider differential diagnoses, and discuss the most important therapy models (i.e., MBT, SFT, TFP, DBT), including but not limited to individual therapy, group therapy and arts therapy. In addition to that, this course will discuss suicidal behavior, a common issue when treating people suffering from personality pathology.
This course's course assignment will involve a psychodiagnostic self-assessment and will motivate you to take a closer look at how you view yourself, others and the world.</body>

column1: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt;Aan het eind van dit blok, heb je substantiële kennis van het klinisch beeld, de prevalentie, de etiologie, de diagnostiek en de behandeling van:
Verder doe je veel kennis op over:
•thema’s zoals afweer, overdracht en tegenoverdracht binnen de behandeling
•psychodiagnostische meetinstrumenten om persoonlijkheidsstoornissen vast te stellen
•de mate waarin persoonlijkheidsstoornissen veranderd kunnen worden
•verschillende therapievormen om persoonlijkheidsstoornissen te behandelen en hun effectiviteit
•je eigen (dis)functionele schema’s en hoe deze jouw kijk als persoon en toekomstig therapeut op de wereld om je heen kunnen beïnvloeden
At the end of this course, you will have substantial knowledge of the clinical picture, prevalence, aetiology, diagnosis and treatment of
In addition, you will be able to:
• distinguish between personality traits and personality disorders;
• explain issues such as defense mechanisms, transference and countertransference within treatment;
• select psychodiagnostic measurement tools for identifying personality disorders;
• discuss the extent to which personality disorders can be changed;
• describe various forms of therapy for treating personality disorders and suicidality;
• analyse your own (dys)functional schemas and indicate how these can influence your view of the world as an individual and as a future therapist.

column1: <body>Today, personality psychology and research into the differences between individuals forms an important fundamental basis for the daily practice of psychologists. Psychologists select people for jobs in corporate life based on personality research. If psychologists treat psychological disorders, they often collect information on a patient’s personality. Personality psychology research is therefore an important basis for every student who wants to work in such diverse fields as clinical research, forensic psychology, or human resource management etc. The course Personality Psychology examines the patterns of thoughts, feelings and behaviour that make a person unique but at the same time similar to others. In doing so, the course provides students with a broad introduction into the major themes that govern Personality Psychology.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • You can define and understand the overarching concepts of personality and individual differences;
• You have an understanding of and are able to distinguish between the different perspectives on personality;
• You can explain how key aspects of personality and individual differences contribute to understanding human behaviour;
<li>You can apply scientific knowledge of a personality perspective such that you can analyse and solve a small real-world problem that is grounded in individual differences. This means:
<ul>

column3: • You will have the basic skills to analyse and clarify a problem brought up by a client;
• You are able to write a proposal for a client;
• You can justify your choice of literature/theories and methodology;
• You are able to apply literature/theories into practice to solve a small real-world problem;
• You are able to write an advisory report for a client.

column1: It is clear that people can differ from each other in numerous aspects. For example, people can differ in how friendly they are, how open they are to new ideas, or how well they are able to deal with stress. In addition, people differ in their skills and motivation. In the present course you will learn about different theories regarding the origin and nature of such individual differences.

During the first weeks of the course, we will mainly discuss prominent historical theories on how people become the person they are. This includes the psychoanalytic approach from, probably the most famous psychiatrist of all times, Sigmund Freud. We will also discuss the behaviourist learning theory, as developed by Watson, Skinner, and others, Roger’s humanist personality theory, and Bandura’s social cognitive theory. As psychology student it is essential to get familiar with these theories as they stand at the origin of our field, and are still relevant for many contemporary questions, such as whether we can be aware of the reasons behind our decisions or what the role of parenting is on the development of our character.

During the second half course we will focus on subjects that play key roles in differences between people, namely personality and intelligence. Questions we will address are, 1) what are personality and intelligence and what are their basic dimensions, 2) in what way do personality and intelligence affect life outcomes. We will discuss different theories and opinions on these topics. In doing so, we will also address the nature-nurture debate on the extent to which behaviour is genetic –i.e., inherited from our parents- versus acquired through our interaction with the environment (e.g., parenting, friends, culture, major life events).

For a good understanding of the literature in this field, it is relevant to also grasp various psychometric and statistical terms. For example, knowing what a correlation coefficient is and how to interpret it will help you to better understand how individual differences are studied. The term psychometrics refers to the science directed at measuring psychological features such as personality, intelligence, and other differences between people.  </body>

column1: In this course we focus on the topic of personnel recruitment, selection, classification and placement. Theories and techniques are considered for the effective fitting of individual needs, preferences, knowledge, capacities and skills, with the needs and preferences of the organisation. We consider among other things prediction and decision-making models during selection. We also focus on utility models, anti-discrimination models, clinical and statistical prediction and validity generalisation.

Tutorial group meetings take the form of producing the assignments related to the themes above after these have been considered during lectures. Attending the lectures is crucially important for the tutorial groups.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The goal of this course is to provide the student with a thorough understanding of theory and practice of personnel selection. The purpose of personnel selection is to help identify the most qualified individual for a job. On the one hand, the course focuses on statistical models and theories of prediction, decision-making, fairness, and utility issues in selection. On the other hand, the course is strongly rooted in the practice of personnel selection by dwelling upon best practices in this domain, specifically during the practical.
The course therefore has the following learning objectives:

column2: • At the end of the course the student is profoundly knowledgeable of theories and the state-of-the-art of personnel selection.

• At the end of the course the student has an in-depth understanding of statistical models of prediction and decision making in selection, including knotty problems in these domains, including validity generalization, and including state-of-the-art knowledge on the controversy of clinical versus statistical prediction.
• At the end of the course the student has state-of-the art knowledge of factors influencing the judgement of recruiters and decision makers during selection procedures.
• At the end of the course the student has a thorough understanding of models of fairness in selection, and has a better developed personal viewpoint on these models.
• At the end of the course the student can make estimations of utility of selection procedures and of adverse impact of selection procedures.

• At the end of the course, the student has applied the knowledge in the area of personnel selection by having developed a selection procedure, including some selection devices, and by having used these in the form of a life selection simulation.

column1: Als professional in de zorgsector zet je je in voor anderen. Om dit op een betrokken en bewuste wijze te doen, is het van belang dat je jezelf goed kent. Met meer inzicht over jezelf en je eigen handelen, maak je namelijk professionele en persoonlijke keuzes die beter bij je passen. De Persoonlijke- en Professionele Ontwikkelingslijn (PPO) helpt te ontdekken hoe je jouw (zelf)kennis het beste in de echte wereld kan toepassen en, als uniek persoon, een verschil kan maken in de zorg.

In het tweede studiejaar wordt de student zelf verantwoordelijk voor zijn/haar eigen leerproces. Het is aan de student om ieder blok een leerdoel op te stellen rondom een van de einddoelen van PPO en hier zelf, onder leiding van een coach, mee aan de slag te gaan. Middels reflectieverslagen houdt de student zijn/haar eigen ontwikkeling in de gaten.

column1: <body>De student kan aan het eind van de Persoonlijke- en Professionele Ontwikkelingslijn:

column2: • een (studie)planning opstellen, studievaardigheidstechnieken toepassen en prioriteiten stellen
• in een team met elkaar een doel realiseren binnen de beschikbare tijd en met het gewenste eindresultaat,
• zijn persoonlijkheid duiden inclusief zijn sterke en zwakke punten en hoe dit samenwerking in groepen beïnvloedt,
• de regels van feedback geven (4G’s) en ontvangen (3B’s) toepassen,
• een effectieve en visueel aantrekkelijke presentatie geven in het Engels en Nederlands,
• reflecteren op zijn eigen gedragingen en leerproces m.b.v. het STARR-model,
• persoonlijke leerdoelen opstellen en terugkijkend op het jaar, reflecteren op het eigen leerproces en SMART doelen stellen voor de studie en professionele toekomst.

column1: Sustainability talks have become widespread. The European Green Deal wants to make finance sustainable. The Netherlands encourages the use of sustainable energy. Amsterdam municipality embraced the ‘doughnut model’ in a bid to adopt a more sustainable outlook. The Erasmus Universiteit considers the possibility of its campus going vegan for sustainability reasons. A surge in demand for sustainability has recently materialised at different governance levels. But what does “sustainability” mean and what would its application entail from a regulatory point of view?

The Perspectives on Sustainability course will address this type of questions by examining theoretical and practical issues concerning sustainable development. It will do so by adopting a legal and economic viewpoint and having interactive lectures with the students. Perspectives on Sustainability is a 5 ECTS course offered at Master level.

Literature will be provided during the course. It will be expected from students to consult multiple sources on each topic. This is essential, because when using a single source, representation of the substance often will be too poor. Multiple sources enrich the representation of the course material, and thus help students to better understand the content. For all lectures students should also study the PPT slides provided.

column1: To kick-start your PhD, you’ll be informed about Erasmus MC Graduate School and all the possibilities and other topics you need to know about a PhD candidate at Erasmus MC. You’ll receive tips and tricks for a successful PhD and you’ll meet some of the key players in Erasmus MC Graduate School and some of your fellow new PhD candidates.

This session is held every third Tuesday or Friday of the month. Live sessions will be from 09.00-13.00 including lunch, with a maximum of 25 participants per session. Online sessions (once every 3 months) will be from 09.00-12.30, without a maximum number of participants.
Be advised: this session is highly recommended for all PhD candidates within the first 3 months after starting their PhD project. 0.2 EC is rewarded for attendance.
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location and the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.
Coffee/tea breaks and lunch are included in the live sessions.

column1: *the program may be subject to change.
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column1: A pharmaceutical pricing strategy is more than simply setting a price to recover R&D investments and adding a mark-up to guarantee a desired profit level. Indeed, a price has often little to no relationship to manufacturing costs in this market. It is the perceived value of a new drug in a broad sense, and how a drug is positioned in the market, that is critical to its success. Especially now that development costs are growing, blockbusters are being displaced by niche drugs, treatment is increasingly personalized, and governments are limiting expenditure on healthcare. For a pharmaceutical company, getting sufficient returns on investments and keeping the pipeline filled becomes increasingly challenging.

Many pharmaceutical companies have shifted their focus from sales and marketing to strategic pricing and market access. This has been accompanied by a shift from a product-centered culture to a disease service-centered culture. Clinicians remain important decision makers, but they must move within the boundaries set by payers. Payers are now the ultimate and most influential clients of the pharmaceutical industry.

The course Pharmaceutical Pricing and Market Access (PPMA) aims to provide students with a detailed understanding of this complex and changing market. We will follow each step of the life cycle of a drug, from phase II clinical trials up to post-launch, integrating both market access theory and examples from the real world. We will discuss the importance of optimizing product launches, real world post marketing studies and innovative pricing agreements. Students will gain insight into how the latest changes in regulations, guidelines and stakeholders in the major EU, US and BRIC countries impact the success of brands, as well as the interactions between all the actors on the markets. They will learn to understand how differences between healthcare systems impact optimizing market access for pharmaceutical products.

column2: • 12 interactive lectures with plenary discussion (2 lectures of 3 hours each per week)

• 6 small workgroup meetings (2 hours, once per week) with 10 to 16 students using Problem Based Learning to formulate learning goals, exchange knowledge and have discussions about the case of the week. Problem Based Learning is an active way of learning that gives you better retention of knowledge, enhances your motivation and encourages you to develop skills that are essential for the labour market in the 21st century.
• 2 meetings in which small groups of (around 3 to 4) students present a business case and debate about the presented market access strategies

column1: The written examination is 75% of the final grade. The remainder derives from the two presentations on the business cases (10% of the final grade for each business case, a missed presentation will be graded with a “1”) and mandatory attendance of the workgroups (5%, if more than one working group is missed, the attendance grade will be “5.4” instead of a “10”). The presentations of the business cases are scheduled in the third and sixth week and the students’ presence is obligatory. The minimum pass-threshold for the weighted average of the course grade is “5.5”. No reading materials and notes are allowed during the exam, other than an English dictionary. A simple, non-programmable calculator is allowed.
The re-sit is composed of one single written examination that comprises the entire course learning goals and thus counts for 100%. There is no re-sit for of the business case presentations.</body>

column1: <body>By the end of the course students will be able to:

column2: • Interpret trends and drivers of drug costs.
• Evaluate how the life cycle of a drug is affected by different aspects of life cycle management.
• Understand pricing and reimbursement systems of drugs in key international markets.
• Critically reflect on different stakeholder perspectives on the pharmaceutical industry (e.g. from patients, industry, government).

• Implement key concepts of pharmaceutical innovation, pricing and market access (e.g. patents, value propositions, value-based pricing, price referencing, market access arrangements) in an own strategy.
• Develop a pricing and market access strategy for drugs
