column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course explores philosophical anthropology with a view to both introducing it as a philosophical approach, through engaging classical texts of the genre, and opening up the subject to the crises of our own time. As a ‘research program’ in mostly German philosophy from roughly 1920 onward, philosophical anthropology tried to provide a philosophically and scientifically informed answer to the question: what is it to be human? It took inspiration from a patchwork of traditions: transcendental philosophy, philosophy of nature, Lebensphilosophie, and phenomenology, among others. This original formulation of philosophical anthropology also had to relate itself to developments in the philosophy of history, existentialism, and political developments both in theory and in the direct context of the Weimar Republic.

The first aim of the course is to address how philosophical anthropology was constructed and developed in this context. We focus on Max Scheler, Günther Anders, and Helmuth Plessner, the latter’s works serving as a privileged point of access from which all the different threads can be unraveled. The political aspect is considered through the fraught interrelation between Plessner and Carl Schmitt.

The second aim is to evaluate what the role of philosophical anthropology is and can be in the contemporary philosophical landscape and how we should evaluate its importance and prospects. This is considered in relation to its methodology of ‘synthetic philosophy’ and its own philosophical building-blocks. Is such a patchwork still possible? More substantially, we look at potential contributions of philosophical anthropology to ecological questions, philosophy of technology, and social and political philosophy. Because many of the questions involved are still open-ended, this course seeks to contribute to asking these questions in a systematic and more or less unified manner. Students are asked to write a final essay at the conclusion of the course in an attempt to contribute to and/or critique philosophical anthropology as a research program today.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Have a fundamental understanding of philosophical anthropology and its relation to other philosophical traditions and insights.
• Can read and comment upon core texts in philosophical anthropology.
• Can apply the concepts of philosophical anthropology to reflect on contemporary crises in ecology, politics, and other domains.
• Can critically evaluate philosophical anthropology and its central concepts.

column1: We will explore how to not just find the ‘lowest common denominators’ but pay attention to deep plurality/difference, and diverse methods of achieving common aims. The course will include group work based on multisolving, and compare partnership vs domination society archetypes. Through the Socratic method, and role playing, we’ll explore how to maximize positive behavioral change and reduce resistance via kindness and empathy.

This course will take students through the process of becoming familiar with the various forms of philosophical tools that can allow for transformational change. It examines various logic systems, types of persuasion, ways of working together beyond the polder model, and also differentiates between episteme and doxa, and addresses the question: what constitutes expertise? And what role does expertise play in a given scenario? How are we all experts at our own experience, but not necessarily how things fit together on a systems level? What is the relationship between specialization and generalization.

This course not only answers the question “what can philosophy contribute to societal transitions?” and shows how it has been applied, but also trains students to think strategically and philosophically together for transforming stuck structures.</body>

column1: This course will examine (i) consequentialist vs deontological theories of what is morally right, (ii) utilitarian egalitarian and prioritarian theories of what is good overall, (iii) the nature of welfare, (iv) the nature of fairness, and (v) social choice theory.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students have basic knowledge of the significant views, ideas and lines of arguments in the philosophy of economics.
• Students should be able to devise examples that help to distinguish the hedonistic, preference satisfaction and Sen and Nussbaum’s capability conceptions of well-being.
• They should be able to provide reasons for and against each conception by providing premise-conclusion arguments in essay form.
• Students should be able to distinguish between various conceptions of fairness.
• Students should be able to formulate Broome’s theory of fairness.
• Students should be able to explain how goodness and fairness come apart.
• Students should be able to argue for or against an egalitarian or adequacy norm for distributing educational resources and opportunities, by providing premise-conclusion arguments in essay form.
• Students should be able to provide examples of their own devising to support this argument.
• Students should be able to define the basic concepts and results (Condorcet paradox, Arrow’s theorem, Gibbard Satterthwaite theorem) of Social Choice Theory.
• Students should be able to apply various Social Choice functions.
• Students should be able to explain and apply some prominent axioms for Social Choice functions.
• Students will be able to cooperate with other students in planning, drafting, and revising an argumentative essay.

column1: As contemporary activist movements challenge western narratives around Colonial exploitation and populist politicians see a nostalgic and nationalist resurgence on the right, contemporary (culture) wars have increasingly come to revolve around history. But what is history? What is, for example, “progress,” what remains of it, and what comes after? And who is the subject of history? The global proletariat, Western Man, or Gaïa? And who, then, is its “object”? Who are the winners of “the process of civilization” and who are its losers?

How do we position ourselves in time? Our understanding of history plays a critical role in our individual and collective self-understanding. From Antiquity to the present, philosophers have therefore offered theories of history, explaining how societies develop and decline. Do they progress or regress, or do they develop in endless cycles, perhaps even in chaotic, non-linear feedback loops? Can history be rationalized at all? In this course, we will investigate what role our understanding of history plays in these social processes. We will focus on the development of a new understanding of history in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries in the work of Kant, Hegel, Marx, and Nietzsche and its critical development by twentieth and twenty-first century philosophers.

While this course module is meant for students in the Philosophy of Social and Behavioral Sciences program, exceptions for students from other disciplines can be made. Please contact the lecturer at kopaitich@esphil.eur.nl.

column1: After this course, students should grasp, and be able to productively work with, differences and similarities in the understandings of history in philosophy. Additionally, students will comprehend and interrogate the historical self-production of the human in “his” changing social and cultural formations. Finally, students will demonstrate, through writing assignments, their capacity to utilize these concepts in response to historical phenomena/problems in their own discipline.

column1: The lectures and seminar-discussions will focus on the following issues:
1.         The sources of human rights law within the system of public international law.
2.         Human rights as a specific modern discourse: the complementarity of constituting state power and controlling state-power.
3.         Human rights between democracy and the Rule of Law.
5.         Facing the limits of autonomy as sovereignty.
7.         Legal, political and ethical skepticism about human rights.
8.         Current human rights questions surrounding globalisation and populism.

The teaching method will be inductive and bottom-up: ‘learning by experience’. It means that students will engage in philosophical reflection on human rights issues while studying relevant literature and by presenting and exchanging their findings in the seminar.

The discussions will be introduced, prepared and reviewed by the lecturers (master class method). By doing so, the lecturers will offer the participants a philosophical method aimed at bringing to the surface implicit normative assumptions within a human rights discourse. They will also offer them the means to question these assumptions.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The overall aim of this course is to encourage and teach students to reflect critically on human rights and human rights issues, from a theoretical/philosophical perspective. More specifically, after completing the course students should be able to:

column2: • understand the history of ideas of human rights and of human rights law
• understand the difference between legal, political and ethical perspectives on human rights
• explain the main philosophical challenges of the human rights discourse
• apply these philosophical challenges to current human rights issues
• understand and apply the concepts, methods and techniques of philosophical reflection on human rights law as a condition for a decent transnational legal and political order.

column2: <title></title>

column1: Within the different (inter)disciplines of media- and visual cultural studies there exist a range of approaches to the interpretation and analysis of images and other media contents. Consider for instance semiotics and deconstruction in literary studies, formal and cultural analysis in film studies, iconography and composition in the study of art and quantitative and qualitative discourse analysis in studies of mass media and social media. These approaches share a tendency to “look through” media in order to focus on the image and other visual contents.

The course Philosophy of Media: Beyond the Image invites students to not only look through media as so many windows on the world – but to also take a critical media philosophical look at media in order to conceptualize media as driving forces behind large scale historical changes and a wide range of developments in our contemporary world.

The course is structured around the media philosophical strands of media ecology (both in the various European and Canadian traditions) and media archaeology (in the Nordic tradition) and focuses on the philosophical implications of canonical texts by authors such as Roland Barthes, Walter Benjamin, Marshal McLuhan, Friedrich Kittler, Donna Haraway and N. Katherine Hayles.

In weekly tutorials as well as lectures, film screenings and site visits to media labs, students explore topics such as the relationship between technology and human agency, media as extensions of the human body and the central nervous system, mediacentric historiographies and media archaeologies, as well as the social, cultural and political implications of various media ecologies from the past, present and future.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Describe and explain the various histories of the social media platforms and applications under discussion;
• Understand the basic tenets of the political economic and STS perspectives on Social Media;
• Critically evaluate the organizational ecologies and business models of the social media platforms and applications under discussion;
• Critically evaluate the ways in which social practices and social media interfaces are co-constituted;
• Formulate a personal standpoint concerning the debates about the ‘effects’ of social media in domains such as privacy, creativity, copyright, distraction, sharing and sociability.
• Write and present a conference research paper.

column1: Philosophy of Science offers a foundation to better understand and evaluate science. In the case of Management, that is not easy: our scientific knowledge concerns things you cannot touch or perceive directly, like markets, organisations, and the mind. In addition, Management is an applied science with roots in different fields, such as sociology, psychology and economics, each with their own assumptions and methods. In order to develop an overview and an ability to contextualize the theories that will be offered later in the (pre-)master, students will learn the most important concepts and ways of thinking Philosophy of Science has to offer.

The course consists of two parts. First the students will get familiar with Philosophy of Science in general by following the thoughts and debates of the most important thinkers of the twentieth century. After that we will zoom in on the science of Management. In addition we will consider current debates in which science plays a role and we will address the question how science can be a force for positive change.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After completing this course the student is able to:
1. Recognize and apply the main concepts of Philosophy of Science;
2. Critically evaluate arguments concerning important scientific approaches;
3. Interpret the relationship between theories and concepts on the one hand and facts and empirical research on the other;
4. Identify the assumptions of theories in Management and evaluate their validity;
5. Evaluate and discuss the extent to which social sciences have something to say on normative matters.
During this course students work on the following skills: Analytic thinking, logical argumentation, theoretical interpretation, academic integrity and academic writing.

column1: This course not only addresses profound philosophical questions of how scientific research as a human activity may track the truth about ‘organizational reality’ but also has the aim of providing a conceptual apparatus to understand and evaluate the assumptions and truth claims of the many different theories that exist in the field of management. Management is an interdisciplinary field, and therefore harbors different theories that explain management reality using different concepts and relying on very different assumptions. Sometimes theories in management even give incompatible accounts of the same phenomenon. For both researchers and future managers, it is important to be able to make a reasoned choice between the theories that apply to a specific phenomenon. This course seeks to provide students with the conceptual apparatus relevant to choosing between different theoretical perspectives and aims to develop the critical abilities of students to analyze and evaluate theories in management.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The principal objective of this course is to equip students for evaluating and choosing between many different theories in the field of management. After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Describe various philosophical views of the scientific development.
• Compare the difference between theories and concepts and facts and empirical research.
• Explain how to establish the validity of non-empirical concepts and theories in social science.
• Outline the assumptions of theories in management and assess their scientific validity.
• Evaluate critical argumentation concerning major positions of management science.
• Assess and discuss the extent to which social science bears on normative issues.
• Synthesize and analyze the philosophical stand of a given context.

column1: An answer to the question 'What is Science?’ will be expounded.

This will lead in a natural manner to the analysis of core concepts of science (method, theory, model, confirmation, verification, infirmation, falsification, observation, explanation, experiment, evidence, aims and values of science). Further an introduction to philosophical debates concerning whether science tells us the truth about reality; social components of science; metaphysical presuppositions that make scientific inquiry possible; epistemic uncertainty in times when action is needed (corona pandemic). In two tutor meetings, Excercises will be discussed, designed to understand the texts better. The text of the course consists of Modules written specially for this course.

column1: <body>This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:

column2: • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
• What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
• What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
• How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?

column1: Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed.</body>

column1: In this course we will study the key topics of this philosophical discipline, and apply these to management science. We will review:

column2: <li>
The so-called “demarcation problem”, asking: what is science?
<li>
The problems of inductive inference
<li>
The problem of theories being underdetermined by the evidence
<li>
Theories of scientific confirmation
<li>
Causal explanation by laws and mechanisms
<li>
Evaluating science with the notions of research programmes, normal science, paradigm shift and scientific revolution
<li>
The role of objectivity and values in science
<li>
Reasoning and argumentation.

column1: This course is about philosophical problems that emerge from medical research and practice. Scientific knowledge is often understood as the inexorable product of careful observation, which reveals how things really are. Science itself is often presented as having a (i.e. only one) method, which can reveal such truths. Evidence-based medicine is presented as the application of the scientific method to medicine, in which the truth about treatment effectiveness and the accuracy of diagnostic tests is revealed through careful observation.

The course begins by making a rapid historical survey of different philosophical approaches to doing science taken by canonical researchers in medicine, biology, chemistry and physics. This reveals that a great variety of different methods have been employed to produce scientific knowledge. Insights from this survey are used to identify philosophical assumptions embedded in contemporary medical research and practice.

Evidence-based medicine holds empirical observation in especially high regard, downplaying the importance of theoretical speculation. As the historical survey shows, this was not always the case. Evidence based medicine will be presented as a the latest iteration in a centuries old debate about the relationship between theory and observation. Using contemporary philosophical debates about its strengths and weaknesses, evidence-based medicine will be put ""on trial""; with some students being asked to argue in its favour, and others against it.

The course then turns its attention to the evaluation of diagnostic tests, especially to the problems that arise when trying to evaluate a test when there is no reference standard to determine disease status. The course will consider if it is even possible to make observations of disease status without theoretical expectations, and, if it is not, how it is that knowledge differs from belief.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: <body>This course introduces the student to philosophical problems that emerge from medical science and practice.

column2: • At the end of the course, the student is aware of the great variety of different approaches to scientific research that have been employed by physicists, chemists, biologists and medics historically and today.

• The student can describe these different approaches using philosophical language; including ontology, epistemology, empiricism, rationalism, theory, observation, deduction, induction, and abduction.
• The student can outline philosophical positions in the debate on evidence-based medicine, particularly on determining the best methodology to evaluate the effectiveness of treatments.

• The student can outline philosophical problems associated with the evaluation of diagnostic tests, particularly regarding how to evaluate diagnostic tests when there is no accepted reference standard.
• Students are able to offer their own views about how to cope with these philosophical problems.

column1: This course is part of cluster 2. Environment, Life and Technology

Starting point is Hegel’s dialectics of scientific experience, focussing on two key text: the introduction to the Phenomenology of the Spirit and to Volume I of the Encyclopaedia of the philosophical sciences. Subsequently, we will discuss how this was taken up by later authors (Engels, Bachelard, Heidegger, Lacan, Butler, etc.). Finally, the question is whether these concepts and methods allow us to come to terms with contemporary technoscience, and vice versa: how can contemporary technoscientific developments revivify / reveal the added value of continental methods and approaches?

column1: As sessile organisms, plants must be able to interpret and respond to their environment to grow and survive. They also live on a different time scale than animals, and even though their life is highly complex and often surprising, most of it is invisible (or still unknown) to humans. This course will therefore teach you the basics of plant biology, including plant structure and morphology, metabolism, reproduction, genetics, evolution and systematics. The main goal of this course is to remove all vestiges of zoocentrism from your mindset, giving you the tools to appreciate the uniqueness and specificities of the Plant Kingdom. You will be able to (i) distinguish the plants from other life forms, (ii) understand how a plant is structured, and which modifications have evolved to cope with the different terrestrial environments, (iii) describe the different parts of a plant by using appropriate botanical terms, (iv) discover why plants are the life sources for food and oxygen for all organisms on Earth, (v) understand the significance of the diplobiontic life cycle of plants, and (vi) appreciate the intricate biochemical and signalling networks of plants, including those of photosynthesis, hormone action and communication with other plants and organisms. Finally, the students will be introduced to the richness of plant diversity resulting from eons of evolution, and to enter a natural area and distinguish the plants encountered as being either Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms or Angiosperms. The course will be supported by extra activities, such as a visit to a botanical garden.

column1: This course highlights the pivotal role of plants on our lives on one side, and the importance of sustainable agriculture in the food production sector on the other side. The first part of the course aims at integrating descriptive knowledge of plant anatomy and morphology with biochemical and genetic mechanisms, in order to study functional processes ranging from seed germination to flowering and fruit set. It also focuses on the study of plant processes - how plants grow, develop and function as they interact with their physical (abiotic) and living (biotic) environments. Based on this acquired knowledge, the second part of the course will focus on agro-ecology and sustainable agriculture in order to give the students an overview about the current systems of plant production and the development of novel sustainable farming systems, from soil management to fertilisation, and from the application of pesticides/herbicides to the use of GMOs. During the course, up-to-date case studies will be presented in order to illustrate how the knowledge of plant ecophysiology and agro-ecology can be a useful tool to cope with increasing environmental and societal issues, such as climate change, food production, sustainable agriculture and environmental pollution.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: After completing this course, the students will:
1. Be acquainted with the molecular mechanisms and the physiological processes that
shape and regulate plant life. This includes:

column5: Photosynthesis – light and ‘dark’ reactions.
Respiration and lipid metabolism
Assimilation of inorganic nutrients (N, P, S)

column3: - How plants acquire and transport inorganic and organic materials for growth:

column5: Water balance and transport
Solute transport, translocation in the phloem and photosynthates distribution

column3: - How plants grow and develop throughout their lives:

column5: Embryogenesis: root and shoot apical meristems
Seed dormancy, germination and seedling establishment
Vegetative growth: leaf development, shoot branching and architecture, root
Control of flowering and floral development
Signals and signal transduction: hormones and plant development.
Tropisms: growth in response to directional stimuli.
Plant senescence and plant death

column3: - How plants interact with their external environment:

column5: Biotic interactions
Abiotic environmental stress

column3: 2. Discover what is new in plant physiology.
Like most areas of biology, plant physiology is
experiencing an explosion of new discoveries and new ideas. We will discuss some of the
new topics in plant physiology and why they are considered important.
3. Understand that plant physiology relates to other fields in biology.
be plant physiologists. For this course to be valuable to you, you must understand how plant
physiology interconnects with agricultural, forestry, environmental science, genetics, the
health sciences, and other fields. Throughout the course, connections between plant
physiology and other areas of knowledge will be emphasized.
4. Focus on how plant physiology will shape the future.
As students, you must consider the
future and your role in it. Plant biotechnology is putting plants to many new uses and
improving them for old ones. Plants can now be used to grow plastics and fuels, to remove
toxic wastes from soils, and to produce vaccines and drugs. Agriculture and forestry practices
have been altered by new crop varieties that resist stress, pathogens, herbicides, and postharvest
losses. These developments in plant biotechnology are derived from knowledge of
plant physiology and plant genetics. As scientists, business people, teachers, consumers,
voters, and parents, you must contribute to intelligent decisions about how plants should be
used to improve the human condition. To prepare you for this, we will discuss the role of
plant physiology in the future throughout the course.</body>

column1: In today’s digital age, online platforms and marketplaces such as Airbnb, Uber, Amazon, and Spotify have become integral to our daily lives and represent some of the most successful business models of the last two decades. This course examines the way these platforms function and how they have changed the way we shop, travel, and consume services.

At the heart of successful platforms lies smart design—a design that builds trust through consumer reviews, utilizes data to personalize recommendations, and employs sophisticated algorithms to match buyers and sellers. Enabled by new technology, these platforms have created new marketplaces that require thoughtful and strategic design to yield desirable outcomes.
In this course, students will be introduced to essential concepts from both economics and marketing that are critical for analyzing, designing, and understanding platform markets.

column2: <li>
The role of network effects in the success or failure of a platform
<li>
Analytical tools for examining two-sided platforms, competition, and market structure
<li>
Key market design decisions, including pricing strategies, reputation systems, and matching algorithms
<li>
The use of A/B tests and experimentation to evaluate the effects of business decisions
• The exploration of biases, potential discrimination, and the broader societal impact of platforms

column1: Attendance is not mandatory but of course strongly advised as there will be no recordings of the course.

column1: The course will demonstrate the relevance of employing different theories, by starting with an elaboration of the problem (the latest facts on climate change), the history of economic thought on climate change and the problems with economic theory in addressing climate change (including but not limited to market failures). The subsequent sessions each discuss climate change from a different perspective, demonstrating different analytical tools and alternative policy options.
The tutorial groups have two purposes. The first is to acquire in-depth knowledge of the perspectives presented in the lectures:

column2: • What are the main assumptions, features, and implications of this theoretical perspective?
• How does this theoretical perspective relate to your previous knowledge of economics and the other perspectives presented in the course?
• How could this perspective contribute to effective policy making in general (not necessarily limited to climate change).

column1: The second purpose of the tutorial groups is to provide guidance for the small groups and their graded group assignment.

column1: Students will learn to critically assess a plurality of economic perspectives on climate change: mainstream economics, ecological economics, capability approach, common pool resource institutions, and structuralist economics. Students will also be able to argue why a complex economic problem such as climate change requires a plurality of economic perspectives, for its analysis as well as for the development of policy options.

column1: Government policy is crucial to tackle the multiplicity of policy problems that modern societies face, from education to energy and from healthcare to environmental issues. Regardless of the scope, salience and complexity of the societal problem, governmental action is often deemed as necessary. In that regard, policymakers have a responsibility to develop and implement policies that have the best chance to contribute to the health, safety, and well-being of their constituents. Yet, uncertainties abound, data are limited, identifying key issues is difficult, and designing feasible policy solutions is controversial. In such a world, proper analysis and guidance are needed so important policy choices are not based on hunches or guesses, and policy processes get stuck for long periods, perhaps with regrettable results.

Policy analysis is the identification of a policy problem and possible solutions. The term refers to both the analysis of public policy (i.e., the study of public policy in a descriptive, interpretative, or explanatory fashion) and analysis for public policymaking. In this course we focus on this second meaning of policy analysis by elaborating on the activities, methodology, and tools that can be used to give aid and advice in a context of public policy making. By doing so, we add to the ‘analysis of policy’ approach which was the focus of the Public Policy course during the first year of the bachelor programme.

Akin to Public Policy, we use a variety of perspectives. More specifically, we look at analysis for policy both from a rational as well as from a political (also labelled as non-rational) perspective. We discuss and compare the epistemology and ontology of both models. We apply the methods and techniques found in the rational toolbox (e.g., sampling, forecasting, cost-benefit analysis) and supplement them with more critical, mixed-method tools (e.g., focus group methodology, content analysis, narrative analysis). Specific attention will be paid to the role of the citizen and the use of civic engagement in policy analysis (e.g., using discursive tools, conflict resolution and consensus building techniques). We also discuss ethical questions concerning analysis for policy and the role of the advisor in that process.

All in all, the course familiarizes students with rationalist and political approaches of policy analysis. Ultimately, students are better prepared to comprehensively understand policy problems and analyse them, not only through models, numbers, and statistics, but also through political thinking and by understanding that public problems are socially constructed.

<li>

<li>

column1: Governments design and implement policies to solve societal problems. Many regional, national, and supranational authorities create policies through more or less standardized processes of policy design, formalize policies through decision-making procedures, and implement policies through existing or newly established agencies. But often the context in which the policy is designed and implemented is complex and dynamic. If governments do not sufficiently incorporate this complexity in their approach, implementation problems may arise and policy efforts may evaporate without significant results.

When designing public policies, governments often try to reduce complexity by splitting up a problem in separate aspects, which can be individually targeted by specific policy measures. Traditional methods of policy-making are aimed at identifying and understanding the causal relations in a policy field and specify and target specific elements in these causal relations. However, its causal relations are unclear or unpredictable and dynamic, policies may have no effect at all or unexpected, and perhaps even undesired effects.

This course deals with the question of what governments can do in a complex context, what they often do (putting complexity aside), why they continue to do so (policy inertia), and what complexity-recognizing and innovation-seeking entail as alternative approaches. The course brings together two important streams in state-of-the-art public administration research: complex systems thinking and policy innovation.

On the one hand, we discuss the principles of complex social systems and their characteristics (i.e., non-linear, without clear boundaries, and not operated through mechanical cause-effect relationships). We pay attention to questions such as: how can governments deal with complexity and dynamics in their social environment? Which theoretical concepts are helpful in understanding and discussing complexity and dynamics? Students gain insight in the principles of complex adaptive systems and methods of complex system thinking, in which notions such as co-evolution, feedback, and self-organization play an important role.

On the other hand, we pay attention to the need for policy innovations and the conditions under which innovations come about. Students are invited to reflect on the dilemma between the need for stable policies that contribute to legal certainty for citizens and the need for adaptive, innovative policies, that meet the conditions of a vastly changing social context. Policy innovations are needed to bridge the gap between the system world of bureaucracy and the life world of citizens. Many innovations are aimed at improving the interplay between various government organizations and private and semi-private organizations, such as housing corporations or health insurance companies. These collaborations allow for more demand-oriented and integrated modes of working. The ultimate goal is to generate as much public value as possible in these collaborations. That is why in this course we will examine theories of public value and collaborative innovation, including processes of co-production or co-creation between governments and citizens.

These news forms of governance require a form of direction that is more facilitating and stimulating. In that regard, the course also pays attention to meta-governance approaches to address questions such as ""how can a government allow social forces to arrive at innovative and effective solutions without completely relinquishing control?""

column1: The second course in the Politics & Society Master specialisation puts citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours in context: it focuses on the various institutional, cultural, and economic conditions relevant for understanding why political attitudes and behaviours differ across regions and change over time. It does so by discussing both classic and recent theories and research in relevant fields, most notably political sociology, political science, and communication science. The main institutional conditions addressed are political institutions, welfare regimes, and national media, as these prove to be crucial for understanding trends and cross-national differences in political trust, public opinion, and voting behaviour. The same goes for the cultural conditions addressed in this course, which most notably include regional and urban cultures, cultural and ethnic diversity, and religion and secularisation. The final part of the course focusses on the role of globalisation – especially its economic ramifications – for political attitudes and behaviour.

Besides providing in-depth insights into the relevance of contextual phenomena for individuals’ political attitudes and behaviour, this course stimulates sensitivity for recognizing unresolved and unexplored research puzzles. To this end, students write a research proposal on how a context condition affects a political attitude or behaviour of their choice. As such, it equips students with key knowledge and skills needed for conducting their research for their Master’s thesis. In addition, it stimulates students to: 1) analyse and critically reflect on the contents and implications of social-scientific theories and research findings; 2) discuss the application of those theories to contemporary social and political phenomena.

This course focuses on understanding and explaining the role of context for political attitudes and behaviours; it does not focus on its moral implications, nor on the moral implications of empirical research on that role.

column1: This course is an introduction to political economy. The basic premise of this course is that political actors have their own interests and do not automatically pursue the general interest. As a consequence the government cannot be considered as a single benevolent actor as is typically assumed in Public Finance. Instead interactions between different political actors determine the outcome of the political process. We will consider the incentives of politicians, voters, lobbyists, and bureaucrats. We will see how they interact and determine the outcome and efficiency of the political process.

We will use standard mathematical analysis and game-theoretic modeling to analyze the interactions of political actors. Exercises will complement the lecture to give students the opportunity to apply the insights and practice the tools encountered in the lecture.

column1: Human Resources have increasingly been recognised as a source of competitive advantage and as such good people management is vital for organisations. The course is designed to develop a thorough knowledge and understanding of the effective management of people. After exploring the theoretical origins of HRM, the emergence of HR strategy and the relationship between business strategy and HRM strategy, the course will focus on discussing and analysing important HRM activities such as HR planning, recruitment and selection, training and development, absence and retention management, reward and performance and exit management. A deepened understanding of the strategic character of these practical HRM activities provides students with the knowledge and skills required for the integration of HR policies into a coherent HRM strategy, the implementation of which will contribute to a high-performance organisation.

column1: The theme of this module is the significance and value of democracy in modern politics and administration. That there is such a value inherent to democracy is not self-evident in a world in which crisis- and conflict management and the effective design of policy arrangements seem to demand clear priority. However the democratic process may be organised, there remains a degree of unpredictability in the behaviour and choice of the demos (‘the people’), as history keeps on teaching us.

Within history as well, democracy was never fully accepted. There was always something to criticise, whether this be the lack of competent judgement of the people, the complexity of decision making, the interested self-seeking of the electorate or political parties, short term effect and the degree to which democracy was overwhelmed by media attention and emotion.

At the same time, political thinkers of the past were fascinated by the idea of self-rule; the notion that given an adequate organisational design, such a design might enable human beings to be genuinely autonomous and independent. Important ideas such as sovereignty, power, social contract, and even the idea of administration itself, were developed in this regard, occasionally also in opposition to the ‘plebeian threat’.

Nonetheless, it cannot be denied that in the course of time, gradually and often operating against the tide, a sense of politics and administration appeared whose principle is self-rule and that often stands opposed to a technocratic idea of the political order. In this course the various stages within this development are identified and characterised in relation to current challenges of politics and administration. Different developments in thinking about democracy are discussed and their institutional realisation in administrative practices is explored. This means that not only the basic ideas and mechanisms underlying modern representative democracy are addressed, but also more recent innovations that aim to enlarge representative democracy with institutions for direct citizen participation. Finally, the challenges of democracy beyond the nation-state in the global realm are explored based on a conceptual understanding of the history of democracy. These themes form the basis of the assignments carried out during the biweekly seminars.

The lectures and seminars in this course are fully integrated. The seminars are used to develop basic historical and philosophical skills that enable students to reflect on the contents of the lectures and thereby work towards a fresh understanding of the character of modern democratic politics and the history of the representative state in its current form. Attending the lectures and staying ahead with the course readings is absolutely essential in order to carry out the seminar assignments and prepare for the individual portfolio assignment.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: “And what should they know of England who only England know?” (Rudyard Kipling)

Politics is the process by which groups reach and enforce binding decisions. Power is the currency of politics. To survive, political systems need to force their members to do what they would not otherwise have done. Notwithstanding globalization, national political systems are still the main place for the legitimate execution of power. At the same time, nations differ widely in their institutions for political decision-making. This allows for comparison: learning more about other countries, and therewith about your own country, classifying characteristics of political systems, analysing their causes and consequences, predicting and evaluating the effects of societal and political-institutional change.

This course introduces students to the discipline of empirical political science. After having discussed the main concepts, we will compare and analyse various facets of national political systems. Democratic versus authoritarian systems, political trust, political communication and media, political cleavages, political parties, election rules and voting behavior, parliamentarian versus presidential governments, the structure and function of parliaments, and the role of constitutions and constitutional courts. Looking through the glasses of a political scientist, we seek to answer questions such as the following: Does trust in governments decline and what factors account for trust/distrust? What is the impact of social media on politics? Does globalization lead to new cleavages in society? What factors explain the rise of populist parties? How are governments formed? Are coalition governments less stable than single-party governments? Are parliaments willing and able to control governments and are they representative of the electorate?

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After passing the course, students are able to
• reproduce major political characteristics of the Netherlands and a selected number of other political systems
• compare major political characteristics of the Netherlands and a selected number of other political systems along relevant dimensions
• explain causal theories about relationships between characteristics of political systems
• evaluate the validity of causal theories based on existing data
• predict the effect of societal and institutional changes on political phenomena
• evaluate proposals for institutional change based on expected effects on relevant feature of political systems
• develop and defend a position of a political group for negotiating a new constitution

column1: And what should they know of England who only England know?”

Politics is the process by which groups reach and enforce binding decisions. Power is the currency of politics. To survive, political systems need to force their members to do what they would not otherwise have done. Notwithstanding globalization, national political systems are still the main place for the legitimate execution of power. At the same time, nations differ widely in the institutions through which this power is wielded. This allows for comparison: learning more about other countries, and therewith about your own country, classifying characteristics of political systems, analysing their causes and consequences, and predicting the effects of societal and political-institutional change.

This course introduces students to the discipline of empirical political science. After having discussed the main concepts, we will compare and analyse various facets of national political systems. Democratic versus authoritarian systems, liberal versus illiberal democracies, political trust, political communication and media, political cleavages, political parties, election rules and voting behavior, parliamentarian versus presidential governments, the structure and function of parliaments, subnational governments and the role of constitutions and constitutional courts. Looking through the glasses of a political scientist, we seek to answer questions such as the following: Does trust in governments decline and what factors account for trust/distrust? What is the impact of social media on politics? Does globalization lead to new cleavages in society? What factors explain the rise of populist parties? How are governments formed? Are coalition governments less stable than single-party governments? Are parliaments willing and able to control governments and are they representative of the electorate? Why have some countries federal systems and other unitary systems?</body>

column1: Migration and diversity are key political topics of our time. This course focuses both on the role that migration and diversity play in politics and policies and vice versa. To what extent are contemporary political debates on migration and diversity really new? What role do different political actors have in the fields of migration and diversity? What about the role of minorities in representational democracies? How are migrants and diversity categorized, presented and discussed in public debate and how do policies play into these processes?

This course focuses not only on contemporary politics and policymaking, but also on how the processed of categorizations and representation of migration and diversity that stand behind. The course unpacks politicization of migration with attention to its manifestation in public opinion, party politics, political movements and public spaces, such as museums. Additional attention is paid to the local level to how migration and diversity are governed in urban settings, and housing challenges related to that.

1. Identify the links between political structures, public opinion, migration and diversity policies
2. Discuss from the theoretical perspective the new political and policy developments
3. Critically examine categories of policymaking and statistical evidence in migration policymaking
4. Analyse the role of politicization and conflict in the governance of migration and diversity
5. Critically interrogate the discursive practices and common representations of migrants and diversity

column1: Public governance, understood as the formal and informal arrangements that determine how  public decisions are made and how public actions are carried out, is an intensely political process that is becoming increasingly complex. Today, the most prominent political unit still is the state, having exercised sovereignty over public policies for more than a century, but whose power, capacity and legitimacy are increasingly challenged by a variety of sub-national and non-state actors.

Traditionally approached from a state-centric perspective, public policy is no longer exclusively made by national bureaucracies as an ever increasingly complex web of actors and stakeholders become involved. How such actors are involved in aspects of public policy-making such as agenda-setting, policy formulation and advocacy is therefore a core component of the course.

This course engages with concrete governance problems encountered across the world, such as inequality in cities, corruption and the climate crisis. In doing so, the course will also highlight the role of non-state actors in the policy process, and how governance is evolving.

Assessment consist of a group project in which you will produce policy advice on an issue of your choice. Adopting a practitioner’s perspective, you will translate scientific evidence into practical recommendations. In doing so, you will develop basic policy writing and analysis skills which will be of value in a wide range of careers.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>On successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Reflect on the current role and place of government in modern societies and describe their historical developments
• Describe the role of a selected number of political institutions in modern states and reflect on their infuence and performance
• Describe how governments design and implement policies
• Reflect on the origins and backgrounds of governmental policies in various policy domains

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Complex governance processes in networks are constantly influenced by the outside world. This is especially happening through the media attention and the dynamics this generates in networks. Media have become a separate institution with its own logic (the media logic) and its own rules how to bring news and package it. Media logic is concerned with the content of the news provided as well as the formats in which news is created and processed. The format of an item on the television news bulletin for instance, has to meet certain criteria: the slot allocated for the story is only a few minutes long, it has to have news value and it should attract or keep the attention of the viewers. These criteria influence how reality is constructed in the news story.

column3: Many authors claim that media have profound influence on our daily social life, how policy problems are shaped and on various other institutions in society. And this becomes visible when media pay attention to governance processes. Not only does the visibility of these processes enhance but also the decision dynamics change considerably as agenda forming theories have been arguing for some time.

The mediatized world asks for public leaders who can communicate their messages in clear “sound bites,” who can adapt swiftly to new developments and “media hypes,” and who can create attractive brands which arouse positive associations with citizens and voters. But in this public leaders in modern network society are faced with a growing gap between the front stage of a mediatized political world on the one hand and the daily practical life of complexity of governance processes in networks on the other hand (the backstage).

In this course we explore the media as a separate institution, their influence on policy processes and the requirements it posed on public managers. But we also explore managerial strategies that public managers have to influence media attention, like (political) public relations, and public branding.

column1: Politieke communicatie bestudeert de communicatie tussen burgers, media en politieke actoren zoal politici en politieke partijen. In deze cursus worden deze actoren geanalyseerd: welke communicatiestrategieën gebruiken politici en partijen, hoe berichten journalisten over politieke kwesties en welke betekenis hebben deze processen voor burgers en de democratie? Studenten analyseren literatuur over politieke communicatie en reflecteren aan de hand van praktijkvoorbeelden op die literatuur. Door middel van kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden bestuderen zij een hedendaags vraagstuk op het terrein van politieke communicatie. Studenten formuleren op dit terrein een onderzoeksopzet en voeren dit onderzoek tijdens de tweede helft van de module uit.

column1: <body>Greatest Hits and Critics’ Picks is a tailor-made, so-called ‘capita selecta’ course with revolving guest speakers from music research and the music industry. In this course, theoretical and practical knowledge on contemporary popular music production, distribution and consumption is combined to offer students cutting-edge insights into the popular music landscape. In a series of small-scale, interactive seminars, a number of invited speakers from popular music research and the popular music profession will share their knowledge on topics as diverse as: crisis management in the music industry; streaming and recommendation systems/algorithms; crowdfunding and novel forms of income generation; or the importance and value of live music for audiences. Throughout the course, students actively engage with the presented themes and topics through student-led introductions, and they write their own research paper at the end of the course.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is exclusively for students enrolled in the minor ‘MU$IC: The economy, sociology, and practice of popular music’. In this course, theoretical and practical knowledge on contemporary popular music production, distribution and consumption is combined to offer students cutting-edge insights into the popular music landscape.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114623,2023,Popular Music: Industry & Society,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. JCF Schaap'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In this theoretical course, students will be made familiar with both the sociology (society) and the economy (industry) of music. On the one hand, students are invited to theoretically engage in the critical and systematic study of popular music’s role in societies from its beginnings in rag time and youth cultures to its contemporary position in 21st Century digital landscape. Key concepts such as genre, scene, identity formation, authentication processes, social and symbolic boundaries, counter- and subcultures and social inequality based on musical preferences will be fundamental in this approach. On the other hand, an industry approach will familiarize students with the functioning of the music industry – both at the level of musicians and global media companies. Students will discuss popular music law, regulation and technology – particularly in a time of rampant illegal downloading/streaming and DIY music production. These developments have brought to the fore advantages and disadvantages for both musicians and the music industry, which do not always serve both parties’ interests. Moreover, industry and organizational structures are discussed in combination with artistic career development. This perspective will also allow us to get a glimpse of the future of music: Web 2.0 and 3.0, the metaverse, algorithmic taste prediction, and the global hegemony of IT companies such as Google, Amazon, TikTok and Spotify.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this course, students are given the opportunity to focus on a specific cultural product that plays a fundamental role in everyday life since the early 20<sup>th</sup> Century: popular music. The topic is approached from two distinct approaches: society (sociology/history) and industry (management/economy). The course aims to familiarize students with the importance of popular music in everyday life and the cultural industries, and provide a toolkit for both critical thinking on and working in/with popular music.</body>

column1: A large variety of economic activities takes place in seaports and seaports are important locations in worldwide logistics processes. The course offers the student an overview of the field port-economics.
In the course the following issues are discussed.

column2: • The position of a port as a node in worldwide transport. What is the impact of emerging processes of deglobalization and trade wars? What is the impact of the dominant but changing position of China?
• Port competition: regulations, institutional structures, the structure of supply chains and the effects on seaports.
• Ports as clusters of economic activities, including activities such as oil refining, chemicals production, logistics, trading, etc., and the competitiveness of these port clusters.
• Strategic, tactical and operational aspects of (container) terminal operations and the implications of mega-containerships (24000TEU).
• The implications of the transition towards sustainability for the operations of ports.
• Basics on the production of green house gasses in the port, related to the different port functions.
• Strategies to improve sustainability in ports and comparing strategies from different ports.

column1: An excursion in the port of Rotterdam is part of the course. The preferred destination for the excursion is the mega-container terminal of ECT at the Maasvlakte. In a bus tour an impression of the port will be given.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Presenting the basic port functions, stakeholders and institutions. Who is who in port economics, what is the core economic function of a port?
• Describing logistics concepts and the changing structure of supply chains and understanding the implictions for maritime transport, port operations and hinterland logistics operations.
• Explaining the economic functions and economic impact of ports as well as changing social attitudes towards the port function.
• Explaining sustainable trends and standards that have an impact on the current activities of ports.
• Explaining how the business case of port activities changes due to the energy transition.
• Explaining the sustainable strategic value of ports in relation to inclusive prosperity.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>The port economics course is organized around two overarching themes. The first theme offers the student insight into the most important practical and theoretical issues of ports in general and containerization in particular. The second theme offers the student insight into sustainability issues related to ports. In many European countries, the center of gravity of national CO2 production lies in the seaports. So decarbonising the seaports is decarbonising the national economy. Therefore, in the second part of the course, special attention will be paid to strategies to decarbonise seaports.</body>

LM van der Lugt', 'drs. M Jansen', 'MA Streng', 'prof.dr. AW Veenstra', 'prof.dr. H Geerlings', 'prof.dr. RA Zuidwijk', 'prof.dr.ir. R Dekker', 'WAA Jacobs']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>

column1: Rotterdam is renowned as one of the largest port and shipping centers of the world. The port of Rotterdam is situated in one of the most competitive port regions in the world. Internationally, the port and city are famous for its large scale port development projects, sustainability, engagement with stakeholders, and cluster governance, entrepreneurship and proactiveness towards embracing new technologies. This Minor broadens the horizon of students towards the highly dynamic world of shipping, ports and transport. Port and shipping are in a transition of decarbonization which is going to have a major effect on ports as gateways and industrial clusters.

This minor offers bachelor students the possibility of understanding the processes underlying international transport networks from an economics, operations and management perspective. It is an opportunity to learn about international and maritime transport, terminal and port management, intermodality and hinterland transport, and the interrelationship between port and region from a multidisciplinary perspective.
In this minor the following topics will be discussed:

column2: • Maritime Economics, which deals with the transportation of goods by sea.
• Port Economics and Management, which deals with the economics and management of seaports.
• Container Logistics and Inland Network, which deals with container logistics from a door-to-door perspective

column1: Students are challenged to use and integrate the knowledge from these modules in case assignments. This minor brings students in close encounter with port and maritime professionals. Students take advantage of learning from the port of Rotterdam, engage with both academia as well as professionals from the port and terminal companies.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Understanding of the processes that underlie port management and maritime logistics from an economics, operations and management perspective.
• Undertake a policy analysis of a Port Authority’s strategy.
• Comprehend a basic forecasting of a port’s throughput and assess the competitive position of a port.
• Write critical review of literature, facts and figures to assess why ports matter for regional development.
• Undertake a basic methodology to assess the role of ports in maritime and hinterland systems.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course surveys the portfolio choice literature with a focus on the econometric methodology. We use both classical as well as Bayesian techniques to model future asset returns and form optimal portfolios. We start with efficient set mathematics and mean-variance analysis. Then we proceed by assessing the performance of the allocations out-of-sample. Finally, we analyze more sophisticated econometric techniques to improve performance. Following this we deal with long-term strategic asset allocation. We first analyze the standard methodology to understand the difference between short-term and long-term investors. Next, we critically assess the plausibility and performance of the outcomes. Finally, we consider more plausible specifications that incorporate realistic aspects such as parameter uncertainty and model instability.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• You learn about the newest academic insights regarding the calculation, interpretation and implementation of optimal portfolios.
• You learn about (solutions to) the implementation issues that one encounters when implementing optimal portfolios in practice.
• You learn about new econometric techniques (such as shrinkage estimators) for modeling asset returns that are especially important for portfolio choice.
• You learn how to calculate (analytically and numerically), interpret and implement optimal portfolios for short-term and long-term investors.

column1: The seaport of Rotterdam is the main gateway to the European market, although it is much more than a node in which cargo is transferred between ship and shore. The quality and competitiveness of the port is determined by its position in networks, both at a local level, and at a global level. These networks are transport links with the other major ports in the world – Singapore, Shanghai, Dubai, New York/New Jersey, and the major ports in Europe Antwerp, Hamburg, Bremen, Le Havre, and multimodal transport links with the main destinations in the European hinterland. In addition, the port is also a network of industrial activity that facilitates a large number of supply chains with transport, storage, production and other activities. Finally, the port is embedded in a network of information exchange that enables safe and secure port operations, the efficient management of transportation in and around the port, and the smooth flow of goods through the port.

This course aims to provide a sound understanding of the role of the port in global networks, and let students gain experience with the development of new and innovative solutions for current problems that exist in this complex context. The elective will provide a variety of perspectives on the port from a number of disciplines, such as port management, legal aspects, public administration aspects, and business economic aspects.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110155,2023,Positive Organizational Psychology - Motivated, Engaged, and Happy Workers",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. EA el Khawli'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Employees play a crucial role in the success of organisations. In a fast changing and competitive environment, the performance of organisations is in part dependent on the engaged and proactive behaviours of their employees. For example, employees can learn new skills that will help them with their job, they can voice out new suggestions to their team, and find new and innovative ways to go about their daily tasks. Often, these positive organisational behaviours are positively linked with employee health and well-being. Therefore, modern organisations can
stimulate such positive organisational behaviours, and thereby ensure employee well-being through invigorating job design and leadership.

In this minor, students will explore how organisations can build an engaged, proactive, and healthy workforce and understand the psychological processes at play in organisational performance and well-being. Examples of topics that will be covered include job design, leadership, motivation, work engagement, emotions, job crafting, coping with work stress, and work-life balance.

This minor provides students who are interested in work and organisational psychology a unique opportunity to learn about the latest insights from the fields of organisational psychology, organisational behaviour and occupational health psychology, applied to relevant issues in human resource management, people & culture, and personnel selection. The minor has unique added value to the knowledge gained in economics and business administration.

The minor will be open for international students. For this reason, all the material and activities will be in English. The language used in all tutorial groups will be English. The course is offered offline (on campus). Attendance to the tutorial meetings is obligated. Students may not miss more than 1 tutorial meeting in each part of the minor (2 in total). Exemptions may be granted in case of a force majeure and after consultation with the student advisor. The exam will be in English only.

Students from all educational backgrounds are admissible for this minor. It is a broadening minor which automatically implies that psychology students are excluded. Students who do not have a background in problem-based learning (PBL) will need to know the didactical model of PBL will be used in this course. Before the course, a short introduction will be provided in PBL for all students enrolled in the minor.

The first module focuses on top-down approaches to employee engagement and well-being. Employers can motivate employees and promote their well-being by designing meaningful and challenging job tasks and providing workers with resources (e.g., job security). Students will also learn about the role of HRM policies in promoting engagement and well-being. The social work environment will also be considered, as interactions with colleagues can influence how workers perceive their social environment. Additionally, students will explore the role of leaders in promoting well-being and work engagement. Constructive leaders can offer guidance and support and are able to coach followers towards goal attainment. Through emotional contagion, leaders can also promote a positive and motivating work and team climate.

The second module of this minor focusses on bottom-up approaches to employee engagement and well-being. Students will learn about the psychological processes that underlie motivation at work and goal attainment. Furthermore, students will learn about how workers can create their own jobs and manage their own careers through job crafting and proactive career behaviours. We will also explore how workers cope with work-related stress, and how they regulate their emotions in different work situations. Finally, students will learn about work-life balance, including concepts such as psychological detachment and work-family spill-overs.
Teaching method(s): Problem Based learning: Tutorial groups, self-study and lectures.
Teaching materials:  Recent journal articles and book chapters, provided on the internet.
Both modules will be concluded with a final exam consisting of true/false and multiple-choice Questions. The grades of both modules count equally in the final grade. The exam is in English.
In order for students to pass the course, both parts of the exam need to be graded with 5.5 or higher.
Students will be offered the possibility to review their answers for each part of the exam shortly after the grades have been announced.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Students will gain knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Job design and work engagement. How can we design jobs that motivate workers and promote their well-being?
• Positive human resource practices. What HR practices contribute to productive and happy employees, and prevent burnout?
• The social work environment. How do interactions with colleagues relate to worker well-being? What is the role of fairness and justice in work well-being?
• Leadership. How can leaders inspire their followers, and how can leaders ensure follower well-being and performance?
• Work motivation. What are the psychological processes of work motivation? How do workers set and achieve their work goals?
• Job crafting and proactive career behaviours. How can workers tailor their work to their own needs? What is the importance of proactive work behaviours (e.g., job crafting, idiosyncratic deals)?
• Coping with stress at work. How can workers best cope with work stress? Are certain job stressors more difficult to cope with than others?
• Work-life balance. How do workers achieve work-life balance? How can work-family conflicts be prevented?

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116705,2023,Positive Psychology for Career Success,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. EM de Jong', 'prof.dr. MC Schippers']",,"Inhoud

</style>

column1: Research has shown that having a purpose in life is an important human need. At the same time, work and career are fundamental and pervasive experiences in life. Many people are unable to find fulfilling jobs that offer purpose and meaning. Many young people especially experience difficulties finding meaning in life, study and career. A life crafting program that guides students in setting life goals and finding their purpose has many benefits for mental and physical well-being, and study success (for an overview, see Schippers & Ziegler, 2019). Positive Psychology interventions during studies and in the workplace can improve important outcomes, such as increased engagement and academic and career success.  At the Rotterdam School of Management (RSM), prof. Schippers has implemented a life-crafting intervention for bachelor students from 2011 onwards. Research has shown that this intervention raised students’ performance by 22 percent compared to earlier years and has boosted retention rates. We argue that it is important to add life skills to students' curriculum because they may benefit from them not only during their time as a student but may do so throughout their lives and in their career. This course will teach students the principles of life crafting, letters to the future, gratefulness and other positive psychology interventions, and the theory behind them. Using these in a coaching trajectory or as a (HR) manager in the workplace can add value and optimize performance and happiness at work.

In the course, students will learn how to apply positive psychology interventions in their daily (student) lives, as well as how to implement such interventions in a company, or as part of a coaching trajectory.
